Title: Athens, Greece — not what I was expecting… Here’s my review
Content:

Having read plenty of online reviews, travel blogs and YouTube videos on the Greek capital, I had the impression that Athens would be a dull and hectic city — with some random ancient ruins dumped on a hill in the middle of it all.
And while the some suburbs certainly have this “rundown, hectic” vibe, the historic center shocked me!
I visited in the middle of August 2023 — peak tourist season in Europe. As you can imagine, it was very hot! And while the city was certainly beaming with tourists, there was a chilled ambiance within the historic center… Green-leaved trees lining cobbled streets filled with quaint shops, flea markets, cafes and restaurants. And not to forget, the occasional grandpa sitting on his stool signing Greek songs with his acoustic guitar… Very Greek!
I think Athens is a perfect destination for a three day long weekend break. Outside of the main attractions — the Acropolis, the Ancient Agora and the Temple of Zeus — there actually isn’t ‘too’ much to do. And all the sites and attractions are all within walking distance in the historic center. But don’t get me wrong, I certainly wouldn’t have minded spending longer in order to line up my stomach with endless kebabs and gyros (yum)!
If this all sounds appealing — go and book flights and your accommodation! Below I will give a brief overview of my trip…
I arrived in Athens around 7:30am local time after a 3.5 hour flight from Riga, having spent the previous ten days in the Baltic states. Luckily Latvia and Greece are in the same time zone, so no jetlag… But, yes, it was not easy getting sleep on an early hours flight! Plus, my flight was slightly delayed (but not quite enough for me to claim compensation — aha!)
Athens airport is connected by the Athens metro system on Metro Line 3. Using the metro is the most convenient hassle-free way to get into the city. I actually have a YouTube shorts video which you can watch by clicking here on how to use the Athens metro.
The journey from the airport into Monastiraki station (the metro station bang in the city center) is approximately 45 minutes. The intense early morning heat could be felt immediately after coming out of the station! I dropped off my bags at my accommodation and headed straight for the Acropolis.
I highly recommend booking tickets to the Acropolis in advance in order to skip the queues (which can be long). You can book tickets for the Acropolis by clicking here — and you can also book guided tours and audio tours via the link as well!
Important tip: do not forget to bring your phone or camera with you to take endless pictures of all the ruins and the incredible skyline views of the city — you’re going to want to! And another word of warning — make sure you wear trainers with a solid grip! The Acropolis is full of slippery marble on the ground.
After a couple of hours of enjoying the spectacular ruins and the breathtaking city skyline, I felt pretty hungry. I headed a restaurant called Thanasis, which is located within close proximity to Monstiraki station. I indulged in a traditional Greek salad and a lovely meat kebab with yoghurt and tomato sauce all drenched on a soft piece of pita — and an ice cold Mythos beer too!
I then got a bit of a nap after a long day, and later headed out to Athens Hawk Hostel rooftop bar — there are many rooftop bars across the city and I definitely recommend you visit one. You get incredible views of the Parthenon lit up under the night sky.
My second day began by walking down to the Hellenic Parliament building. I was amazed how the guards were able to withstand 35 degrees Celsius height whilst in full clothing — poor blokes!
I then headed down to Panathenaic Stadium — the host stadium of the first modern Olympic Games in 1896. You may be interested in booking not only a guided tour of the stadium, but also an Olympic style workout on the stadium! Click here if you’re interested!
Next, I explored the Temple of Olympian Zeus — the ancient place of worship to Zeus. I enjoyed a nice stroll along the cobbled and marble streets within the historic centre. I then headed over to the Philopappos Monument to get some more skyline views across the city. The afternoon then finished with me heading to Tylixto Greek Wrap, where I enjoyed some gorgeous gyros — I highly recommend you come here to get some!
I had an early morning ferry to catch from Piraeus terminal to the island of Ios the next morning, so it was an early night for me. Just a word of warning however — if you are planning to go island hopping from Athens and you don’t have a rental car, make sure you depart from the Piraeus terminal. Piraeus is accessible on the Athens Metro system, and other terminals under the name “Athens” are not easily accessible by public transport.
After three days in Ios, I returned back to Piraeus after a seven hour ferry journey for my third and final day in Athens. I didn’t really get up to much on my final day — I needed to some laundry and I needed to catch up on some sleep! If you do need to get some laundry done, I highly recommend visiting the Easywash Self Service Laundry launderette located in the city center — just make sure you bring cash in euros with you to insert into the machines. You can buy washing detergent capsules in the vending machines in the store — no need to take your own!
I finished my time in Athens by having a lovely meal at the Maiandros restaurant off the corner from Monastiraki Square — pita bread, babaganoush, hummus and some kebab with fries were all on the menu for me.
And then it was straight to bed for me, as I had a 9am flight to catch the next morning to Tirana, Albania. Do note that if you are planning to head on from Greece onto either Albania or North Macedonia, both of those countries are not in the EU, so when you arrive you will need to get new physical SIM cards, or you could get an eSIM.
But in conclusion, I would highly recommend visiting! It would say, however, may consider visiting Athens during shoulder season — the heat in July and August is very intense. But even in the hot summer heat, I thought it was still ‘bearable’, due to the heat being more of a “dry heat” rather than a humid one.
Thanks for reading! I highly recommend getting a VPN for your travels — it will keep your devices protected from malware in public neworks and also VPNs allow you to change to virtual location of your internet connection, so you can access blocked websites and resources in the country you are currently in.
Please also consider subscribing to my YouTube, TikTok, Instagram and Pinterest pages!
Please note that some of the above links are affiliate — I may earn a small commission at no extra cost to you if you make any purchases on these links. Thank you!

Title: 9 days in Athens: How the Greek capital stole my heart
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Apart from maybe Paris, I don’t think there’s a city that I have heard more mixed reviews about than Athens. Over the years I have been told all sorts of things: It’s dirty, it’s the most beautiful place you could ever visit, it’s disappointing… Still, Athens was very high on my list of cities I absolutely wanted to visit, and as a lover of all things Greek mythology my hopes were high. This summer was my first with a boyfriend, and he’s even more into Greek mythology than I am (I swear he knows the details of all of these gods like they’re his family members) and so the destination of our first trip together (AKA The Big Relationship Test) had been decided.
To everyone who told me that Athens was a disappointment: Did we visit the same place? Even the first night, the very first walk through the city, I knew that Athens was about to snatch a place in my top 5 favourite cities. Honestly, what’s not to like? The incredible atmosphere? The amazing and cheap food? The breathtaking architecture? The fact that there’s cats EVERYWHERE?! I fell in love instantly.
Here’s a little overview of what our holiday in Athens looked like. Warning: As much as I enjoyed it, this trip did not go smoothly. What did you expect? It’s me.
We rented an Airbnb on a street called Kolokotroni. The location could honestly not be better. The studio was basically in the middle of the city and we were surrounded by restaurants and shops. The flat itself was lovely. It had a little balcony, it was nicely decorated and you could tell the owner had put a lot of effort into it.
Unfortunately, we did have some issues with the hot water. I had received instructions that you had to press a button every time you wanted to shower and then wait for about 30 minutes. That in itself is not a problem, although it’s not exactly ideal when you need to get up early and you want to shower as quickly as possible. But the bigger issue was that, even after the whole button-pressing ritual, there was not nearly enough hot water for both of us. The building itself also didn’t make me feel super safe, so although it was a great stay considering how affordable it was, I would not recommend it, especially as a solo traveller.
I arrived in the afternoon, ready to get to know Athens by myself. Since we had booked separate flights, my boyfriend wasn’t arriving until the next evening. I went to drop off my stuff at the studio and then went for a walk in Plaka. I got some ice cream, took in the many beautiful squares and soaked up the ambiance that was being created by the hundreds of al fresco diners. During my walk I also discovered a souvenir shop called Thiki. It ended up being our favourite shop that week. I think we went there about four times. We learnt that the owner takes care of a number of street cats. She had named them all! Anyway, I got some souvlaki and feta fries to-go that I enjoyed on my balcony. Lovely first day.
I started with a walk around the Airbnb and ended up on this gorgeous square called Agia Irini Square. It is there that I would have many breakfasts and brunches. That day I had a great caesar salad at Tailor’s House, apparently one of Athens’ most popular coffee places. My favourite thing about this square? The fact that so many cats hang out there. My boyfriend was about to land that evening, so I had some time. I sat outside and read for a bit. The weather predictions for the rest of the day weren’t looking too optimistic, but up until that point everything was fine.
That is, until I continued my walk in Monastiraki. I was still having a jolly old time, meeting cats both outside and inside in shops, but it started to rain and it gradually got worse. I then went to a cafe with a nice view of the Ancient Agora, where I thought I could sit under the awning for a bit, until the rain turned into a storm and the whole thing came down so we had to flee inside. The street I had strolled down not even an hour earlier turned into a river and I saw doormats and chairs fly past. The water was knee-high, so I knew that I wasn’t leaving that cafe any time soon. Luckily, I had a good book with me. Then, my boyfriend texted me to let me know that his flight had been delayed because of the storm.
I was surprised to see that the water disappeared as quickly as it had come down. Within an hour the streets were fine again. At least in Athens, because I later heard that other parts of Greece had been heavily damaged. I then made the mistake of deciding to not go back to the studio and stay out until I could go and meet my boyfriend in the city. The rain stopped for maybe 30 minutes until it started again and I ended up in another cafe. I received an emergency alert that said everyone was strongly advised to stay inside as apparently Greece hadn’t seen a storm like this in a while. Great. I eventually had to leave the cafe and walk through the most intense downpour I have ever experienced. By the time I met up with my boyfriend, I was absolutely soaked.
We started our first full day together with a rainy morning, but luckily that was only the first hour and it didn’t rain anymore for the rest of the holiday. We went to check out the three impressive buildings that make up the Athenian trilogy: the university, the academy and the library. For lunch we went to a place called Mam that sells pastries with all kinds of filling. I went for spinach and feta but I have to admit I was jealous of the one with minced meat my boyfriend got.
We explored the Psyri area together and got ice cream from Kokkion. Delicious!
The big day. The reason many people visit Athens. And they’re absolutely right, because the Acropolis is something you just have to see. Nothing I could write here would do it justice. BUT BE WARNED. This has to be the worst-organised tourist attraction I have ever visited in my almost 31 years on this planet.
Let me set the scene for you. About two weeks prior to our visit I decided to buy our tickets in advance, and I was delighted to see that the official website offered a ‘Skip-the-line ticket’ that allows you to not have to queue and just walk right in. Perfect!
Cut to us arriving at the entrance that morning (which of course is quite the climb in itself) and taking in three extremely long lines, although one was clearly the longest and looked like it went almost all the way down the hill again. None of this mattered to us though, I proudly exclaimed, because we had skip-the-line tickets! Until an American woman next to me said ‘Yeah, that’s not a thing.’ Scuse me?
Turns out when they said ‘Skip-the-line ticket’, what they actually meant was ‘Queue-for-three-hours-instead-of-six’. Also, there are zero signs that explain what the different lines are for, where you have to go, nothing. We eventually figured out that we had to take the middle, second-longest line to have our digital tickets printed. And so we spent over two hours in the queue either batting away tour guides who promise to take you up there immediately but you basically have to pay all over again, or explaining to other confused visitors that they still had to queue. Yes, even with a ticket. Yes, Sir, I know it says ‘Skip-the-line’, so does mine…
Again, it is absolutely worth the hassle. You would just think that one of the world’s biggest tourist attractions would be better organised. After this adventure we visited the Acropolis Museum, which was almost just as spectacular. In the evening we went for dinner in a stunningly decorated restaurant called Tazza. We also had an ice cream parlour in our area called Le Greche that we went to for dessert almost every evening!
We bought the Athens Pass, which gives you access to the Acropolis and five other sites. I would definitely recommend getting one of those as you’ll save money even if you only visit two of these sites. On the way to the Ancient Agora we bought Loukoumades, dough balls that are covered in whatever toppings you want. We went for white chocolate. So good!
We visited both the Ancient and the Roman Agora. Both are impressive, but the most main thing to see here is the temple of Hephaestus at the Ancient Agora, one of the best-preserved ancient temples in Greece. Unbelievable!
Our last activity of the day was Hadrian’s Library. By then I had also purchased cat food that I had in my bag wherever I went, so a good amount of our days were filled with me feeding cats I ran into. Did I mention I was living my best life?
Time for our first day trip! Delphi HAD to be on the itinerary, so we woke up at the crack of dawn and got on a bus that would get us there. Let me tell you one thing: No matter where you go, a day trip with a bus full of elderly tourists is an experience you won’t easily forget. First of all, there was our morning break at a motorway restaurant where we accidentally left a member of our group behind, so we had to go back to pick them up.
But the absolute highlight happened when we were at the site itself. Two older women lost it at the tour guide because their headphones weren’t working properly, after which the guide spent the rest of the tour making snide comments about the ladies under her breath, but also still loud enough that everyone with working headphones could hear it. This whole thing was almost as entertaining as Delphi itself. Also an absolute must, by the way. The history of that place is beyond interesting and the view is stunning.
Our last full day in Athens. After a visit to the Temple of Zeus, another site that’s included in the Athens Pass, we decided to have a relaxing afternoon so we chilled in the national garden for a bit. We still had an exciting evening activity planned though! We went to the top of Lycabettus Hill to see the sunset, which was absolutely packed with people, but breathtaking nonetheless. When I say ‘we went to the top’ I mean we had to climb for about half an hour and then took the rickety cable car that made both of us fear for our lives so many times that I almost regretted not walking all the way up myself, which is saying a lot. The sunset more than made up for it though. It was a perfect way to end the day.
For our last full day we decided it was time for another day trip. There were several options and I still had things on my list that I really wanted to see (the temple of Poseidon being the main one), but we were also really craving a more relaxing day and we were both desperate for a swim. So we took the ferry and arrived in Aegina about an hour later. This is just a gorgeous island with several beaches, great restaurants and the best pistachio ice cream you’ll ever eat. The island is famous for its pistachios, so of course I had to try my favourite ice cream flavour here. Those couple of hours just swimming in the sea felt so nice after all of those activity-packed days. On the ferry ride back we had another stunning sunset.
My boyfriend had the earliest flight, so after dropping him off I had six hours by myself again. I also had my luggage with me, so I couldn’t really do much (not being able to leave your luggage at the hotel when you arrive before check-in time or when you leave after check-in time is definitely one of the downsides of an Airbnb for me). And so I basically ended the week the same way I had started it: by having a long lunch at Tailor’s House and watching the cats on Agia Irini Square.
I think it’s clear by now that I would 1000% recommend Athens. Let me know if you have ever been, if you would like to go, and if you will use one of my tips when you do!

My take on Athens, the birthplace of Western civilization and one of Europe’s most visited cities
Athens, the famous Capital city of Greece, is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Continental Europe, and surely one of the most visited Capital cities in the whole world.
This is obviously the case for a good reason: Athens is globally known as being the birthplace of Greek philosophy, democracy and thus, Western civilization.
From a historic perspective, there are not many Capital cities in the world that come close to Athens in terms of Historical importance and sites on offer.
In June 2021, I began my Greek odyssey in its famous capital Athens as, for like so many across the globe, this city had been on my bucket list for a long time.
In total, I spent 5 days in Athens, which was just enough to see all of the important Archaeological buildings, sites and museums.
But did I enjoy my time in Athens? And is it worth all the hype or is it a bit overrated?
I will answer these questions in this article, but I can tell you that obviously, like for any other city and place in the word, there are ups and downs about Athens, and you should be aware of both before adding it to your European or…

Title: The City of Gods
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Sharing escapades with an eager audience is every traveler’s dream

--
Listen
Share
An article about my visit to Greece, a city where historic ruins meet the Mediterranean blues
Athens, named after the Greek goddess Athena, has been a popular destination for travelers since antiquity. This bustling cosmopolitan city is one of the oldest in the world with a recorded history of over 3000 years of inhabitation. My recognition of Greece dates back to the early childhood days when I read the story of Alexander the Great, the Macedonian prince, who tamed the famous strong headed stallion as a young boy and later set out to conquer the world. In fact it was only after Alexander assumed power that the city state of Athens and the neighboring principalities conglomerated to form the country now called Greece. Alexander brought Greek ideas, culture and life style to the countries that he conquered and the marks he left behind during his conquest of the subcontinent are amply visible in Taxila which I happened to visit as a school boy.
I was lucky to visit Greece more than a couple of times and every time it was an experience of sorts, as the places transform for the better over the years. The first time that I visited the Balkan Peninsula was in the mid 1970s. It was the month of April and it was pleasantly cold out there in the open. We were told the metropolis had its first snowfall in forty years which was still visible on the top of Mount Lycabettus, in central Athens. The subsequent visits years later, in the months of July and August, were different in the way that summers had set in and the day time temperatures were some what uncomfortable. It was hot according to the European standards. Located between Mediterranean and Alpine climatic zones the city enjoys typical Mediterranean climate. The northern mountainous suburbs are usually cooler than the southern tip surrounded by the sea.
Ancient Athens was a powerful city state and a centre for arts and philosophy. It was known as the cradle of Western civilization and birth place of democracy. The heritage of classical era is portrayed through a number of ancient monuments and art works, the most famous being Parthenon and Acropolis, standing as the epic land marks. There are a vast variety of Roman and Byzantine monuments as well, the Temple of Olympian Zeus and Hadrian’s Arc to name a few. All these monuments are located within a radius of two km along with new structures like the Greek parliament, Panathenaikos stadium and the former Royal palace, all built in the 19th century. Ottomans, the last of the foreign rulers, did not leave too much of noticeable heritage and it was after their departure that the country became independent under a monarch, to be followed by a democratic set up in the times to follow.
During one of my visits to Athens I met a Greek lady, secretary to the District Manager PIA, who looked after me during his absence. She was there to help me receive my family on arrival from Pakistan. After we were through with our snacks she asked me about my choice of tea or coffee and my opting for Turkish coffee made her look visibly upset. Finding it difficult to control her feelings she very politely told me that in her country they called it Greek coffee, only to make me realize that with the long history of Turkish subjugation there was no love lost between the two neighboring countries. In Pakistan the Two Nation theory seems to have evaporated with the signing of (useless) confidence building measures and we are bending over backwards in a bid to please our erstwhile hostile neighbors.
Athens is a lovely place and it was a jolly good experience going places on conducted tours as well as at our own. We stayed at Athens Gate Hotel, named after the historic Hadrian’s Arc right across the road, and hardly fifteen minutes walk from the famous Syntagma square. Temple of Zeus stands next to the Arc and the expansive National Gardens stretch right up to the square. Syntagma, also called Parliament square, is essentially the tourist core of the city wherein beats the heart of Athens. It is an expensive area and a shopper’s paradise. The former Royal palace now houses the Parliament building and the old Parliament building has been converted into National Historical Museum, alongside the National Archeological Museum; all standing in a row at the square. During a visit to the British Museum, London, I was astonished to see a complete room placed in the big Greek relic’s hall. It was purchased by the British from the Ottoman rulers and re-assembled and erected there. Giving a soft touch to the place there are pigeons in big numbers in front of the parliament house simulating the London Trafalgar square. Tourists feed these birds and get photographed in the process.
The National Gardens designed by the first queen of Greece and formerly used as King’s private park with duck and turtle ponds and a botanical museum make an oasis in the modern jungle of concrete. Henry Miller calls it “the quintessence of a park”. A nice and calm place it is still no match in serenity and tranquility to the famous Kew Gardens in London. We were lucky to see a carnival, under way in the vast gardens, and it was a pleasant surprise to see the Greeks, young as well as old, dressed in their long and brightly coloured traditional dresses decorated with beads and thread work like that seen in our wild North. May be the invading Macedonians have something to account for it.
Ermon Street, a pedestrian road, shoots off from Syntagma square and is full of fashion shops and branded stores. Clogged with tourists at all times it is always a pleasure to be there. Language is invariably a bar for non English speaking nationalities. Once on the Ermon Street I encountered such a situation when a white tourist sought my help for ‘God knows what?’ Failing in his efforts to make me understand his question he frantically persisted with his queries and gave up only when I took out a tourist map from my pocket and waved at him. The sign language worked and he moved away smiling.
Shopping sans bargaining in Athens is not feasible by any means. The asking prices are staggeringly high. The Greeks are clever businessmen. You plan simple window shopping and you are lured into the store by the sales person. You move in to the store to look around and compare the prices with those back in your home country and you come out with ‘three bags full’. We walked into an antique cum souvenir shop near our hotel and were amused to see a coal iron put up for sale. The sales girl, seeing our ‘interest’ in the item, came over to us and started giving details of its usage some eight decades ago. We did not have the face to admit before her that it was still widely used in our country even at the turn of the century. We selected a replica of a traditional Greek chariot in the souvenir shop which, the sales girl insisted, was made of white stone. A year or so later my wife thought it had got dusty and needed washing and it virtually went ‘down the drain’ under the running tap water. It was some salt like material which dissolved softly.
The vibrant and multicultural Omonia square is the second most important centre located in the heart of the city. This area is cheaper as compared to Syntagma square and that is what prompted us to book a hotel in that locality during our last trip to Athens. It is regarded as the transportation centre of Athens. Mass transit system includes buses, trams, metro and suburban railways. Taxis are cheap and during rush hours it is considered normal to flag a taxi even when another passenger is already in.
The best way to see a place is to take conducted tours and that is what we exactly did. Some of the old and modern sites were in our walking range but for the others we booked the tours. Athens is a melting pot of architectural styles ranging from Greco-Roman to Neo-classical and modern styles. Most of the prominent buildings are from the Greco-Roman or Neo-classical era. Parthenon, the greatest monument of antiquity, dedicated to goddess Athena, stood on a hill top as an enduring symbol of ancient Greece. The temple of Zeus, the largest of the Greek temples constructed by Emperor Hadrian, has only fifteen of its original 104 columns now standing. The Hadrian’s Arc near the temple of Zeus was built as a gate between the ancient city and the Roman city of Athens. King’s palace is also nearby. According to a popular legend Lycabettus, the tallest hill in the city, was actually a boulder thrown from the skies by goddess Athena.
Panathenaikos stadium in the city suburbs, where first modern Olympic Games were held in 1896, was initially built in 330 BC. It sits in the hollow of a hill, where going up and down a couple of times you will easily burn out last night’s meal. Made of white marble, same as used for Parthenon, this stadium has a seating capacity for 60000 spectators. It is a replica of ancient Athens stadium.
The port city of Piraeus and the ancient city of Athens, initially inhabited around the holy rock of Acropolis, have virtually amalgamated with each other to make twin cities where it is difficult to draw a line between the two. The port at Piraeus is important as shipping is the other most significant industry besides tourism. Greece has 3000 merchant vessels constituting 18% of the world’s fleet. Though the revenues are gradually diminishing the Greeks still profit handsomely from maritime trade. Aristotle Onassis, the Greek shipping magnate who shot to fame after marrying the widowed Jacqueline Kennedy, after the assassination of US president John F.Kennedy, was a man with staggering wealth to his name. Besides Aristotle Onassis, Greece has to its credit the all time great philosophers like Aristotle, Plato and Socrates.
The Greeks claim that ancient Athens is the city with most glorious history in the world. It is a magical city worshipped by gods and people. It is an enchanting capital where democracy, as well as the most wise men of ancient times, were born. It is their country. They have a right to make any claims and there certainly is a fair bit of substance to their claims.
The writer is a dental surgeon and can be reached at: dsq006@gmail.com

Athens, the capital of Greece, is one of the most popular tourist destinations in the world. It also happens to be the home of western philosophy. Yet most tourists are unaware of the significance that certain locations in the city have for the history of philosophy.
Friends, and strangers, who share my love of history, often ask me what locations they should visit there.
I am originally from Scotland, emigrated to Canada about eight years ago, but recently became a permanent resident of Greece. I’ve spent a lot of time exploring Athens, doing research for various books on philosophy. (My graphic novel, Verissimus: The Stoic Philosophy of Marcus Aurelius, depicts scenes in the Ancient Agora and Delphi.) Friends, and strangers, who share my love of history, often ask me what locations they should visit there. So I finally decided to write this short guide to Athens for fans of ancient philosophy.
One thing worth clarifying at the outset is that ancient Greece ended up becoming part of the Roman world. In 146 BC, Greece was conquered by the Roman Republic, becoming a client state and later a province of what eventually became known as the Roman Empire. Later…

Title: 24 Hours in Athens: A Whirlwind Adventure
Content:

--
Listen
Share
I rarely have regrets when traveling but my confession is that 24 hours in Athens is truly a shameful tease. After booking a weeklong family tour to Greece, I knew our stop in Athens would be too short but I was thankful for all we packed in within the next 24 hours…
After a wonderful Mediterranean style breakfast at the hotel, our first and only day in Athens began (where else) but at the Acropolis. The Acropolis is perhaps the most famous site in Greece, the legendary hill containing a number of ancient sites, the most famous being the Parthenon. For me, while the Parthenon felt smaller than I imagined, it was no less majestic and breathtaking. I learned the hard way (like, really hard) that the stones of this site are extremely slippery and thankfully I only fell down once, but this elicited a near stadium volume gasp from those around me…very amusing for us all.
After we were done at the Acropolis, we took a turn through the Acropolis Museum. It was not only aesthetically beautiful with lots of light and harmonious, neutral tones, but also had many historical artifacts you might otherwise miss out on. If you go to the Acropolis, don’t skip out on it!
A site that we also squeezed in on this day was the Panathenaic Stadium. I was very excited for this one even though we were only able to stop for a few minutes. The Panathenaic Stadium was used for the first modern Olympic games. This modern stadium was built on top of the site of a more ancient stadium and is made completely out of marble.
After cramming in many site visits from the early morning to the early afternoon, came the favorite activity of perhaps most every traveler: free time to explore. During this time we sampled some gyros (a must), a freddo (iced, blended espresso), did some souvenir shopping and went in search of one of the most famous neighborhoods of Athens: Monastiraki. Our hotel was a bit far away from this area but we managed to make it there, enjoying the stops along the way. The neighborhood of Monastiraki is thousands of years old and holds ancient charm in its cobblestone streets and historical buildings.
I first found Athens to be a bit congested and urban but this made for a striking and intriguing contrast to its ancient, historical sites that have stood for so many centuries. With the incredible food, sites, sounds and smells, there’s so much to take in, making the experience all at once exciting and overwhelming. But what ties it all together is the winning Greek warmth and charisma that permeates the culture, drawing travelers back again and again. Next time I find myself in Athens, it’ll definitely be for more than 24 hours.

Nestled in the heart of Greece, the city of Athens stands as a testament to the enduring power of history. This ancient metropolis, often referred to as the “Cradle of Western Civilization,” is a place where every cobblestone has a story to tell and where time seems to stand still while the world rushes past. Athens is not just a city; it’s a living, breathing museum of the past, a vibrant hub of culture and heritage that has withstood the test of centuries.
Rich Cultural Heritage
From the Parthenon’s majestic columns, which have witnessed the ebb and flow of civilizations, to the bustling streets of the Plaka district, where the echoes of ancient footsteps still resonate, Athens is a city steeped in history. Its very air seems infused with the wisdom of philosophers, the valor of heroes, and the artistic prowess of poets, playwrights, and sculptors. In every corner, the spirit of antiquity mingles with the vibrant pulse of modern life, creating a unique atmosphere that captivates all who wander its labyrinthine streets.
Unveiling a Historical Journey
In this blog, we invite you to embark on a historical journey through the ancient wonders of Athens. Our mission is to unravel the tapestry of time, to explore the city’s legendary past…

Welcome to Athens — a city where ancient history intertwines with modern life. Come along with me as I take you on a journey through this fascinating metropolis and share my thoughts on the emotions it evokes along with my flight and Airbnb costs to my trip to Athens, Greece.
Walking along the streets of Athens, one can sense its bustling energy and the aromatic smells emanating from its eateries. Amidst the savory scents and laughter of locals, I felt a strong sense of camaraderie and liveliness. Athens is the kind of city where every street corner seems to hide a culinary treasure, and every meal is an invitation to savor life’s simple pleasures.
As I wandered through the city center, I couldn’t help but feel disoriented by the maze of narrow alleys and busy squares. However, amidst the chaos, I sensed a constant undercurrent of contagious energy and enthusiasm. Athens has its own unique rhythm that encourages exploration and embracing every moment. The city’s vibe is invigorating and creates a desire to keep moving forward.
While Athens is known for its bustling urban life, it also offers moments of tranquility in its parks and green spaces. Being surrounded by nature, I experienced a deep sense of inner peace and contemplation. These green oases serve as a retreat from the city’s fast-paced lifestyle and a reminder of the importance of maintaining a harmonious balance between urbanization and the natural world.
Visiting the Acropolis was an awe-inspiring journey through time and history. As I ascended the ancient steps and stood before the Parthenon, I was overwhelmed by a profound sense of reverence and wonder. The sheer magnitude of this iconic monument and its enduring beauty left an indelible mark on my soul. Athens is a city that envelops you in its vibrant and ever-evolving embrace. It’s a place where you can’t help but feel alive, where the blend of history and modernity creates an electrifying tapestry of emotions.

Title: Athens, Greece Street Art Map And Inner City Suburb Guide
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Splatrs is dedicated to bringing street art to those who love it with the best content on where to find street art around Australia (and sometimes abroad), as well as who you need to know and what is happening in the street art scene across the country.

--
Listen
Share
Athens, Greece, the birthplace of democracy, the freddo espresso, and saganaki cheese (all that is good in this world), is also said to be the motherland of graffiti.
The origin of the word graffiti is derived from Greek “graphein,” meaning “to write,” “draw,” or “scratch.” But moreover, the practice, as we know it today; to take to the streets to paint or tag, allegedly started with a Greek national in the US whose practice caught on and then made its way back to the homeland.
The accuracy of this tale, I wasn’t able to validate, but it makes for a good story, and with Athens density of street art — floor to ceiling, wall to wall — you feel that this must be the source.
In 2017, I had the pleasure of calling this ancient city home; soaking in the sunshine, the food and, of course, the art! When it comes to documenting street art in the Greek capital, the greatest challenge is that there is simply too much to accurately map.
One street in Athens can house more great art than an entire city elsewhere. So, I have tried my hardest to do it justice. I have broken my map into the main artistic regions of Athens and pinned spots where there is a large density of art, or significant murals to check out.
Use the map as a guide, but keep your eyes peeled from place to place, there is gold everywhere on the streets of Athens.
When first arriving in Athens, I was lucky enough to call this area home. There is a young modern crowd here with oodles of bars, restaurants, and cafes to be found. And, on basically every street, you will find painted walls.
Artists featured: STMTS, exitonwall, Achilles, INO, and Dreky the Pirate. Follow them!
Psyri is possibly the hippest neighbourhood in Athens. Again, bars, restaurants, and cafes a-plenty and an even richer density of street art. There is one street — Sarri — where you can find epic pieces from almost every prominent artist in Athens.
Artist featured: Yiakou, Achilles, David Selor, Vasmou, and Hambas.
I fucking love Exarcheia. If you Google it, you will see lots of talk about anarchy and riots. That’s not why I love it, of course, but I love the vibe of people who are passionate about fighting against the system if it is not serving the people. As soon as you enter Exarcheia, you’re destined to see political graffiti, Antifa symbols, and expressions of rage, as well as an array of murals, posters, and paint.
Artists featured: Wild Drawing, Olga Mavrommati, MOTA, and STMTS.

Title: 10 reasons to live in Athens, Greece
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
People are always surprised when I say that I live in Greece. To tell the truth I have never imagined that I was going to live here… and neither when I initially came to spend 3 months was I planning to stay for that long. Three years and a half have passed and here I am. Before getting to know Athens and Greece I didn’t have an image in my mind of what I was going to find here, and in different ways and little by little the city and the country have conquered me. Today I can say much more than 10 reasons to live here, but I will just give you a taste.
1-Weather
Greece is in fact a blessed country for the weather that it has. The only thing that I would change would be to add some humidity in the air, since sometimes it is so dry that it causes irritations. Other than that, the seasons are very well defined and never reach extremes. Of course in the North it is more cold during the winter, and in mountainous areas. In Athens, the winter hardly has temperatures below zero, normally it is between 10 and 20 degrees until April, May, and then it starts to rise. It snows mostly three times during the winter, and normally it does not accumulate on the ground. During summer, the temperature can reach more than 35 degrees, especially in July and August. My favorite seasons are spring and fall, both with pleasant temperatures, although during fall it rains a bit more. Still, in general it rains quite little in Athens (in the summer we spend three months with the sun shining intensively).
2-Islands
Who has never dreamed of visiting the famous Greek islands? Or spending the honeymoon around here? As a matter of fact, the islands are one of the most incredible reasons to live in this country. And Athens is in advantage because it has the biggest ports and it is quite close from some of these paradises. It is very curious to talk about trips with Greeks, although many of them have never visited some of their neighbor countries, every summer they go to two or three different islands and they love to talk about what each one has that is special, and to compare them. In three years, I could already know some of these enchanting places, and each year choosing becomes more difficult, as the more you listen about the places, the more you want to visit them.
3-Safety
Ok, Greece is no Denmark, and organization is not Greek’s favorite word, neither it is law. But one thing that is very respected around here, is the space and freedom of each individual. Theft is common, as also in every other corner in Europe, but here we can walk the streets at dawn without worrying if we will manage to come back home safely. Athens, being a big city and with more than three million inhabitants, might not be the best example in safety of the country, nevertheless it is rare to hear about murders or general violence against people in the streets, and even the protests during the crisis are somehow pacific.
4-Food
Unmissable! Just with this word you can have an idea of the Greek cuisine. In the last three years I have gained some kilos (and I don’t complain because I was skinny before), something that in 25 years of life I have never achieved, regardless the place I was living. Yes, the food is delicious, and there is great variety. In Athens, besides thousands of taverns, you can find Mexican restaurants, Arabic, Japanese, Chinese, Italian, Russian and so on. From Greek food, features the olive oil, the olives, feta cheese and the famous souvlaki (the Greek acarajé, as I usually compare, with this delicious dish from Bahia).
5-Nightlife
Again the weather here helps a lot. There is nothing like a bad winter that makes the Greeks stay at home instead of enjoying the night. Either for dinner (normally after 9pm) or drinks at some bar, or a club, the Greek nightlife is very exciting. Athens has different neighborhoods that concentrate these clubs for different tastes, and the best thing is that it costs nothing to enter these parties. You only pay what you drink. For the typical Greek clubs, the parties called buzukia, you pay a more expensive entrance, but it includes food and drinks. And the night never ends, you only come back before 3am if you want to.
6-People similar to Brazilians
Greeks are very different from the typical European from the North. Besides being Mediterranean, they have mixed up with Turkish, and this mix has given origin to a joyful and lively people. They love gathering to eat and talk, spending hours sitting at the table after a meal. Besides that, normally they are friendly with strangers, maybe in Athens a bit less since it is a big city. They are also passionate about music and arts in general. The only thing that I miss about the joyful Greek life style is the dance. They don’t do it like Brazilians. Although they get excited with the typical Greek dance, they are usually not moving so much at parties and clubs.
7-Peaceful life
Even though Athens is the capital of the country, it has this air of a small town. Despite having great movement and quite a hectic nightlife, busier than other European capitals, you can easily find quiet neighborhoods in the suburban areas, like small villages. Having an older population contributes a lot to that.
8-Prices and courtesies
Greece is not a cheap country, but comparing to others in Europe the cost of life is interesting. You can buy a bottle of water with less than 50 cents of Euro. And to have a nice meal here can cost between 5 and 10 euros. Besides, it is very common at restaurants to offer free water and sometimes free dessert. Apartment rentals are also cheap comparing to capitals like Paris, and even cities in Brazil, like São Paulo and Rio, and, in general, there are not big social differences. I know, for instance, people working as maid at hotels and living in a very good apartment in a noble area of the city.
9-Cafes
Athens has cafes in every corner of the city. And it is a Greek habit to go out to have coffee and chill at any moment of the day. Their happy hour is much more connected to coffee than to beer as in Brazil. OK, to me, since I am not a big fan of coffee this could be a disadvantage somehow, but most Brazilians would certainly enjoy this routine a lot.
10-Culture/History
Who does not know that Greece is one of the richest countries historically and culturally speaking and that a lot of what we inherited as western civilization come from here? Even words from Portuguese have origin in the Greek language, and they are a lot! It is amazing to go around Athens and to visit the ruins and monuments, and at any place that you go to visit in the country, you will certainly find a piece of this history.
*The text originally published in Portuguese can be found at: http://www.brasileiraspelomundo.com/grecia-10-razoes-para-viver-em-atenas-201727512

Title: Athens’ Neighborhoods: Monastiraki
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

--
4
Listen
Share
Hello there! My name is Nick Iakovidis and I live in Athens, since I was a baby. I would like to take you on a trip to my home like no other will ever take you! I’ll share with you the secrets of my city, that gave birth to Socrates and Plato, and guide you through her streets. So, prepare yourselves for a great adventure and walk with me in one of the oldest cities in Europe!
We start with the most famous neighborhood of Athens, Monastiraki.
Monastiraki is the heart of Athens. You can reach it either by bus, train or metro, so it is pretty easy to get there without getting lost. Once out of the train station, you will reach the “Monastiraki Square” which you can see in the photo below. It is always filled with people, locals, street artists, and tourists from every place on earth.
See that church in the left corner? This is the church of “Panagia Pantanassa” (“Mother Mary — Queen of the World”). It may seem insignificant, but it is in fact one of the oldest churches in Athens, built around the 10th century AD! It was originally part of a much larger monastery, which covered the entire square. When the monastery was destroyed during the 19th century, the church became known as “little Monastery” or “Monastiraki” in Greek, thus giving its name to the neighborhood! Look closely at its corners and you will spot parts of ancient Greek pillars, which were used for its building, proving how old it really is!
While the train station is a common meeting point with our friends, family, or dates, the locals don’t like spending much time here. There are plenty of routes to choose from and wander into the streets! Also, I would like to advise you not to fall into temptation and sit in one of the many roof gardens like “360", “MS Roof Garden”, “Anglais”, and “Citizen”, neither have souvlaki at the restaurants found in Mitropoleos street, near the square! These places are tourist traps and overcharge everything.
Instead, take the Ifaistou street and go on a trip to the Flea Market of Athens, also known as “Yusurum”. Originally created by Jewish immigrants in 1863, this market is where you can find anything you ever wanted. Vinyls and CDs at “Zacharias”, rock, punk, and heavy metal accessories at “Full Moon”, leather sandals and silly t-shirts, lots of hippie clothes, cannabis products, and souvenirs. Whether you want to buy a mini-Parthenon or a cool-looking set of leather boots, this place will get you covered.
But if you want to dig really deep while in there, and find valuable treasures, unlike anything else, you need to go to “Abyssinia Square”, located at the end of Ifaistou. Named after the Africans from Ethiopia, who settled there during the Ottoman occupation, it is where numerous antique shops are located. Here you will find comic books, posters, memorabilia, collectibles, rings, and telephones, all coming from decades ago! Here, laying on wooden tables in front view you may find things like broken clocks, old musical instruments, even valuable coins from 100 years ago! It is the perfect place to find a unique gift to take back!
Extra tip: every Sunday there is a bazaar of antiques here, so don’t miss it!
Are you tired from your trip and need a drink?
Then spend your time in one of the many bars, hiding around the Flea Market! Unlike those found in the central square, here you will have a great time, enjoying your drink like a true Athenian!
Need a place where you can marvel at the Parthenon while drinking your favorite cocktail or coffee? Then, allow me to introduce you to “Couleur Locale”, or as it is known here, “one of the most beautiful terraces of the city”:
Beautiful, isn’t it? “Locale” opened in 2014 and since then, it has become a favorite place for university students to party. Be sure to check out its signature cocktails like “Gin Basil Smash”, “The Surfer” and “Sleep no More”, made with gin and unique Greek flavors, like mastic, basil, and lemon. So, take your friends and go have the party of your lives under the attic night sky!
Perhaps you prefer a more quiet approach! Like a small green garden inside an old neoclassical house! Well, then say no more, and knock on the wooden door of the building right next to “Locale”. Don’t be afraid, it is not abandoned! It is just camouflage!
This is “Taff: the Art Foundation”:
Yes, this is real. Yes, it is in Monastiraki, hidden in plain sight.
TAF opened its doors to the public in May 2009 and since then it remains one of the most active and creative organizations in the city. It hosts a variety of cultural events, like concerts, galleries, and art exhibitions, all made by local artists. If you seek an artistic, bohemian paradise, right in the heart of Athens, you’ve found it!
Still, want more?
Then, take out your phone and prepare to update your Instagram! It’s time to visit the most instagramable cafe in Monastiraki!
This is “Ellyz Cafe”
“Ellyz” resembles more a pink paradise, straight out from a Disney movie, rather than an actual place. Once inside, you will find yourself enjoying your brunch on a cozy couch, while hundreds of flowers are hanging over your head. Its menu could make even Willy Wonka himself green from envy! Try chocolate pink hearts, creamy lemon tarts with flowers, and tasty rose cheesecake, which will melt in your mouth! Coffee lovers don’t forget to try a pink cappucino or a fredo latte with a large pink donut on top!
Extra tip: make sure you go to Ellyz with a friend who knows to take great photos!
Of course, Monastiraki is a multicultural neighborhood. Besides the above cafes and bars, you will find exotic places to travel you in faraway lands. Don’t miss to check out “James Joyce Irish Pub” (which is a personal favorite) and enjoy a Guinness with juicy chicken wings, while watching sports on one of the many tv screens. Or how about a visit to exotic Cuba? Seek the “Buena Vista Social Bar” and have a Latin party on its vintage decorated terrace!
It is time to share with you one final secret. Go to the end of Adrianou Street and start walking towards the centrer. In front of you, you will see one of my favorite spots in Monastiraki. On your right lies the ancient Agora of Athens, covered in a green dress of trees and bushes. You might spot the temple of Ifaistos and the Stoa of Attalos, graciously standing above all the others. Perhaps you might hear the sound of trains arriving at the station.
On your left there are the numerous cafes and restaurants of Adrianou, always filled with people. You will see elders reading their newspapers while drinking ouzo, tourists laughing and carrying their luggage, children loudly playing on the street next to people, who are selling antiques. A young couple might pass next to you, enjoying ice cream while holding hands, or a company of college students, eager to plan their night party at one of the bars mentioned above. You will hear Greek, Russian, and English, all mixed together in multicultural harmony. Perhaps, if you are lucky enough, you will feel the light summer breeze of Athens cooling your face, as the sun makes its way down to the West.
This is Athens. This is Monastiraki!
A Crossroads of Civilizations!

Title: The Acropolis: Athens’ Sacred Hill and Democracy’s Birthplace
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

From cheeky tales in history to travel sagas and cultural deep-dives, we’re here to spill the tea on society’s fabulous and chaotic evolution.

--
Listen
Share
If real estate developers from 2500 years ago could time travel to present-day Athens, they’d likely nod knowingly at the Acropolis and say, “Location, location, location,” before immediately filing permits to build luxury condos with “authentic Parthenon views.” Perched 150 meters above sea level, the Acropolis stands as humanity’s most enduring architectural humblebrag — the ancient equivalent of posting a vacation selfie with the caption “just a casual Tuesday #blessed.”
This wasn’t just any construction project — it was ancient Athens announcing to the Mediterranean world: We’ve got surplus wealth, artistic genius, and we’re not afraid to use it. Also, Sparta, are you taking notes?
What began as a practical hilltop fortress evolved into Western civilization’s most iconic symbol of democracy and architectural achievement. The limestone outcropping that once protected Athenians from invaders now protects something else entirely: our collective cultural memory of a time when a small city-state pioneered ideas that would fundamentally alter human history — all while setting the record for world’s longest-running construction project.
The Rocky Rise to Fame: A Brief History
The Acropolis’s story begins long before Pericles decided to give it a fancy makeover. Archaeological evidence shows human occupation dating back to the Neolithic era (around 4000–3000 BCE), when our ancestors apparently shared the same appreciation for defensible real estate with good views as modern luxury condo developers.
The Persian invasion of 480 BCE brought a dramatic plot twist. When King Xerxes and his forces captured Athens, they razed the buildings on the Acropolis, providing Athens with what modern architects might call “an unfortunate but clean slate for urban renewal.” The Athenians, after defeating the Persians at Salamis, left the ruins as a memorial to Persian aggression, perhaps history’s first example of politically motivated construction delays.
The Acropolis as we know it emerged during Athens’ Golden Age under Pericles (495–429 BCE), the influential statesman who spearheaded an ambitious building program funded by the treasury of the Delian League — essentially repurposing defense funds for infrastructure projects. When allied city-states complained about their defense contributions being used to beautify Athens, Pericles essentially responded with the ancient Greek equivalent of “What are you going to do about it?” This massive urban renewal project employed thousands of artisans and laborers — basically the New Deal with more nude statues.
The Acropolis: A Not-So-Brief Timeline
Architectural Marvels: The Buildings That Changed History
The crown jewel of the Acropolis is undoubtedly the Parthenon, a temple dedicated to Athena Parthenos (“Athena the Virgin”). Completed around 438 BCE, the Parthenon embodies perfection through imperfection. Its architects built subtle curves into seemingly straight lines and tilted supposedly vertical columns inward — optical illusions designed to make the structure appear perfectly straight. Think of it as ancient Photoshop: reality enhancement before filters existed.
The Parthenon’s dimensions follow a precise mathematical ratio, with its 46 outer columns assembled with such precision that many joints remain water-tight after 2,500 years — which makes you wonder what these builders would think about your contractor’s excuses.
Next door stands the Erechtheion with its famous Porch of the Caryatids: six sculpted maiden columns who’ve been holding up that roof for twenty-five centuries without a coffee break or basic labor protections. These ladies represent history’s longest-standing case of unpaid female labor, though today five are replicas, with the originals safely housed in the Acropolis Museum (except for one “recruited” by Lord Elgin who now resides in the British Museum — an international custody battle that continues to this day).
The Propylaea, the monumental gateway designed by architect Mnesicles, remains one of history’s most impressive entrance halls — though modern visitors experience it more like an ancient Greek subway station during rush hour. Its innovative design included Doric columns (the simpler style) on the outside and Ionic columns (the fancier ones with scroll-like details) on the inside, a mixed architectural order that was revolutionary for its time.
Gods, Myths, and Drama: The Cultural Significance
The Acropolis wasn’t just a collection of pretty buildings, it was ancient Athens’ spiritual and cultural heart. According to myth, the site was where Athena and Poseidon competed to become the city’s patron deity in what was essentially the ancient world’s most high-stakes talent show. Poseidon struck the rock with his trident, producing a salt spring (essentially the divine equivalent of giving someone bottled water when they already live next to a freshwater lake). Athena countered by gifting an olive tree, offering food, oil, and wood. The Athenians chose Athena’s offering, demonstrating that even in mythology, economic benefits trump special effects.
The olive tree remained central to Athenian economy and religion, with the sacred olive oil from trees descended from Athena’s gift used as prizes in the Panathenaic Games — ancient Greece’s version of the Olympics, but with more olive oil and fewer corporate sponsors.
The Acropolis witnessed Athens’ greatest triumphs and darkest moments. When Christianity replaced ancient Greek religion, the Parthenon became a church. Under Ottoman rule, it became a mosque — making it perhaps history’s most overqualified religious building. In 1687, the Venetians bombarded the Acropolis, igniting ammunition stored inside the Parthenon and causing catastrophic damage — proving that using world heritage sites as military installations is never a good idea.
The most controversial chapter began in 1801 when Lord Elgin removed sculptures from the Parthenon — proving that with the right paperwork, even institutionalized looting can be made perfectly legal. These “Elgin Marbles” now reside in the British Museum, with Greek requests for their return continuing and Britain’s finder’s keepers position becoming increasingly awkward in an era of cultural repatriation.
Visiting Today: Tips and Reflections
If you visit the Acropolis today, you’ll join approximately 3 million annual visitors in a pilgrimage that’s equal parts awe-inspiring and sweat-inducing. Here’s what to expect:
Despite the crowds and occasional scaffolding of ongoing restoration work (which has been ongoing since approximately forever), standing on the Acropolis remains a profound experience. You’re treading the same marble as Socrates, Pericles, and countless anonymous Athenians who shaped Western thought, though they probably weren’t wearing Crocs or complaining about Wi-Fi connectivity.
The Acropolis’s greatest lesson might be how it connects us across time. The ancient Athenians grappled with questions of governance, justice, and truth that we still haven’t fully resolved. As you descend from Athens’ sacred hill, you carry with you a tangible connection to the birthplace of concepts that shape our world today.
Plus, you’ve earned the right to say “when I was at the Acropolis…” at dinner parties for at least the next decade — which might be the most enduring legacy of all.

Title: Ancient Agora of Athens
Content:

Listen
Share
Athen’s Agora was the center of public life in ancient Athens, surrounded by impressive temples and government buildings. It served as a gathering place for citizens to discuss politics and trade goods. Notable structures included the Stoa of Attalos, a covered walkway lined with shops, and the Temple of Hephaestus, which has come down to us as one of the best-preserved temples from ancient Greece.
“Wow, this place is a lot,” I remarked to my husband an hour into our explorations. “Everything we have ever learned about ancient Greece originates from here. This is the epicenter of the Western world.”
The archaeological site was remarkably green, clean, and well-maintained, unlike almost everywhere else in Athens.
“Dude, could you imagine if all these buildings were tagged?” I mused.
Ryan took a good look around and replied, “I almost can’t believe they’re not.”
“In all honesty, they almost should be, as a symbol of how far democracy has fallen,” I said, unaware of how much farther it still had to plummet.
When we were there in 2018, I still believed in democracy. However, as I write this, I’m not so sure I do anymore. The thought of America turning into an oligarchy wasn’t even on my radar back then. What was Elon Musk even doing in 2018? Sure, he was the CEO of SpaceX and Tesla, and he was making headlines for selling flamethrowers and trying to rescue some trapped Thai kids in a cave. But the idea of him overthrowing the U.S. government and acting as its president seemed highly unlikely. Why would a billionaire even do that? And if one did, it certainly wouldn’t happen in America, the home of the so-called leader of the free world. Fast forward seven years, and now I believe democracy is a dying institution.
Although we do not practice democracy in its purest form today, even ancient Greece encountered similar challenges and sometimes fell into oligarchy. The term “democracy” literally means “people power,” and one of the most notable features of their system was the absence of political parties. I salivate just imagining a system where voting was based solely on majority rule, without an electoral college to alter the final results.
I used to believe in voting, as well, but that, too, is something I now question. However, it’s more accurate to say that I don’t trust any politicians — not a single one of them. No one I voted for is standing up against the looming oligarchy because they are part of it. They realized there was no point in pretending anymore.
Where there’s power, there’s corruption. I’ve come to realize that democracy is no different from communism — it looks good on paper. The realities of political maneuvering, social inequality, and the influence of money often contrast sharply with democratic ideals. Therefore, while democracy is often celebrated as a preferable system of governance, it still has the potential to fail. And when democracy falters, it can bring an entire country down with it.
The Temple of Hephaestus loomed over Athens’ Agora on a hill not far in the distance. The temple was originally dedicated to the Greek god of artisans, blacksmiths, carpenters, metallurgy, fire, and volcanoes — more commonly known as Vulcan in Roman mythology. Visitors are not allowed inside; even in ancient times, ordinary people could not enter the inner sanctum — only priests had that privilege. The interior featured a large statue of the deity, which could be seen from outside when the temple doors were open, allowing the gods to “see” the rituals performed in front of the building.
It’s my theory that democracy has shut itself away inside this temple. Whenever the temple doors are opened, democracy remains a deity that citizens can only gaze upon and worship from a distance.

Title: Greece, Checked! Exploring Athens, Santorini, and Crete
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
“It takes a lifetime to discover Greece, but it only takes an instant to fall in love with her.” — Henry Miller
Starting my unforgettable journey through Greece, I’m excited to finally check it off my bucket list while diving into its stunning beauty and fascinating history.
Thanks to my travel agent’s help, who carefully put together a package including visits to Athens, Santorini, and Crete, along with accommodations and airport transfers, all I needed to do was book a flight.
I started my journey in Athens, a city that effortlessly blends ancient history with modern culture. As I walked through the streets of Plaka, I was captivated by the combination of ancient ruins and bustling cafes, which revealed the city’s rich history and culture at every corner.
During my stay in Athens, I visited the Parthenon atop the Acropolis, one of the most iconic landmarks in the world. Standing beneath the ancient temple, I was awestruck by the sheer scale of its history and significance. The Parthenon’s towering columns and intricate carvings are a true testament to the brilliance and craftsmanship of the ancient Greeks.
To fully immerse myself in Athenian life, I chose to stay in the heart of downtown Athens. This allowed me to walk everywhere, making it easy to explore landmarks such as Syntagma Square, Monastiraki Flea Market, and the vibrant neighborhoods of Psiri and Exarchia. Being centrally located made me feel part of the city’s pulse, and I enjoyed soaking up the vibrant atmosphere that surrounded me.
“I want to have an ‘Eat, Pray, Love’ experience where I drop off the face of the planet and move to Greece.” — Jennifer Hyman
My journey then led me to Santorini, a destination that had long captured my imagination. As the ferry approached the island, I was greeted by a breathtaking panorama of white-washed buildings clinging to cliffs, adorned with blue-domed churches. The striking contrast between the pristine whitewashed architecture and the deep azure of the Aegean Sea was truly mesmerizing, creating a scene straight out of a postcard.
Exploring Enchanting Villages:
Stepping onto Santorini’s shores felt like entering a dream. I embarked on a journey to explore its enchanting villages, starting with the iconic Oia. Its narrow cobblestone streets led me on a whimsical journey, lined with charming cafes, boutique shops, and art galleries tucked away in every nook and cranny. The village’s crowning glory, however, was its unparalleled sunset views. Joining fellow travelers atop the cliffs of Oia, I witnessed nature’s masterpiece unfold as the sun dipped below the horizon, painting the sky in hues of gold and crimson.
Continuing my exploration, I ventured to Fira, Santorini’s bustling capital perched atop the caldera cliffs. Here, I found a vibrant atmosphere pulsating through its labyrinthine streets. From chic boutiques to traditional tavernas, Fira offered a delightful blend of modernity and tradition. And no visit to Fira would be complete without a stroll along the cliffside promenade, where panoramic views of the caldera stretched out before me, offering a glimpse into the island’s volcanic past.
Embracing the Island’s Natural Beauty:
Santorini’s allure extends beyond its picturesque villages, beckoning travelers to immerse themselves in its natural wonders. I embarked on a trek along the caldera rim, traversing rugged terrain and ancient pathways carved into the cliffs. With each step, I was rewarded with sweeping vistas of the Aegean Sea and the neighboring islands, a reminder of the island’s volcanic origins.
Moreover, Santorini’s beaches are not to be missed. From the black sands of Perissa and Kamari to the red sands of Red Beach, each shoreline offered its own unique charm. I spent my days lounging on the sun-drenched shores, taking refreshing dips in the crystalline waters, and soaking in the Mediterranean sun.
A Word of Advice: Bring Comfortable Walking Shoes:
As I navigated Santorini’s enchanting landscapes, one thing became abundantly clear: comfortable walking shoes are an absolute must. Whether exploring the winding streets of its villages or trekking along the rugged coastline, sturdy footwear ensured that I could fully enjoy all that Santorini had to offer without any discomfort.
Finally, I set sail for Crete, the largest of the Greek islands, and a place of myth and legend. Exploring the Palace of Knossos, I felt like I was walking in the footsteps of ancient kings and heroes, with the echoes of the past reverberating through the labyrinthine ruins. I also took the time to unwind on Crete’s beautiful beaches with their crystal-clear waters and golden sands, which offered the perfect respite after days filled with exploration and discovery.
In conclusion, my Greek odyssey exceeded my wildest expectations, offering a tapestry of experiences that will remain in my memory for years to come. I am grateful for the opportunity to have experienced Greece’s natural beauty, rich history, and vibrant culture. I know that Greece will always hold a special place in my heart, beckoning me back to its shores time and time again.
“There are two kinds of people. Greeks, and everyone else who wish they were Greek.” — My big fat Greek wedding
--
--
Alka Mehta is a published writer for The Motley Fool and NerdWallet, with degrees in finance and computer science.

Entry 150. Athens, GreeceThursday, April 20
After some seriously rocky adventures on Kefalonia, I was kind of looking forward to heading back to big-city civilisation. The Greek islands have great potential but they can be quite hard work, especially so if you visit outside of high season.
To be honest I felt the least welcome of any place on my travels whilst being in these islands because of grumpy locals, over-priced food and accommodation, difficulty in getting places and the slapstick level of service.
Maybe it’s a Greek thing, maybe it’s just that they’re sick of tourists because we’ve been coming here for thousands of years. Whatever. I hope I do it justice, so please bear with me.
