Title: Athens, Αρετή, Alekos Fassianos and My Papous
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
“Prosochí ton eptivon”. A message in Greek broke out through the intercom, pulling me out of my drowsy state. I checked the time. We were soon to land. I inferred I was listening to a seatbelt advisory. Having already fastened my seatbelt, moments later the English version came on confirming my intuition, announcing further that our descent into Athens had begun. I began pinching myself. I had been intermittently napping, but the adrenaline began coursing through me as I approached the land of my fore-bearers. I was arriving, but some part of me felt I was returning. Something was stirring within me.
Curious as to the plane’s relation to Athens I peered outside. Resting above the horizon was a bed of low hanging clouds. The plane was descending along with the sun, which casted an orange-peach hue over the bed of clouds. They were tipped with pink highlights. Fluffy like cotton candy. It was so peaceful. They were hovering over the dark blue ocean as if trying to hide the horizon. This scene mesmerized me. An island quickly faded from the view, supplanted by a mountainous coastline. Greece had already enchanted me with her beauty and I hadn’t even landed yet.
The intercom spoke once again, returning my attention to the cabin. I caught nothing. The phonology captivated me. It swayed itself to a rythm which enchanted me. Had my late papous, my greek grandfather, been beside me he could have translated the message for me. He would have won the hearts of the cabin crew members, by his charm and capacity to speak greek. He would have understood everything. He would be completly at ease. He could have taught me greek. I might have known just enough to impress a greek girl. I am sure that’s what he would have wanted for me. I chuckled.
I felt him near. I felt him almost beside me. I began to concentrate on the map of Greece, displayed on the screen in front of me. Particularly I focused on the Peloponnese where his father Elias emigrated from a little over a century ago. I placed my pointer finger over where I estimated Stemnitsa was, his village. I glanced beside me to the unoccupied seat and wished that he was beside me. I knew I felt him with me. He was in my heart, encouraging me and I knew above he was dancing that his engonós (grandson) was arriving in the land of our ancestors.
I arrived to Athens with no itinerary prepared. I also had no cellular data, so I was already in for an adventure. While this would concern most people I found it better to wing it. An itinerary impeded spontaneity I believed. I was to follow my travel ethos. Be curious and spontaneous. Befriend the local people and live like they do. The “just wing it and see what happens” approach had already taken me far. It afforded me a flexibility that I had enjoyed. It allowed me couch surf in Vienna and befriend two german girls in Portugal. Easy for a white 23 year old male, foolish enough to believe that he manifested this fortuitous timing. Granted it seemed like a recipe for disaster. Often the best moments of travel are the least expected ones. They are the moments you can’t reserve on booking.com. This is a central pillar in my travel ethos. Be present, be curious, be outgoing and learn.
I disembarked the plane with an excitement akin to that of a schoolboy leaving for summer vacation. My immediate objective was to find my way to the city center. With this thrill coursing through my veins, I boarded the X95 bus and seated myself. The man beside me put on his headphones, tuning himself out, but I wanted to tune in. Tune in to this wonderful sensation, this natural high of being in the land of my forefathers.
After taking a seat towards the back, my ears suddenly perked up. It was a familiar language. It was not greek, nor english but rather Spanish. Oh how that thrilled me! I tilted my head back ever so subtly, confirming that given their accent they were a spaniard. I took a glance back at a young man by himself with a phone pressed to his year. We made eye contact and I lingered by eye contact past him, as if I was inspecting the back of the buss to bluff my intrusive gaze. I turned back around, and cracked a smile. He knew I was interested in him. I knew I had to introduce myself. I had attracted a spaniard. It was only natural.
After he ended the call I summoned the courage to introduce myself. His name was Chevem (pronounced “Chema”). “Encantado!” I told him, shaking his hand. He was from Madrid prompting me to tell him, “Me mola mazo Madrid”. He was endeared that I knew such colloquialism. I further appealed to his sense of patria sharing with him of my travels to Madrid and my appreciation of its art and beauty. He was already eager to help orient me around Athens, for he was a tour guide and would show me around he promised. I felt he had been sent from Hermes. As if on cue, a group of tourists asked us what stop we were approaching. Chevem answered them in english and switched back into Spanish to continue our conversation. I felt this seemingly insignificant code switch affirmed my high level of Spanish. He was endeared by an American traveling alone, with an intimate knowledge of Madrid and its colloquialism. It thrilled him to know that I was from Boston, as he told me his close American friend Martin too was from Boston. We became quick companions. Me molaba mazo ese madrileño.
Soon the bus was approaching Syntagma, the city center. We got off together, as he told me his friend was awaiting him to drive him back. He did me a grand favor by sharing his celular data so I could navigate my way to the hostel. We left promising each other that we’d hang out.
When I walked into the hostel I felt like I was crashing a party. The place was buzzing with travelers. I waded through excited travelers drinking and sharing stories to get to the bar which functioned as the hotel’s reception desk. I soon learned it was happy hour. Everyone certainly seemed content, a group of travelers to my left were making a toast.
While checking in, a woman seated to my left answered my question about the Acropolis Museum I had asked the receptionist, informing me it was closed. She then to my surprise invited me to join her for a drink. Despite my fatigue, I joined her briefly, bonding over our common experience running cross country and passion for travel. Suddenly, I felt someone to my right. A women had approached the bar to check in. I moved my chair to afford her more space. I returned myself to the conversation, but with the new guest so close behind me I became distracted. Out of the corner of my eye I sneaked a glance as she headed upstairs, and a sense of regret lingered in me for having not spoken with her. Who was that I wondered.
Feeling hungry and the need for some alone time, I excused myself and headed out alone for dinner. The traveller who had befriended me offered to accompany me, but I politely declined. I was guarding myself a little. For some reason, remaining alone felt most comfortable. Tired, and perhaps accustomed to my solitude, I needed to decompress after hours of travel (in two days I had traveled through three countries).
Soon I found myself at a nearby gyro shop, just around the corner. I was spacing in and out while waiting for my order. Soon, I heard the cook call to me, calling me twice “Friend, friend!”. I turned around to see him smiling beckoning me retrieve the pork souvlaki I had ordered. It was delicious. I was to return here several times, for the quality and for the cheap prices, 2.50 euros for a souvlaki. The place seemed to be family owned becuase of the charm it exuded.
Not a few minutes later entered a young, attractive women dressed in all black. She was alone as well and seemed oddly familiar. She was beautiful. Stunningly beautiful. Black hair and fair skin. She ordered and went outside, I presumed to smoke. One minute there, then she was gone. Quicker than I could think to approach her. My mind, which had been in a state of dormancy due to the exhaustion of traveling that day, came to life. Had I been more awake I might have ordered another souvlaki and waited behind her to strike up a conversation. No, I thought to myself, that would have seemed to contrived. Best that I leave her alone, I figured. But something began stirring within me, urging me to reach out and introduce myself. Just as I had done a hour ago with Chevem. I ordered another souvlaki, perhaps to buy myself more time to think as she was now outside eating her dinner.
Time was ticking. I was mustering up the courage to approach her. Of course I had to. It would be disingenuous to my nature to pass her by without a friendly hello. Yet this is what I did. I left. I didn’t even look her way. She intimidated me. A few paces away from her I halted myself in my tracks. I can’t forego this, I thought. A fierce dialogue was taking place in my head. The voice of spontaneity and the voice, perhaps, of reason. On somewhat of an autopilot I approached her calmy and directly so she could see me. The next moments were a blur.
“Hello, I was hoping to eat with you. What’s your name?” My voice felt shaky as I spoke, and I barely had time to wonder if she could perceive my nervousness or if my words sounded odd before she smiled and replied, “My name is Lisa.”
Noticing her accent, I asked curiously, “Are you French?”
“Yes, I live in Paris,” she said, and my heart fluttered a bit. Her accent was charming. I took a deep breath and attempted my French: “Enchanté, je m’appelle Ryan, Can I take a seat?”
“Of course!”
It was that easy. It somehow seemed easier in Athens. Like it was the only city that two strangers could come together and befriend one another in the snap of a finger. Lighting a cigarette, she shared with me that she’d recently been let go from her job. She was taking advantage of the time to travel, clear her head and search for a new job. I shared with her of my travels through Europe. We quickly bonded over our love for Spain, has she had done Erasmus in Málaga, but confessed to me that she knew little Spanish. Her smile encouraged me, and I felt a rush of warmth by her openness and interest in befriending me. It felt like she too was craving some company.
She soon revealed her impeccable English, delivered with a delightful French accent. Typically, in the first few words, she would insert an “uh” at the end of certain consonants, creating a blunt yet charming inflection. Occasionally, she extended her “a’s,” pronouncing them as “uh’s,” a subtle reflection of her French background. She was already eager to spend time with me and began suggesting ideas. “We could (uh) go to the (uh) park and grab a café,” she suggested, her speech flowing melodically. The predominant quality of her articulation was the way her words blended together, allowing suffixes to soften until certain word groupings became nearly indistinguishable. It was so charming to listen to. She was a chatter box. “I think I have herdt of Boston yes!” she told me.
Not only was her company a wonderful, unexpected gift, but coming to know her that night brought to light the topics most dear to me: my family, friends, and experiences in Spain. Sharing these stories made them feel closer, and brought Lisa closer to me. She opened up about her family, too. With neither of us knowing much about the other’s past, I found such a warmth with her. My heart began to soften as I let go of the negative prejudices towards the French I had internalized from my Italian and Spanish friends. There are bitter rivalries in Europe and France is often on the short end of the stick because squished between all these countries. This generalized animosity towards them.
We put it together that we were staying at the same Hostel. And yes, it was a familiar face because she had been the women who checked in beside me. I had the sense it was her. We walked back together, exchanged numbers and made plans to have breakfast the following morning.
Going out the night before. Smoking for the first time. Karoake.
Within twenty minutes I was standing on hostel’s roof top marveling at the Parthenon. I was still on cloud nine, trying to wrap my head that I already hade made friends in a foreign city. A lot awaited me in that moment. I remained there for a few minutes, appreciating the Acropolis. I called my sister Alexis to her know that I’d arrive safely, and her enthusiasm echoed my own, fueling my anticipation for the adventures that lay ahead As soon as my head hit the pillow I fell asleep.
The next morning, after a restorative night of sleep, I woke up with an insatiable desire to explore. A breeze of fresh air entered the room. I stretched my arms and yawned as I peered over the balcony. The street was mostly covered by these beautiful orange trees. The sidewalks were covered with oranges. The apartments were all white. A cat entered my vision and darted across the road as a car approached. Awake too were the birds. I felt this street was inviting me outside. If every street had this enchanting quality to it I would be content with just a walk through Athens. I had no anxiety to google some generic, curated list of landmark, some “top ten things to do in Athens”. I didn’t need the internet to generate ideas. I sought my own experience. I sought adventure.
I found a table tucked in the corner of lobby and grabbed some fruit. Minutes later Lisa came down and sat down across from me. I continued to share with her what little french culture (music and pop culture) I had assumed from my french friends in León. As she went to grab breakfast I fetched my notebook from my room to jot down some notes as she had already begun to teach me a little french. I wrote for practice “J’aime Marseilles” sharing with her that I would greet my french friend named Theo, from Marseilles, whenever I would see him. Lisa responded “I love Marseilles too”. I made the hand motion that french rapper Juul does, which further endeared her. I appealed to he what little french culture I knew. She was delighted by it all.
After a pleasant breakfast with Lisa I went for a saunter around the Acropolis, familiarizing myself with the area and serendipitously encountering the Areopagus Hill. It is said to be the spot where the Apostle Paul first preached the gospel to the Athenians. I could see why any orator would choose the site, a prominent position where crowds could gather around.
Descending from Areopagus Hill my wandering took me into the city center past Syntagma where I watched the changing of the guard in front of the tomb of the unknown soldier, the n front of the capital building. After the solemn ceremony concluded I went and found another great gyro restaurant.
When I entered the lobby of the Hostel I recognized the man who I had shared the room with last night. I introduced myself to him and learned he was Mumbai. He was friendly and travel savy. We discussed how it had been uncomfortably hot in the room (which is why I alerted him that I creaked open the balcony door to allow some fresh air in). I told him about my pleasant walk I had gone on. It was peaceful walk. You’re not rushed when you walk alone. He told me that he loved traveling alone because everything is done at your pace. He was an agreeable man, filled with anecdotes of travel.
I was amazed to read a small kiosk that taught me of St. Paul’s passage through the area in 51 A.D. The Areopagus Hill is said to have been where Apostle Paul disseminated the tenants of the christianity to the Athenians. That was nearly two millennia ago. Incredible. A marine officer named Josh, who I would meet through the hostel, told me that Athenians, philosophers and politicians would congregate their to debate. It was spot I would return to several times, it wouldn’t get old. I went alone, I went with Lisa one time, I went with Josh and another guy to enjoy the view at night. The touristy environment almost adds to the experience. I practiced a little of my Italian with a family who asked me for their photo to be taken.
From the Areopagus Hill I let the hill take my down into the city center, passing through Syntagma, the city center, and the parliament building. Ahead on the side walk, I saw two soldiers marching towards me. They were dressed in a white garb with a red hat, a traditional uniform.
When I passed the parliament building, again on my way back, I saw the same soldiers guarding what I would learn was the tomb of forgotten soldier. I just happened to catch the change of guard. It reminded of when I was in Arlington national cemetery, witnessing the change of guard at the tomb of the unidentified soldier. We were there for the fourth of July. I was twelve then. Now, standing in Athens, I was reflecting again upon the valor and selflessness of the soldier, ten years older.
I continued walking, thinking about where I would eat. Soon I was seated in a gyro spot that I happened to come upon. The gryo was great. I thought they might have treated me to dessert because I was alone, but I would later learn it is customary in Greece for a small desert to be served.
After lunch I was in need of a siesta, and though tired I was curious to know this convenience shop across the street of the hostel. I was drawn to it by the little fruit stand, with crates of fruit and with bananas hanging. . Drinks, snack, cigarettes organized across the shelves gave the shop a cozy feeling. It had a charm.
I made the conscious decision to buy a greek product, a kind of greek oreo which caught my eye. How was I going to buy there, an oreo I had been eating my entire life? I returned to lie down in my little bed, curious as to how these oreos would taste. These were were the best I’d ever eaten. These had double the quantity of vanilla cream, it tasted fresher and cookie/biscuit part tasted a rich chocolate.
While munching on my third or fourth one (nearly half the pack) I came to discover that I was munching on the original Oreos, called in greek, Papadopoulou. This particular, more mass produced variant, comes from the traditional gemista biscuits. The Oreo I was accustomed too, is the american adaptation, the new kid on the block. The extent of the Greek influence is impressive, I began to realize they had their hands, they invented everything. After I had them, I began to see the papadopoulou’s everywhere I went.
After a little siesta, it was late-afternoon. I checked insta where awaiting me were unread messages from Lisa, who was curious as to my plans. I told her I was going to see a post-impressionist exhibit about a fifteen minute walk from the hostel. We decided to meet there within the hour. I revived myself and made my way over, hoping Lisa en route too, as I remained without data.
I had learned of the exposition from having flipped through a travel brochure on the plane. It was the first of many activities we did together. And through browsing the exposition, I learned more about her. Many of works were based on places with the French Riviera. We conversed about works set in Marseille and Saint Tropez, the later where her sister lives. She told me how beautiful those places are and recommended I travel there. I learned her father is an artist, and though now retired, was an art director (That’s how I would come to learn about Alekos Fassianos, a greek painter, Lisa’s Dad encouraged her to go see). In fact it was after the exposition, Lisa told me she wanted to go to see Fassianos.
After strolling through the well curated exposition we were curious as to what the other galleries contained. The only issue was our ticket was only for the exposition, not the rest of the museum. Though that didn’t discourage us from at least trying to enter the other galleries. We would only get as far as a few steps into them until we were caught, and asked to leave. We tried entering each floor’s gallery, hoping maybe one attendant would be more lenient than the prior, but to no avail. We laughed at ourselves. I did manage to recognize a Giacometti portrait which right by the entrance of the second floor. It belonged to his 1950’s, 60’s abstract yet figurative dull color toned style. It was silly of us.
We had a nice walk back to the Hostel together, where I left her for the day. From the gallery though the route contained its own gems. We walked past the first Olympic stadium and alongside a park full of preserved classical greek pillars and such. I took siesta and when recharged wanted to return to the Agora hill, where I had been that morning, to catch the sunset. With the luxury of time, taking advantage of appreciating the sunset was very important to me. It was a bit cloudy but I enjoyed viewing the Acropolis illuminated by light at night. It appeared even more impressive. The view motivated me with the time remaining that night to go to the museum.
With only an hour remaining, there was barely anyone in the museum and I felt that I had it all to myself. I progressed my way through the floors arriving to the top floor where I encountered the marble friezes of the Parthenon. The Acropolis was in view, the Parthenon itself stood illuminated, visible through the window.
Across from what video essay about the Acropolis. I was drifting on and off. Despite my fatigue and intermittent lapses in attention (jolting awake when a couple passed by) I learned of the tragic saga of repeated plundering and pillaging. I was shocked to learn, a French ambassador, in a bid to document the Acropolis, commissioned an artist to sketch and survey it. They ordered them to “Take everything you can [from the Acropolis], leave not the living or dead” It was shocking to see that written. That it still remains despite everything its endured is incredible. Wars, pillaging, yet it remains testifying to its sacredness.
The friezes themselves are magnificent, I was left quite impressed, proud to be related to a culture which takes great pride in its art and tradition (and the friezes are the union of both). They are remarkably preserved, and beautifully crafted, a testament to the talent of their sculptors. They depict scenes from the annual celebration of Athena such as chariot riding and processions of soldiers and citizens. Something began to dawn on me though, as I browsed, as I passed through the floor. As I saw gap after gap left intentionally between the friezes, I began to feel quite sad. The museums had intentionally left these sizable gaps between the conserved friezes to serve as a poignant reminder of the western pillaging that occurred through its history.
Lord Elgin plundered these friezes. This impunity is deplorable. One can now see in the British Museum.
The next day we went to see the Acropolis up close. Having gone to the museum the night before, I was ready to appreciate now equiped with the it’s historical context. That morning I used the panini press and made myself a simple ham and cheese sandwich. I added some apple slices, tomatoes, I sat myself down with Lisa. After a little ham and cheese pannin some fruit and coffee I headed with her to the acropolis. I attempted to use my NIE card, which proved my residency in Spain to enter for free but they caught me. She was let in free for being under 27 and a EU citizen.
She was happy to help me learn a little french it was almost comical the contrast that she spoke english incredibly well and I with my ten words in french was just hopping to add an eleventh.
As we ascended up to the Acropolis, we were greeted by the striking ruins of the theatre and the statue of Dionysus. The archaeological remnants left us in awe. A cat rested on some stones, welcoming us to the ruins. Lisa, enchanted took out her phone to take a picture of the cat, with the view of the theatre behind. She told me she would send the photo to one of her sisters, also a cat lover. We began petting it. It’s back was warm and soft. I told the cat “enchante” french for enchanted. It seemed like there was a cat everywhere in Athens awaiting to greet us.
The Parthenon was striking to see up close. I concentrated on the friezes, only a few remained intact.
Lisa led me to over to the smaller temple of Athena where I began to hear spanish spoken among a group of tourists. There were gathering themselves to pose for a photo.
As we drew nearer, I mentioned to Lisa that they were Spanish, having caught a few words. One of them had said “Venga” which gave me a laugh. Suddenly I was being asked by one of them in english to take their photo. I was of course delighted, feeling lucky to be chosen as I was already speaking to them in Spanish. “A ver, que guapos, que grupo” This enchanted them. I explained to them that I was an American studying abroad in León, justifying my decision (as I often do)
One of them told me to go along with my girlfriend, as they assumed she was my girlfriend, I told them the truth that she was my travel companion. One of them said to me “todavía” Lisa was a bit shy with them but she did speak a little Spanish to their delight. We ran into them a few more times around the Parthenon, and they remained enchanted by this fluent Spanish speaking American and his french travel partner.
I loved talking about French and American culture with her as we walked around the Parthenon. We were looking out over into Athens. Athens is a sea of white apartment dotted with ruins. Lisa, her french accent, was very beautiful to listen to.
We also ate a really lunch. There was this appetizer I was going to order but the waiter interceded and recommended I get the eggplant one that is made following his grandmothers restaurant. It was as he said delicious. I also tried Tsatsiki sauce. My mom loves eating eggplant so I thought of her.
Meeting up with Chema was a challenge in of itself. Lisa and I were heading out to Syntigama, where he told us he’d come too, but I didn’t have any data. We had to duck into a café by Syntigama square so I could hop on the wifi and locate him. After walking around a little aimlessly, we found our bearings and confirmed with him that we were to meet him in front of a Gucci store. We waited a few minutes talking about(I wouldn’t realize the irony of our meet up point until getting to know him a bit later). I was reassuring Lisa that her Spanish was good enough to understand him.
He began to take us on a private tour of the area explaining to us the significance. He was speaking in Spanish.
We met Martin in a plaza where an old greek orthodox church stood. They showed us this hole in the wall mom and pop restaurant called Alvi. The food was deilicious. No signage, one would have hardly recognized it existed at all. There was no receptionist, we passed through a narrow hall which led to an open space with these small tables. A cat crawled beneath my legs. I was enchanted with this local place far from tourist crowded sites.
We talked about many things, politics, political theory and in several different languages. English served as the common language when we all talked with one another. Chema and I would break off and speak Spanish with each other. Lisa and Martin communicated in French. Chema and Martin ordered in Greek. I was their pupil, they were my professors and new found friends on that warm Greek night — sharing food wine and conversing in Spanish, French, Greek, and English, speaking the language of those whose hearts align in hope and outrage against injustice. I had an insatiable curiosity to learn how Chema and Martin perceived art and history, language class struggle, Karl Marx, and Noam Chomsky.
I was amazed that here I was gathered in this local, off the map spot, with a beautiful french women accompanying me on my travel, a madrileño I had befriend on the bus and Martin, sharing stories of Athens and being an expatriot teacher. I must have taken it for granted that there I could be in their company, a young educated man about his tour through Europe, a member of an upper class family, and at the same time, with the company of this cultured french women, indulge himself in the diversion of meeting Anarchists; and enjoy a delicious meal as Chema and Martin explained, that the Athenian anarchist movement still breathed life into the last stronghold of international anarchism — a city harboring the fading echoes of ancient Athenian civilization. Lisa and I were with them but yet so far from their every day lived experience that I felt this fraudulence for simply agreeing with their radical view. Their raw authenticity, that they truly lived as they thought, compelled an agreeable response from me — one that felt utterly uncharacteristic. My professors and their progressive stances then seemed so inauthentic…
They told us that there was to take place a rally the next day because Greece was to privatize its school system. They invited us. We told them we would let them know. Our hesitancy discouraged them. After all we were travelers, how much was their to expect to us? They took that as a polite no, but I felt part of genuinely considering it. This wasn’t your standard vacation.
After dinner we went to this cool bar and because it closed we went with our drinks and found a little bench on the side of the street. They were smoking and the subject of the conversation was about French anarchism and the French Revolution the revolt of ’68 and the realist French art movement like Gustave Courbet
The gritty nature of the Athenian streets enchanted me. There’s this certain beauty to the urban messiness of Athens that I came to appreciate.
I don’t think I wasted a second of my time in Greece, certainly not by walking its streets with the simple desire to be lost in them. The following morning I rose early as was my habit while traveling and stretched my legs around the neighborhood. I was already getting a feel for the area and felt somewhat adjusted to the rhythm of the bustling city. I was content.
A man with a friendly face was stationed in the middle of the street. A street seldom trafficked by cars. I had already passed him once as I ventured out from the hostel, and he gave me a smile prompting me to greet him “kalimera” (good morning). In fact that simple interaction had given me the confidence to say kalimera to others who I passed, and this simple phrase helped me blend in, giving others the impression that I was a greek speaker. This felt incredible. It felt like I had really transformed myself into a native greek. Their came a certain validation from receiving these greek greeting, although they were simple and said reflexively I had an enormous pride to be engaging with them through their language.
There I was trying to make sense of what this man was promoting. To my delight, when I inspected more closely the entrance he was stationed by I realized he was working for the Cafavy Archive. The great greek poet C.P Cafavy had lived there. I felt a rush of excitement. I immediately thougt of my Dad who had introduced me to his genius. The friendly greek man outside approached me informing me that it was open to the public. He could see the excitement brewing within me. That was a lovely interaction for us both. I was spewing with excitement. Something told me he didn’t get to many 22 year old greek American solo traveler’s getting this excited for having stumbled upon the archive.
My excitement was contagious and it quickly spread to the rest of the staff who attended my questions. They informed me that the archive had just opened and I had been one of it’s lucky first visitors. They all seemed eager to answer any questions of mine. I felt well received.
These kind of fortuitous, meaningful discoveries were somehow awaiting me throughout the whole week. As I left the archive after having combed through everything it had to offer me, I interacted once more with the friendly gentlemen outside. I thanked him and wished him a good day. There’s a heightened sense of euphoria when one stumbles upon something that had been latently desired.
The archive reminded me of the epic poem of his, titled Ithaca. It was the appropriate poem to mull over given the adventure I had embarked on. The poem is sung to Ulysses the wayward captain returning from the Trojan war. It’s the journey that confirms the mission and the mission that confers the journey. The poem would remain with me for the rest of the trip. As I made the short walk back to the hostel, I felt enlightened. I began reciting the opening line of the poem. The words of the opening verses characterized the spirit of my travel.
As you set out for Ithaka
pray your journey is a long one,
full of adventure, full of discovery.
The remainder of the day was filled with adventure and discovery. Lisa took me to a café her friend recommended to her in Exarcheia. It was called Lacantina and we had falafel.
We were amazed at all the street art which made the entire neighborhood pop with color. At the museum of archeology we were impressed by this painting which one sees as they ascend the stairs.
We met up with Chema who was gracious enough to continue to touring us through Athens. He took me a bookstore where with help from an employee I was able to find a collection of Cafavy’s poetry that I wanted to gift my father. He was soon to retire. It was essentially again a private, expedited tour.
The following morning I needed to get myself to Piraeus, the nearest port to Athens. I wanted to visit this island that Lisa had told me about. Unfortunately, she wasn’t feeling well enough to do the excursion and had to remain resting in the hostel. I didn’t have any cellular data, so I mapped out the route and trusted everything would go smoothly.
The only complicated transfer was when I arrived Piraeus, I was unsure of what bus to take to get myself to the ferries. I could see the ferries, they were probably a mile or so away. While I decided what to do I order this sesame bagel stuffed with cream cheese. It was delicious. I got it from the kind of café that serves you directly on the street. I loved those little cafés.
I figured I would take any bus I could get and that I could assess from there if it was heading towards the ferries. Luckily I hopped on a bus that took me to more or less the spot I needed to be. I found the blue ferry building and I bought tickets from a kind greek women. She pointed her finger to the ferry that I needed to take and told me to hurry as it was embarking soon.
I rushed over. Got on board. And made my way to top. I could breathe. The hard part was over. I decided to take in the sun and rest a while.
After a short rest I wanted to walk around the ferry. It wasn’t so crowded. I found a corner where I could seclude myself and obtain a view of the ocean. It was msrvillous. The sea was shiny, glistening from the bright sun. I felt somewhat the sun made the blue of the ocean appear lighter, almost more vivid. I am not sure what the effect what but I felt my sense of vision improve itself. It was stunning to watch us approach these islands.
A women politely asked me if I could take picture of her and her daughter, pulling me from the hypnotizing effect of the sea. She was celebrating her fiftieth birthday by taking a trip with her daughter. I wished her a happy birthday.
I walked over with her to meet her daughter. There was something so warm about her that reminded of my mother. She called “my darling”. I was suddenly taken by their openess and warmth. They lived in London and spoke english with the British accent. Madu was a nurse and was born in Sri Lanka, a country unfortunately plagued with political violence.
Her daughter was my age and soon to graduate college. She wanted to become a doctor. I found her accent so charming. Their company and conversation quickened the ride and after talking about my year abroad, my family, America, politics and contemporary issues the ferry was already soon to dock. We soon parted ways and confirmed that we would see each other again on the return trip.
It didn’t take long for the island to enamor me. A charming little church greeted us on the dock. I had never seen a church on a dock before. Its white exterior seemed to glow ever strong with the sun’s pounding radiance. The sun warmed my spirit.
As I made my way through the town it easy to identify who and who wasn’t a local. There were tons locals riding motorcycles, the most comfortable mode of transport I figured. While they were in the middle of their errands, while travelers criss crossed the roads, impeding the flow of this slow paced island life. Even the signs enchanted me, as everything felt simpler, more elemental. I popped into greek orthodox churches and paused to take photos.
I didn’t know where I was going. I figured I would stick to the coast line and follow it. An hour had passed and I realized I was no where near the little village I had ventured out to see. The island was far bigger than I had estimated.
That’s when the courage came upon me to stick out my thumb and see if I could hitch hike, to really test the friendliness and openness of the greek people.
There was already a truck departing near me from this road I was coming from. When I held out my thumb and pointed with my other hand left the truck driver who I’d said , no he said greek and I instinctively said what he told me back he pointed the other way. Essentially he through his hands communicated that he was headed the opposite way.
The next car which drove by was this older mean who I saw was wearing a mask who politely acknowledged my request but politely declined touching his mask as to indicate de didn’t feel well. He didn’t want to contaminate me. Two cars later came Stavros who pulled ahead of me and scrambled to clear the passenger seat of some kind of bird cage. He was eager to have me. I didn’t even know exactly where I wanted to go, which didn’t seem to suprise him. I trust him and he assumed my destination was the next port which was where I intuitively was heading.
The seatbelt didn’t quite click activating an alarm. I had to hold it the buckle in place to cancel the alarm. We chatted for a brief five minutes and he taught me a little greek and he was delighted to hear that I, being American, had greek ethnic heritage. It was easy to impress him with phrases like “Christos anesti” “Opa!”. I thought he had a simple soul, so impressionable by my limited showing of greek. He was happy for me. I could tell that. It seemed like of all the people on the island and it was him who was awaiting for me to meet him. Something about the trust we had both in each other to go through with the hitch hike made the connection seemingly more profound.
By then it was early afternoon and the island became even more beautiful somehow. Time seemed to slow itself in this little enchanting port. Stavros had dropped me off and went about his errands.
There seemed to be more cats than humans.
I went through the village’s quiet streets. It was apparent I was the only tourist which felt odd. After wandering through the little port which didn’t take to long to fully know, I found a bench and sat myself down on the left side and within a second it collapsed under my weight. A few women behind me chucked and smiled at me, as I brought myself to my feet. Had I known greek I could have connected with them further. But the moment we shared was sufficient enough to express everything it held, the clumsiness and silliness of sitting in a bench that collapses beneath you. I tried to reassemble the bench but one of the green beam came out when I pulled it. Then I began to laugh and it felt so great to laugh as I walk away from the pile of beams that once was a bench.
Farther along the road I found a little rocky point along the coastline of ηέρδικλ to pause to reflect on the day, recording some thoughts in my travel journal. I recorded some of Cafavy’s poetry. As I gazed across the ocean toward the island, it felt as though the entire spectrum of blue had come alive before me — each shade represented. The sky and sea seemed to blend into one infinite canvas, every pigment of blue imaginable dancing between them. I closed my eyes momentarily, letting the first glimmer of sight settle in my mind, only to open them again, just to remind myself it was real.
Before me stretched a shimmering path, reaching across the ocean out into the horizon beneath the sun’s embrace. The gentle chirping of birds filled the air, weaving themselves into the rhythm of the waves. In that moment, I was utterly still, wholly content, and wonderfully alive.
I was so content.
I was in a state of atraxia, a state of tranquility and equanimity, free from worry and distress. Atraxia is derived from the Greek words a-, meaning “not”, and tarassein, meaning “to disturb or confuse”. Epicureans sought ataraxia as the highest goal and considered it to be true happiness.
After a brief stint of reflection I sat myself down at a calm restaurant for a late lunch. Everything I had was so fresh and delicious.
I was seated contemplating what I wanted to choose for dessert. I was going to receive a customary dessert and was given the option. A lady across from was ease dropping and interceded for me. She was an elderly women who insisted that I try a certain dessert. Of course, I obliged and went with her recommendation. She and her husband were retired greek Americans who had recently made the island their home. They told me how peaceful it was to live there. They soon gained my trust. It gave them joy to know I was greek American. They took me under their wing and expressed their concern that I was not going to make the ferry on time. I was so relaxed it would not have stressed me to coordinate how I was ever to make it back on time with no ride. They told me they would bring me.
First they wanted to show me the island. They had fallen in love with their new home. They had friends through the island and as we passed their home they shared with me anecdotes of the friendliness of their neighbors. I was impressed by how concentrated the island was with these tiny churches. Bella told me there were 360 churches dotted across the island. They explained to me that the island was home to the monastery of a greek Saint named Agios Nectarios, also known as the Wonderworker of Aegina. He was miracle healer who is considered the patron saint of people with cancer, heart disease, arthritis, epilepsy, and other illnesses. Dino told me: “and give his money to the poor people whatever money they give”
They drove me through the winding roads of the island and brought me to see the monastery, one of the most visited sites on Aegina. The monastery grounds include a large church and a small chapel where St. Nectarios’ tomb is located. Thousands of pilgrims come to the island every year they told me to honor him. They were devout greek orthodox christians and their faith inspired me. They spoke so simply. “Follow your grandfather, it makes sense” Dino said to me. He implored me to become greek orthodox.
As we zipped towards the main port I felt an incredible desire to rekindle my sense of pride in being greek. I felt an incredible honor to share ancestry with these humble simple people. I expressed to them my desire to buy pistachios. The island was known for its pistachios. They dropped me off near a pistachio vendor. I had a hour to kill and wanted also to explore the nearby marketplace. There was a fish market and other stores that I bopped into. I came across an artist selling his drawings. I stopped to appreciate his artwork. He drew on whatever he could find, scraps of paper and this captivated me. He read my interest and gave me a price. I confessed to him that I didn’t have much cash and we negotiated a price for a few drawings. I was thankful. I complimented him. He told me he was a Belgian but the art world disillusioned him and he left to find a simpler way of life. He felt he had become creatively a slave to his patrons and yearned to have the freedom to create as he pleased. He had a lucrative career in Antwerp, but walked away from all the money to rediscover his happiness. I found that admirable.
Then as I was walking away from him to my delight a fish vendor called to me signaling that Madu was chasing me down. I didn’t know that she was seated at a nearby restaurant, and through a window had spotted me speaking with the artist. She invited me into the restaurant and asked if I was hungry. I politely told them I was good but appreciated their generosity. I could tell they really enjoyed my presence, which made them already feel like family to me. It’s amazing how quickly you can bond with strangers through this particular feeling.
I also had gone into other merchant’s shops. I tried baklava. The sweet crunchy flakey dessert. Its origins are contested amongst the Greeks, Turks and Lebanese with some saying it originated in Persia. The store owners were very kind to me. They exuded kindness as had everyone on the island.
Later that night I return to Athens via the metro with Madu and her daughter. It was a pleasant return. Lisa awaited me and we went out for dinner. It was a magical day. I was reflecting and treasuring the experiences I was having, bringing them deep within my heart.
I arose after a restorative sleep somewhat on the later side. When I came down to the hostel lobby I found Tristan, the guy from Maine I had befriended. He was seated at the bar and I told him it was Joshua Laurence a chamberlain the colonel who defended the union left flank at Gettysburg. He was a history buff like me and I appealed to his Maine nativity. He was excited at what I had learned. After hours of fighting they ran out of ammunition so Chamberlin ordered a bayonet charge. The line prevailed and the Union army won the battle. The night before we were talking about the civil war and how he grew up attending St. George a private school where Rucker Carlson’s kids attended. He knew Bobby. He loved sailing. We enjoy several chats together. He was one of many people I so easily bonded with that week.
Lisa came down for breakfast and I excused myself from Tristan to greet her. We ate breakfast together and I showed her the art I bought from Chem the migrant Dutch artist on Aegina. Lisa and I had only more or less of an idea for our itinerary. We tossed out ideas, while trying some of the delicacies I had procured from the island. We tried the pistachio wafers fillers with this pistachio butter cream. They were really rich almost too much I joked. I even gave one to Josh who also was at breakfast. I recommended he go to the island and gave him the run down. He was there in Greece on leave from his military service. He was a greek orthodox and was excited to explore all the churches. Aegina would be great. I told him of my travel and he seemed eager to go. He in return recommended I go to Socrates prison.
Lisa and I went to yesterdays bread where I bought a nice vintage flannel. We’ve really had all this time this week to get to know each other. I’ve been following the story of her job situation and prospects marketing this French purse brand. Her first interview went well and today she met with the HR women to discuss salary. The final interview is this Monday so I’m praying that she gets it. The consequences weren’t that grave if she doesn’t get. In fact it would free her schedule allowing her to join her family in the Pyrenees to ski. It impressed me that she express these conflicting feeling in english so fluently.
After a little thrift shopping and Lisa’s fashion advice, we went out separate ways her to the interview and to the Alekos Fassianos exhibit. You realize here that people walk very nonchalantly. It’s a beautiful neighborhood. It’s quite sad that the center park is occupied. The federal government is planning to build a metro in Exarchia even though the referendum BU the locals was overwhelmingly against it.
The Fassianos exhibit was this hole in the wall place. There was no signage indicating where it was. I arrived and someone was scavenging through trash directly outside. I had the good fortune of arriving when a Greek women did too. I could tell she was also confused and asked her. She went into a convenience store where with the owner she asked. We eventually found it but I kind of piggybacked off her Greek to find it. I might not have found it without her presence, even though it was hidden in plain day. It was odd.
The exhibit was great. I really liked his style. It’s Picassoesque but very much his own. I particularly liked the one of Hermes on the bicycle. The greek God of messages is depicted on a bike, which I thought was quite suiting. His color palette too is so beautiful. I like the little details he incorporates into the background of his painting. Churches and often appear in his works. I must have spent a hour soaking in everything I could about the artist. I even bought some of his postals.
I had learned of him through the Lisa’s Dad who recommended she go. He was an art director teacher and continues to paint teaching a class to newly arrived immigrants. He draws a lot of nudes. Lisa actually doesn’t like his style which was a very honest confession. But she of courses loves him and the other day she called him while we were walking to get his advice. (How are you in French is pronounced more like saw va)
When I met up with Lisa after it was at six dogs a cafe besides a tattoo parlor that seemed good. I had been expressing to her my desire to get one and she encouraged me. The tatoo artist was named Bill. Bill was like always go with the women’s advice bc I though to get the smaller one. I got my first tattoo of the word Arete. Greek rap was playing in the back. I was nervous. Having Lisa there meant a lot to I think she really was encouraging. I got it tatted behind my elbow the the ancient greek word Αρετή — “arete”. It’s a beautiful word which translates to having excellence in all facets of life. It means to strive to achieve excellence in the moral, physical and mental spaces of one’s life. But beyond its translation, I’ll dive later into the meaning of the tattoo.
That night Lisa and I left the hostel to go see the sunset over Athens. We went to the Areopagus hill which is said to be where St. Paul preached the gospel to the Athenians. The view was beautiful of the city. The acropolis and everything was super pretty. Lisa and I agreed it’s better to have about a week to get to know a city like about the size of Athens. You’re not rushed and you can really get to all the areas, even the non tourist areas.
Martin recommended we go see it from here: His footnote to the link was “Go to the basketball courts then climb up the hill” https://maps.app.goo.gl/7xyos2vv716bxahg6?g_st=iw
After the sunset we met Martin at the Omonio metro station. From there we walked to a restaurant in a neighborhood he told us is starting to become trendy but still not known by tourists. That’s always music to my ears, I am always conscience of my effort to experience the authentic neighborhoods of a place. Around the hostel and Acropolis is the tourist friendly district.
Martin took us to a restaurant called Exodus Kafeneio. Martin ordered three beers for us in Greek. The waiter was friendly, Martin is considerate too he wanted to ensure we had the seats which faced the street. We were there sipping our mythos thanks to him. I relished this pork in wine and pepper sauce dish and tried some of what Martin got Turkish tortellini (tortellini with beef, cow butter, yogurt and garlic sauce, chili pepper flakes) it was great.
Martin opened up to us about his book project which is about this person who is searching for a lost artist across Detroit and Greece. He was telling us about how little the teachers are paid and many teachers work and come back from work to teach four classes of English to get by. The majority of people lost all their savings in 2008 and 2012 and people live without savings.
He used to be a communist but now is an anarchist. He shared us a story about how he was protesting in Charleston during the George Floyd riots (he was bartending there) and when the rioters smashed into a break the communist discouraged it. He realized that then they weren’t as radical as they though. They wouldn’t support the redistribution of wealth to members oppressed by centuries of racism. Also in Athens in 2011 the anarchist had the numbers to storm the parliament building but the communists prevented them. The communists and anarchists do not get along in Athens.
It’s hard to explain, and I’m sure I won’t get it quite right. You see, when you travel, you experience the moment you’re in, which absorbs you completely. It pulls you into the present, as everything you see feels new. But travel also has a way of pulling you backward in time, and even forward into the future.
Spending time with Lisa made me realize just how warm and open-minded she is, which softened some of my once harsh, intense attitudes toward the French. She confessed — quite honestly — one of the common generalizations about French students on Erasmus: their tendency to isolate themselves with only each other. And yet, I found myself defending them, comparing it to how Americans can be far more insular and ignorant. My time in Athens didn’t make me less interested in Americans; it made me even more curious about Europeans and their ways of thinking. I felt beholden to them, learning so much from their culture, their history, and their perspective.
Somehow during my week in Athens my thoughts always returned back to my family, especially my sister. We called each other one night and I cried telling her how much I missed her. I had never felt so close to my immediate family — my sister, my dad, my mom — thinking especially of her and the way she relates to our father, Angelo. Travel itself triggers its own kind of internal journey — one of reflection. Memories return, and moments once forgotten recrystallize, emerging with a clarity they didn’t have before. It’s as if the act of moving through space creates a new lens through which the past is suddenly sharper, more vivid, and connected to the present in unexpected ways.
In the end, my time in Athens was not just a trip across the world; it was a journey through time, through family, and through the layers of identity that have shaped me. The presence of my Pappous, though no longer physical, was a constant companion — guiding me, encouraging me, and reminding me of the values he lived by. As I traced the geography of my ancestry, my travels took on a deeper meaning. It was not merely about seeing new places; it was about rediscovering a part of myself that had long been dormant, a part of me that is both Greek and American.
I discovered the works of Alekos Fassianos and the french post impressionists. The vivid, dreamlike paintings of Fassianos seemed to speak directly to the spirit of the Greek people — capturing the mythic beauty of Greece while reflecting its modern, complex soul. Each painting felt like an extension of the landscape itself, echoing the timeless dance between the past and present.
And it was C.P. Cavafy’s words from Ithaca that echoed in my mind as I walked along the shore of Aegina: “To buy fine things, mother of pearl and coral, amber and ebony, sensual perfume of every kind — as many sensual perfumes as you can.” The poem spoke to the idea that the journey is as important as the destination, and that the true treasures lie in the experiences themselves. In this, I found a blueprint to reflect upon my own journey. The beauty of an island which unfolded itself in layers to me: the shimmering glow casted over the tranquil waters; the warmth of the sun and people, their hospitality as beautiful and inviting as the land itself.
It was on that island, I realized that my journey mirrored the archetypal one Cavafy describes: I heard the call, I passed the tests, and I left transformed. Greece, with all its layers of history, culture, and personal connection, continues to call me back. In its landscapes, its people, and its poetry, I found not only echoes of my Pappous’s legacy but also the deepest parts of myself.
This trip became more than just a moment in time — it was a full circle, a reunion with my heritage and an awakening to the world around me. As I carry these experiences, I feel myself walking further into the future, yet always anchored by the wisdom of the past. Greece will always be there, calling me to return, as it continues to shape my path forward.
Hoy las vacaciones de Sisofis terminaron
Exodus 33:14–16 and God says to Moses, “My presence will go with you, and I will give you rest.”

Title: Athens between past and present

Keenan’s Adventures, travels, and wordly outtings

--
1
Listen
Share
When I was moving out and selling as much as possible someone came to my apartment to buy my old mattress. On their way out they saw the two photographs I’d printed and mounted on the wall. They asked about buying them and I decided to give them the one of Saratoga beach. The brush of pastels spread across a sunset beach had given colour to an otherwise empty apartment. It was time to move on. Giving away my DIY print was a great ending for something I can no longer retain. The other print, of Yuki at a pagoda in Japan, didn’t seem appropriate to give away and so I threw it out — a symbolic guesture to move out and move on.
I’ve come to Athens on a class trip with ten other students and my studio professor. We are here as tourists but also researchers, seeking to understand the architecture and archeology of the city and islands in the Agean.
On the first day we walked around the the Archaeological Site of Kerameikos. This was the first of many walking days to other ancient ruins including the Roman forum, Hadrians library, Ancient Agora, temple of Zeus and Aristotle’s school. Many of them are ruins with little remaining but help to understand the history of the city. Since we were travelling as an architecture class, our focus was largely on the building ruins and urbanism.
One of the most interesting walks was on the first day when we visited Philopappos Hill across from the acropolis. In the 50s an architect by the name of Dimitris Pikionis oversaw the construction of roads and pathways that transformed the landscape from a visual experience to one that included the tactile roughness of old stones collected from the city. He salvaged marble slabs and reused them as paving stones to make pathways. This got me thinking that I should explore walkscapes in my future architectural research and the ways different ground conditions affect the user experience. The ground and pathways played a small part in the book I self published and my thesis. This is an area I’d like to investigate further.
The path led to a reconstructed church and pavilion. At the time of construction the pavilion had a view of the acropolis but is now blocked by trees. Our professor was of the opinion that the way the pavilion connects views, landscape, and movement all together makes it one of the most important transformative works of modern architecture. I would agree that the pavilion is quite nice and impactful but I don’t know enough of its legacy to understand it’s significance.
As one ascends past the pavilion, various glimpses of the acropolis are visible between trees and bushes. The acropolis is always present and is beautiful. The pathway changed slowly from smooth slabs to rougher flagstones eventually reaching an open plaza and at the top a monument that was once a tomb. This was our first glimpse of the city from above but not the last.
The art of photography has in it emotions of the photographer. The past three years of graduate school have been largely framed as a period of self development and growth accelerated by an abrupt transition from partnered to solitary life. I see a clear personality in the lineage of my photography that I am keen to change. Now that I’m travelling alone I feel that it is appropriate to find a new way of looking at the world. I want to be different and see that in my photography. I want this new chapter to be transformation and evolution.
A year ago, I bought an extra wide camera lens for landscape photography and sold my stock lens that was no longer giving me sharp images. This purchase was a legacy of my previous perspective to frame open landscapes and wide vistas behind a solitary figure.
As this trip approached, I reassessed my desire to obtain a zoom lens thinking that zooming in would be a suitable way to alter my perspective. I couldn’t find a good deal on a used lens and was also busy with school. A week before my departure I was again looking for a specific camera lens and reading online that eBay would be a good place to get second hand lenses. At 2AM I purchased a lens from Japan that would arrive a few days before I left. I was concerned about it arriving late because I would be moving out of my apartment the day I departed. Unfortunately I did not read the listing properly because the lens was an a-mount SAL18135 and my camera needs an e-mount SEL18135. I didn’t expect a lens would be made with different mounts so I got the wrong lens.
During our time in Athens we also visited many museums including the acropolis museum, museum of contemporary art, and archeology museum. The acropolis museum was the most interesting because it was the first thing we did in Athens and the building was very modern. It had fragments of the acropolis arranged along an interior core the same size and dimension as the pantheon. Chunks of the ruin had been placed to give a semblance of the real thing up on the hill. As an introduction to the archeology we would see in the next few days, it was an excellent appetizer. Below the museum was an excavated neighbourhood.
The museum of contemporary art was interesting because there were provocative works that spoke to geopolitical issues, pain, and suffering. We we fortunate to have a guided tour by a curator and access to the roof that is normally closed to the public. This was a unique view of the city because there aren’t many buildings taller than theirs from which to see the rest of the city. It was also relatively close to the acropolis which has protected views.
While it can be difficult to imagine a world based on foundation ruins, it helped to hear stories and read history. The acropolis was as highlight well worth the early morning visit. Arriving at opening avoided the crowds and was under a softer sun that wasn’t as draining in terms of heat. The ruins were impressive because they are clearly visible from the city but up close the scale became larger than expected. In the past it would have been possible to walk within the ruins but that has been closed off and some kind of reconstruction work was underway.
The visit to the acropolis was complemented by a reading from the professor that I reread while sitting on a piece of marble at the acropolis. The reading described the entrance sequence and the arrangement of buildings forming an asymmetrical aesthetic perspective. After reading the article I was able to walk the space and assess it for myself. It is not entirely visible today because a large statue is missing and the pedestrian pathway was altered with a horrible slab of concrete but it is otherwise accurate and interesting.
For the modern urbansim, we visited the an urban park along the port coast that was made for the 2004 Athens Olympics by destroying an industrial area and the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center by architect Renzo Piano which was a fantastic example of an urban park on a slope. Unforutnately the library was closed but the upper lighthouse lookout was open and was an interesting moment to see the port as well as the park.
Athens is a wonderful city. I’ve been continuously impressed by the kindness, generosity, and politeness of the people. Twice we went to restaurants where we unknowingly ordered the wrong thing and twice we were offered food on the house to compensate. The people have been patient and kind- an unexpected delight. As well, the platting has been fantastic and the food delicious. Many of our meals came with a shot or dessert to finish off. We’ve also eatten a lot of soulvaki and gelato. It feel like we didn’t go a day without a stop for gelato.
Two other very enjoyable moments were the climbing of Lycabettus hill and Lofos Strefi. The first is one of the most prestigeous hills that make up ancient Athens and is a fantastic lookout. We had some trouble as a group collecting at the bottom because we all came from different places and some were late so it was a scramble up the hill in time for sunset. The rush was worthwhile though because the view was beautiful. The path zigzags up to a restaurant and crowded lookout. Right below on the path though was a pleasant spot to take photos and watch the night creep over the city. I struggled to capture photos with the wide angle camera lens but enjoyed catching up with a friend as the sun set and the cityscape illuminated. Unfortunately we were not able to stay as long as we would have liked because the rest of our party was waiting for us for dinner.
Some days later I was on my own and went up Lofos Strefi which I suspect is an old marble quarry. This is another nearby hill that’s not as high. The view was interesting because I could see the acropolis and to my left was Lycabettus. On an overcast evening where the rain sprinkled, I enjoyed a moment of solitude to listen to music emanating from the trees below. For the time, I enjoyed being alone on the hill above a city of millions. I would later discover it to be a musician in a restaurant hidden behind a rock cropping and under a large tree.
I’ve struggled on this trip to frame my pictures. Part of the reason is that I’m not enjoying the super wide aspect of the 10–18mm lens I have. It is so wide that it visibly distorts the images requiring a lot of post cropping and because of that it looks artificial. It is also the conditions cities are not panoramic landscapes and a tighter crop is more desirable. On the other hand, it could be that these struggles are a reflection of the internal turmoil to perceive the world differently and to be different. Photography in some ways is confirming some of my personal turmoil.
While the cameras has been troublesome, the iPhone remains a dependable with a regular field of view and suitable perspective. It’s easy to use, light, quick to access and always with me. It doesn’t come as a surprise that most people are phone wielding tourists and dslrs are fewer and fewer. Some days I wonder if I should just leave my camera at home. For the blog and Instagram the iPhone is sufficient but I’m always hoping for a special moment that would be worthy of a large print.
Thank you for liking and subscribing, I’m trying to reach 100 followers.

Athens is an unequivocal dump.
I had illusions of Athens being similar to Thessaloniki, so I booked a ticket. Flying in from Corfu on New Years eve was an admittedly strange time to arrive. The airport was clean and modern, the rail connection to the city was descent. At this point I was mildly optimistic about visiting this city. Arriving in Syntagma square and heading a little north along big boulevards and then climbing slightly into a narrow grid network of streets, I found my accommodation.
After checking in to my accommodation. I watched the fireworks from the top of a nearby hill. Something that struck me from the ground level but was far more visible from above was the layer of smog enveloping the city. Pollution levels were on a par with other dirty cities like Sofia, Hanoi and Bangkok. However this is supposed to be a first world European country. I was expecting something more like Rome or Madrid, instead it reminded me more of the grimmy streets of Sofia and I felt I could even of been back in the chaotic streets of Hanoi or Bangkok again.
Immediately after setting out to explore the center on new year’s day, I encountered a large group of drug addicts who had gathered in the morning sun next to a classical building. I saw arms peppered with scars from injecting, others had needle in hand ready to use. As I walked on I quickly forgot the scene i’d just witnessed as I made it to towards Syntagma square in square. Admittedly I had an od impression of the city on Jan 1st as everything was closed and Greek people were at home. But I noticed another homeless drug addict sleeping on a bench in a narrow alley in the center. I was shocked to see his forearm covered in open wounds, it honestly looked like his arm was rotten. I was in such disbelief as to what I had just walked past that I went back to make sure that was indeed what I witnessed. What struck me about this scene was the respectable well dressed people walking past this man or standing just twenty meters away, but being totally oblivious to his plight.
In the subsequent days I walked around more and discovered Athens has a bustling bar and restaurant scene in the center. However outside the center the streets are a mess. Pavements barely exist so people walk in the street. All the streets seem to be coated in a layer of dirt, whether from pollution or something else I don’t know. I stayed in an airbnb where you have to raise and lower a metal security gate, like they have on shops when closed. “It’s to stop the anarchists damaging the building” the host said. In a society where anarchists are so mainstream, it suggests to me a lack of direction.
All in all I had a very bad impression of Athens. How can I enjoy the chaos of the city and the food when you have drug addicts and homeless people suffering horrifically in the center. And the Greek people acting with total indifference. Add on to that the cities dirty disorganised streets and thick atmosphere of pollution, I felt an overall seedy atmosphere. This overrided any quaintness from the neverending ramshackle nature of the shops.
One positive note I will end
on is the Greek peoples hospitality was very impressive as always, it’s just a shame Athens can’t be as impressive.

[Socrates] was so well-disciplined in his way of life that on several occasions when plague broke out in Athens he was the only man who escaped infection. — Diogenes Laertius
In 430 BC, Athens was devastated by plague. We don’t know exactly what caused it but it’s been speculated that it was a form of typhus, typhoid, or possibly smallpox. What happened during the Athenian Plague seems to foreshadow aspects of the current COVID-19 pandemic. Our own experiences probably also help us to better understand what the ancient Athenians must have been going through. I won’t labour the obvious parallels but rather I’ll just tell the story and mention some comparisons briefly along the way…
The epidemic spread throughout the Mediterranean but Athens, the largest and most cosmopolitan city in the region, was hit hardest of all. Attica, the area encompassing Athens, had a total population of roughly a quarter of a million, including thousands of foreign residents and maybe a hundred thousand slaves. The disease was apparently brought into the Greek port of Piraeus by travellers and merchants, from whence it quickly escalated into an epidemic, tearing through the population of neighbouring Athens.
After the first outbreak began to relent, the Athenians must have breathed a collective sigh of relief. Unfortunately, though, there were two further major outbreaks of the plague in Athens, occurring in 429 and 427…
