Title: The Acropolis: Athens’ Sacred Hill and Democracy’s Birthplace
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

From cheeky tales in history to travel sagas and cultural deep-dives, we’re here to spill the tea on society’s fabulous and chaotic evolution.

--
Listen
Share
If real estate developers from 2500 years ago could time travel to present-day Athens, they’d likely nod knowingly at the Acropolis and say, “Location, location, location,” before immediately filing permits to build luxury condos with “authentic Parthenon views.” Perched 150 meters above sea level, the Acropolis stands as humanity’s most enduring architectural humblebrag — the ancient equivalent of posting a vacation selfie with the caption “just a casual Tuesday #blessed.”
This wasn’t just any construction project — it was ancient Athens announcing to the Mediterranean world: We’ve got surplus wealth, artistic genius, and we’re not afraid to use it. Also, Sparta, are you taking notes?
What began as a practical hilltop fortress evolved into Western civilization’s most iconic symbol of democracy and architectural achievement. The limestone outcropping that once protected Athenians from invaders now protects something else entirely: our collective cultural memory of a time when a small city-state pioneered ideas that would fundamentally alter human history — all while setting the record for world’s longest-running construction project.
The Rocky Rise to Fame: A Brief History
The Acropolis’s story begins long before Pericles decided to give it a fancy makeover. Archaeological evidence shows human occupation dating back to the Neolithic era (around 4000–3000 BCE), when our ancestors apparently shared the same appreciation for defensible real estate with good views as modern luxury condo developers.
The Persian invasion of 480 BCE brought a dramatic plot twist. When King Xerxes and his forces captured Athens, they razed the buildings on the Acropolis, providing Athens with what modern architects might call “an unfortunate but clean slate for urban renewal.” The Athenians, after defeating the Persians at Salamis, left the ruins as a memorial to Persian aggression, perhaps history’s first example of politically motivated construction delays.
The Acropolis as we know it emerged during Athens’ Golden Age under Pericles (495–429 BCE), the influential statesman who spearheaded an ambitious building program funded by the treasury of the Delian League — essentially repurposing defense funds for infrastructure projects. When allied city-states complained about their defense contributions being used to beautify Athens, Pericles essentially responded with the ancient Greek equivalent of “What are you going to do about it?” This massive urban renewal project employed thousands of artisans and laborers — basically the New Deal with more nude statues.
The Acropolis: A Not-So-Brief Timeline
Architectural Marvels: The Buildings That Changed History
The crown jewel of the Acropolis is undoubtedly the Parthenon, a temple dedicated to Athena Parthenos (“Athena the Virgin”). Completed around 438 BCE, the Parthenon embodies perfection through imperfection. Its architects built subtle curves into seemingly straight lines and tilted supposedly vertical columns inward — optical illusions designed to make the structure appear perfectly straight. Think of it as ancient Photoshop: reality enhancement before filters existed.
The Parthenon’s dimensions follow a precise mathematical ratio, with its 46 outer columns assembled with such precision that many joints remain water-tight after 2,500 years — which makes you wonder what these builders would think about your contractor’s excuses.
Next door stands the Erechtheion with its famous Porch of the Caryatids: six sculpted maiden columns who’ve been holding up that roof for twenty-five centuries without a coffee break or basic labor protections. These ladies represent history’s longest-standing case of unpaid female labor, though today five are replicas, with the originals safely housed in the Acropolis Museum (except for one “recruited” by Lord Elgin who now resides in the British Museum — an international custody battle that continues to this day).
The Propylaea, the monumental gateway designed by architect Mnesicles, remains one of history’s most impressive entrance halls — though modern visitors experience it more like an ancient Greek subway station during rush hour. Its innovative design included Doric columns (the simpler style) on the outside and Ionic columns (the fancier ones with scroll-like details) on the inside, a mixed architectural order that was revolutionary for its time.
Gods, Myths, and Drama: The Cultural Significance
The Acropolis wasn’t just a collection of pretty buildings, it was ancient Athens’ spiritual and cultural heart. According to myth, the site was where Athena and Poseidon competed to become the city’s patron deity in what was essentially the ancient world’s most high-stakes talent show. Poseidon struck the rock with his trident, producing a salt spring (essentially the divine equivalent of giving someone bottled water when they already live next to a freshwater lake). Athena countered by gifting an olive tree, offering food, oil, and wood. The Athenians chose Athena’s offering, demonstrating that even in mythology, economic benefits trump special effects.
The olive tree remained central to Athenian economy and religion, with the sacred olive oil from trees descended from Athena’s gift used as prizes in the Panathenaic Games — ancient Greece’s version of the Olympics, but with more olive oil and fewer corporate sponsors.
The Acropolis witnessed Athens’ greatest triumphs and darkest moments. When Christianity replaced ancient Greek religion, the Parthenon became a church. Under Ottoman rule, it became a mosque — making it perhaps history’s most overqualified religious building. In 1687, the Venetians bombarded the Acropolis, igniting ammunition stored inside the Parthenon and causing catastrophic damage — proving that using world heritage sites as military installations is never a good idea.
The most controversial chapter began in 1801 when Lord Elgin removed sculptures from the Parthenon — proving that with the right paperwork, even institutionalized looting can be made perfectly legal. These “Elgin Marbles” now reside in the British Museum, with Greek requests for their return continuing and Britain’s finder’s keepers position becoming increasingly awkward in an era of cultural repatriation.
Visiting Today: Tips and Reflections
If you visit the Acropolis today, you’ll join approximately 3 million annual visitors in a pilgrimage that’s equal parts awe-inspiring and sweat-inducing. Here’s what to expect:
Despite the crowds and occasional scaffolding of ongoing restoration work (which has been ongoing since approximately forever), standing on the Acropolis remains a profound experience. You’re treading the same marble as Socrates, Pericles, and countless anonymous Athenians who shaped Western thought, though they probably weren’t wearing Crocs or complaining about Wi-Fi connectivity.
The Acropolis’s greatest lesson might be how it connects us across time. The ancient Athenians grappled with questions of governance, justice, and truth that we still haven’t fully resolved. As you descend from Athens’ sacred hill, you carry with you a tangible connection to the birthplace of concepts that shape our world today.
Plus, you’ve earned the right to say “when I was at the Acropolis…” at dinner parties for at least the next decade — which might be the most enduring legacy of all.

Title: Ancient Agora of Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication is about taking off on foot, in a car, by plane or in the mind. It’s about taking off of work, school or life in general. Old stories, new stories and imagined stories that feature these various forms of taking off, including masks and hats, are all welcome.

--
1
Listen
Share
Athen’s Agora was the center of public life in ancient Athens, surrounded by impressive temples and government buildings. It served as a gathering place for citizens to discuss politics and trade goods. Notable structures included the Stoa of Attalos, a covered walkway lined with shops, and the Temple of Hephaestus, which has come down to us as one of the best-preserved temples from ancient Greece.
“Wow, this place is a lot,” I remarked to my husband an hour into our explorations. “Everything we have ever learned about ancient Greece originates from here. This is the epicenter of the Western world.”
The archaeological site was remarkably green, clean, and well-maintained, unlike almost everywhere else in Athens.
“Dude, could you imagine if all these buildings were tagged?” I mused.
Ryan took a good look around and replied, “I almost can’t believe they’re not.”
“In all honesty, they almost should be, as a symbol of how far democracy has fallen,” I said, unaware of how much farther it still had to plummet.
When we were there in 2018, I still believed in democracy. However, as I write this, I’m not so sure I do anymore. The thought of America turning into an oligarchy wasn’t even on my radar back then. What was Elon Musk even doing in 2018? Sure, he was the CEO of SpaceX and Tesla, and he was making headlines for selling flamethrowers and trying to rescue some trapped Thai kids in a cave. But the idea of him overthrowing the U.S. government and acting as its president seemed highly unlikely. Why would a billionaire even do that? And if one did, it certainly wouldn’t happen in America, the home of the so-called leader of the free world. Fast forward seven years, and now I believe democracy is a dying institution.
Although we do not practice democracy in its purest form today, even ancient Greece encountered similar challenges and sometimes fell into oligarchy. The term “democracy” literally means “people power,” and one of the most notable features of their system was the absence of political parties. I salivate just imagining a system where voting was based solely on majority rule, without an electoral college to alter the final results.
I used to believe in voting, as well, but that, too, is something I now question. However, it’s more accurate to say that I don’t trust any politicians — not a single one of them. No one I voted for is standing up against the looming oligarchy because they are part of it. They realized there was no point in pretending anymore.
Where there’s power, there’s corruption. I’ve come to realize that democracy is no different from communism — it looks good on paper. The realities of political maneuvering, social inequality, and the influence of money often contrast sharply with democratic ideals. Therefore, while democracy is often celebrated as a preferable system of governance, it still has the potential to fail. And when democracy falters, it can bring an entire country down with it.
The Temple of Hephaestus loomed over Athens’ Agora on a hill not far in the distance. The temple was originally dedicated to the Greek god of artisans, blacksmiths, carpenters, metallurgy, fire, and volcanoes — more commonly known as Vulcan in Roman mythology. Visitors are not allowed inside; even in ancient times, ordinary people could not enter the inner sanctum — only priests had that privilege. The interior featured a large statue of the deity, which could be seen from outside when the temple doors were open, allowing the gods to “see” the rituals performed in front of the building.
It’s my theory that democracy has shut itself away inside this temple. Whenever the temple doors are opened, democracy remains a deity that citizens can only gaze upon and worship from a distance.
My books Memory Road Trip (e-book or paperback) and Time Traveled (e-book or paperback) are both available! You can also find them at most major international book sites.

Title: Athens: Where Myth and Modernity Collide
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Athens — a city where time stands still, yet everything pulses with life. It’s here that my journey as a techno nomad begins, a place where ancient history intertwines with modern chaos, and where every corner seems to whisper stories of the past. I spent a week in this vibrant city, absorbing its energy and allowing it to shape the beats of my first track Upon arriving, I was immediately drawn to the Acropolis, the iconic heart of Athens. Standing beneath the towering Parthenon, I could feel the weight of history, the echoes of ancient civilizations in the air. The Acropolis, perched high above the city, offered a panoramic view of Athens, a sprawling metropolis that felt eternal. Each stone seemed to hum with energy, and I could already sense the beginnings of a deep, resonant bassline forming in my mind. The contrast between the sacred ruins and the bustling city below gave me the idea for the track’s foundation — slow, powerful beats that rise and fall like the ancient columns around me.
But my exploration didn’t end there. I ventured to Pnyx Hill, a site where the seeds of democracy were sown. Standing where Athenian citizens once gathered to debate and decide the future of their city, I felt the collective power of history. The energy here was quieter, but no less potent — like a steady, rhythmic pulse beneath the surface. This inspired the more subtle, driving melodies in the track, layers that build tension and momentum as they progress.
Athens, however, isn’t just a city of the past. Its modern side is equally captivating, and nowhere was that more apparent than in the anarchic neighborhood of Exarchia. This part of the city is raw, rebellious, and alive with creative energy. Graffiti-covered walls, political posters, and street art filled the streets, while the hum of life and resistance was palpable. The urban chaos here felt like an assault on the senses — in the best way possible. It was this part of Athens that brought a gritty, industrial edge to the track, a distorted synth that mirrors the frenetic energy of the city’s underground.
As I continued to explore, I sought balance in quieter, more spiritual places. The Temple of Hephaistos, nestled in the ancient Agora, offered a peaceful respite. Here, among the columns of the temple, I found the space to breathe, to reflect, and to listen to the quieter tones of the city. This serenity inspired the atmospheric breaks in the track, moments of pause between the intensity, allowing the listener to absorb the depth of the soundscape.
Evenings were spent along the coast of Palaio Faliro, where the waves gently lapped against the shore. The calming rhythm of the sea gave the track its final touch — a hypnotic groove that carries the listener forward, like the endless ebb and flow of the ocean. This final element tied everything together, a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, there is peace.
After a week in Athens, I had completed my first track — an aural reflection of the city’s soul. It’s a blend of ancient and modern, of chaotic energy and quiet reflection, much like Athens itself. This journey through history, rebellion, and tranquility has set the tone for what’s to come. Athens, with all its layers and contrasts, gave me the foundation for a sound that’s deeply rooted in place, yet entirely my own.
As I prepare for my next stop — Berlin — I carry with me the lessons and sounds of Athens. This city has shown me how to balance history and modernity, chaos and calm, and weave them into a track that captures the spirit of a place. Stay tuned for the next chapter in this sonic journey as I dive into the heart of techno in Berlin.

Title: Greece, Checked! Exploring Athens, Santorini, and Crete
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
“It takes a lifetime to discover Greece, but it only takes an instant to fall in love with her.” — Henry Miller
Starting my unforgettable journey through Greece, I’m excited to finally check it off my bucket list while diving into its stunning beauty and fascinating history.
Thanks to my travel agent’s help, who carefully put together a package including visits to Athens, Santorini, and Crete, along with accommodations and airport transfers, all I needed to do was book a flight.
I started my journey in Athens, a city that effortlessly blends ancient history with modern culture. As I walked through the streets of Plaka, I was captivated by the combination of ancient ruins and bustling cafes, which revealed the city’s rich history and culture at every corner.
During my stay in Athens, I visited the Parthenon atop the Acropolis, one of the most iconic landmarks in the world. Standing beneath the ancient temple, I was awestruck by the sheer scale of its history and significance. The Parthenon’s towering columns and intricate carvings are a true testament to the brilliance and craftsmanship of the ancient Greeks.
To fully immerse myself in Athenian life, I chose to stay in the heart of downtown Athens. This allowed me to walk everywhere, making it easy to explore landmarks such as Syntagma Square, Monastiraki Flea Market, and the vibrant neighborhoods of Psiri and Exarchia. Being centrally located made me feel part of the city’s pulse, and I enjoyed soaking up the vibrant atmosphere that surrounded me.
“I want to have an ‘Eat, Pray, Love’ experience where I drop off the face of the planet and move to Greece.” — Jennifer Hyman
My journey then led me to Santorini, a destination that had long captured my imagination. As the ferry approached the island, I was greeted by a breathtaking panorama of white-washed buildings clinging to cliffs, adorned with blue-domed churches. The striking contrast between the pristine whitewashed architecture and the deep azure of the Aegean Sea was truly mesmerizing, creating a scene straight out of a postcard.
Exploring Enchanting Villages:
Stepping onto Santorini’s shores felt like entering a dream. I embarked on a journey to explore its enchanting villages, starting with the iconic Oia. Its narrow cobblestone streets led me on a whimsical journey, lined with charming cafes, boutique shops, and art galleries tucked away in every nook and cranny. The village’s crowning glory, however, was its unparalleled sunset views. Joining fellow travelers atop the cliffs of Oia, I witnessed nature’s masterpiece unfold as the sun dipped below the horizon, painting the sky in hues of gold and crimson.
Continuing my exploration, I ventured to Fira, Santorini’s bustling capital perched atop the caldera cliffs. Here, I found a vibrant atmosphere pulsating through its labyrinthine streets. From chic boutiques to traditional tavernas, Fira offered a delightful blend of modernity and tradition. And no visit to Fira would be complete without a stroll along the cliffside promenade, where panoramic views of the caldera stretched out before me, offering a glimpse into the island’s volcanic past.
Embracing the Island’s Natural Beauty:
Santorini’s allure extends beyond its picturesque villages, beckoning travelers to immerse themselves in its natural wonders. I embarked on a trek along the caldera rim, traversing rugged terrain and ancient pathways carved into the cliffs. With each step, I was rewarded with sweeping vistas of the Aegean Sea and the neighboring islands, a reminder of the island’s volcanic origins.
Moreover, Santorini’s beaches are not to be missed. From the black sands of Perissa and Kamari to the red sands of Red Beach, each shoreline offered its own unique charm. I spent my days lounging on the sun-drenched shores, taking refreshing dips in the crystalline waters, and soaking in the Mediterranean sun.
A Word of Advice: Bring Comfortable Walking Shoes:
As I navigated Santorini’s enchanting landscapes, one thing became abundantly clear: comfortable walking shoes are an absolute must. Whether exploring the winding streets of its villages or trekking along the rugged coastline, sturdy footwear ensured that I could fully enjoy all that Santorini had to offer without any discomfort.
Finally, I set sail for Crete, the largest of the Greek islands, and a place of myth and legend. Exploring the Palace of Knossos, I felt like I was walking in the footsteps of ancient kings and heroes, with the echoes of the past reverberating through the labyrinthine ruins. I also took the time to unwind on Crete’s beautiful beaches with their crystal-clear waters and golden sands, which offered the perfect respite after days filled with exploration and discovery.
In conclusion, my Greek odyssey exceeded my wildest expectations, offering a tapestry of experiences that will remain in my memory for years to come. I am grateful for the opportunity to have experienced Greece’s natural beauty, rich history, and vibrant culture. I know that Greece will always hold a special place in my heart, beckoning me back to its shores time and time again.
“There are two kinds of people. Greeks, and everyone else who wish they were Greek.” — My big fat Greek wedding
--
--
Alka Mehta is a published writer for The Motley Fool and NerdWallet, with degrees in finance and computer science.

Title: Athens Land Ownership Mapping: Privatised Gains, Socialised Losses — State Led Privatisation of Public Land Assets
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This blog series presents the results of the common investigation of Dark Matter Labs and the Institute of Human Rights and Business which seeks to explore the opportunities and barriers to just transition in the built environment through perspectives of urban land ownership.

--
Listen
Share
This is the 5th article in the series — a collaboration between Dark Matter Labs and the Institute of Human Rights and Business (IHRB). Previous articles mapped property ownership-related patterns in Copenhagen, Prague, and Lisbon. In this post, we turn our attention to Athens, identifying parallels with Lisbon in how the city’s land management, ownership and built environment patterns were shaped in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis.
Like Lisbon, Athens together with its greater public interest have been significantly impacted by the Troika loan conditions, weak regulatory frameworks to protect vulnerable groups, and a lack of data transparency in land and property ownership registers, although this is now being addressed through efforts to digitise the national cadaster.
This blog supports the argument that municipalities and state governments, just as the large developers and investment companies, play an active role in neoliberal city and country development logics leading to privatisation and financialization of the public real estate assets. It also argues that the European city and national governments should play a much stronger role in promoting spatial justice and societal resilience through land management rather than using it as a mere tool for profit and public debt repayment.
Athens has become the second least liveable city in Europe, according to a recent report “On the quality of life in European cities, 2023”, published by the European Commission. The reasons are similar to the issues and patterns observed in Lisbon, which largely resulted in the increasing unaffordability and ever-increasing spatial exclusion of its citizens.
Acquiring, analysing and visualising data on land ownership can be a powerful tool in comprehending the past, and current built environment justice patterns and their socio-spatial intricacies. In Athens, due to a lack of data access and transparency, despite numerous efforts, it has been challenging to precisely assess and depict who owns land and property in the city, as well as what are the historical transactions that could bring actors in power into the public eye.
We have therefore taken a desk research approach to finding data on major landowners and significant land sales conducted in the past decade, contextualising them within Athens’ housing landscape and reflecting on their relationship with the city’s future transition strategies.
The blog is therefore structured as follows:
A) Largest landowners
B) Major Land Sales
C) Forces at Play
B) Athens’ housing issues
D) Data transparency review — National Property Registry
E) Concluding reflections — Future city transition
Link to Map
2. Athens Municipality: The city of Athens itself owns a large portion of public spaces, including parks, squares, infrastructural land and municipal buildings (Athens Social Atlas)
3. Greek Orthodox Church: Holds substantial real estate, including historic churches, monasteries, and other religious properties, as well as land that has been bequeathed to the Church over centuries. (See: Reuters, Athens Social Atlas)
2. Foreign Investment Funds: Over the past two decades, several international investment funds have purchased property in Athens, to capitalise on the low real estate prices that followed the financial crisis. This includes hedge funds and real estate investment trusts (REITs) that have acquired properties, especially in tourist-heavy areas or neighbourhoods undergoing redevelopment.
In the past decade, Athens has seen several major land sales as part of a broader wave of real estate activity, subsequent privatisation efforts, and international interest in Greece. Below are some of the most significant land sales based on land size and estimated market value, taking into account location (prime or less-developed areas), demand (tourism, logistics, residential), and strategic importance (e.g., port facilities, large urban developments).
Hellinikon Project (former Athens Airport)
Astir Palace Resort (Vouliagmeni Peninsula)
Piraeus Port Authority (PPA)
Marina Zea (Piraeus)
The sale of public land in Greece, facilitated by the Hellenic Republic Asset Development Fund (HRADF), has been a major source of societal outcry, particularly in the wake of the country’s sovereign debt crisis (2009–2010).
As part of the bailout agreements imposed by the Troika (European Commission, European Central Bank, and the International Monetary Fund), Greece was pressured to privatise public land and assets, a move critics argue significantly weakened the state both politically and economically. This privatisation agenda, which often disregarded national social needs, was aimed at settling debt by selling off strategic assets such as airports, ports, and vast tracts of land. Projects like the Hellinikon redevelopment, where public land is being transformed into private luxury developments, have marginalised lower-income residents and reduced public access to urban and coastal areas. Local communities, environmental organisations, and political opposition have strongly resisted these sales, especially of large coastal sites like Ellinikon, which includes the former Athens airport and Agios Kosmas beach, arguing that the privatisations prioritise elite interests over broader public needs.
Politically, the HRADF’s operations have been highly controversial, with opponents dubbing it the “Sell-out Fund of Greece” and questioning the constitutionality of its mandate. Additionally, the low sale prices of assets, such as Lamda Development’s acquisition of Hellinikon for a fraction of its real value, have intensified public resentment, with many viewing these transactions as a fire sale of national treasures.
As noted in the Athens Social Atlas article, the privatisation programme fits into a long history of public land abuse and illegal seizures. This includes everything from individuals and companies encroaching on public land for private purposes to large-scale speculative developments by private enterprises. What is more, in some cases, this also relates to the opposite scenarios when privately owned land has been taken over by the state. The absence of a transparent National Land Registry, coupled with a fragmented bureaucracy, has facilitated large-scale exploitation and commodification of public assets.
The great article from Athens Social Atlas (2015), by renowned scholar and economic geographer Costis Hadjimichalis summarises some of the dynamics that shape the land seizures in Attica. He also writes that:
“The main reason for land-related abuses and illegal activities, but also for the delays in privatisation and sell-off by the HRADF, is the lack of a National Land Register. Essentially, due to a variety of factors, the state is not fully aware of the actual size and location of its real estate assets. Other than the lack of a land register, other important factors are the fragmentation of public services dealing with public land, the weakness or indifference of civil servants and the combination of political expedience and corruption.”
The recent development of a national land register provides some hope for a more informed and democratic decision process in terms of land management. However, while HRADF records its most profitable year, the rhetoric remains the same: “With a record contribution to the public funds as well as to the development course of the country, it seems that the operation of the TAIPED will be completed, and by the end of the year it will be absorbed by the Superfund” and “In total, the revenue from concessions — privatisations this year — will, for the first time in the history of the Fund — exceed 4 billion euros , an amount that will be automatically directed to the repayment of a not inconsiderable part of the public debt, contributing to its reduction by almost two percentage points of GDP“. This year alone, Greece hopes to raise more than 5 billion euros in 2024 from the sale of state assets, including a stake in Athens International Airport and concession deals for two toll roads, a senior privatisation official said on Wednesday — the privatisation logic continues. What has changed are add-ons such as “Decarbonisation Fund” and ESG compliance, with the support of the largest consulting firms.
To understand some of the further reasons behind the present spatial injustice issues in the Athens Metropolitan Area, one has to further examine the forces that came into play, prior to and following the financial crisis, as well as the enabling policies and regulatory mechanisms that facilitated their enforcement. These include:
Sources: (Law 2778/1999), (Law 4646/2019), (Law 4714/2020 — Article 5B), Law 4242/2014, Laws 4242/2014 and 4373/2016), (Law 5006/2022),
1. Housing financialisation a la Griega” — Alexandri, 2022
2. Social justice and a city: surplus capital and the remaking of Athens
3. Housing Crisis and Neoliberal Social policy in Greece
4. “​Platform — driven housing commodification, financialisation and gentrification in Athens
The dynamics described above led to multiple urban socio-spatial problems. Eteron — the Institute for Research and Social Change — a non-profit organisation working towards the production of knowledge and citizen empowerment through its
Project Housing360
provides an impactful overview of the present housing problems in Greece.
Property ownership in Greece is fragmented and often difficult to track accurately. This is partly due to incomplete land records and inheritance processes, outdated property registries, and legal complexity. The creation of a comprehensive, unified land registry system, the National Property Registry, also known as ‘Ktimatologio’, has been a laborious process spanning over three decades.
Before the establishment of the Ktimatologio, property records were managed by ‘Ypothikofylakeia’ (Mortgage Registries), which were responsible for recording legal documents related to property transactions, such as mortgages, deeds, and other encumbrances. As the Ktimatologio gradually expands, it is replacing the Ypothikofylakeia. In areas where the Ktimatologio is fully operational, the Ypothikofylakeio is either phased out or its role is significantly reduced. However, in areas where the Ktimatologio is not yet implemented, the Ypothikofylakeio continues to function as the primary land registry. Presently, the Greek government expresses optimism regarding the Ktimatologio project’s culmination by the year 2026.
An interactive digital map, with all properties currently incorporated into the registry, has been recently released, accompanied by the number for each plot. In adherence to data protection protocols, under both national law and the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), ownership details will remain undisclosed within the map.
To uncover ownership information, Greek Law permits anyone invoking “legitimate interest” to apply for information held in the land registry, which is provided by the Land Registrar in the form of a certificate or excerpt of the Land Book” (ELRA) — therefore the information can be considered public in the sense that anyone can have access to it. Each property is marked with a unique number, the so-called Code Number E of the national K thematic catalogue (KAEK), which is the exclusive code number for each parcel of land, the identity of the property. The interactive digital map represents the first time that each plot’s code is publicly available. One can purchase different types of information upon registration through a Greek digital system Taxisnet for residents with Tax registration number.
As this is a work in progress, property holders are still having the liberty to register their properties and update information conveniently, eliminating the need for physical visits to government agencies with supporting documentation. Though the deadline for property registration has lapsed, the online map aims to serve as an incentive for registration, ideally before November 30th, 2024.
After analysing Copenhagen, Prague, Lisbon, and Athens, it is clear that European States have followed certain common patterns in land management and real estate development. The role of the state and municipalities, often perceived as passive guardians of public interests against large private investors, has shifted towards active promoters of privatisation. Publicly owned development companies, such as Copenhagen’s City and Port Corporation or Greece’s TAIPED (Hellenic Republic Asset Development Fund), are increasingly used to stimulate economic growth and repay debt — whether infrastructure-related as in Copenhagen or tied to Greece’s financial crisis.
This system inherently incentivises the maximisation of returns on investments, often through the sale and development of public land into high-value, luxury projects. This approach prioritises short-term financial gains and large-scale developments, with little room for smaller, complex, or low-return projects, such as providing or retrofitting affordable housing.
While balance sheets may look strong, with institutions like HRADF showing greater financial returns, the reality is that profits are privatised, while the risks and losses are borne by society at large.
This raises the questions:

Title: Contrasts in Athens: Ruins, Reality, and Resilience
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The Journal of an Explorer

--
Listen
Share
Athens, Greece, January, 3rd 2023.
Yesterday, as a deceptively serene January sun shone on one of those poorly built streets of Athens, most likely hastily rebuilt after an earthquake, I found myself walking from the Acropolis to my hotel to interview Marlena for my podcast Stories of Healing.
On a side street of the bustling city, a man was standing on the sidewalk while another attempted to inject drugs directly into one of his neck’s arteries with a syringe. This unexpected encounter hit me hard. The compassionate teachings from the documentary The Wisdom of Trauma flooded my mind. I couldn’t help but wonder about the lives of these two men: Do they have families? Homes? How do they survive amidst such despair? The contrast between the seemingly timeless ruins and the rawness of the present was stark. The Greek government’s efforts to preserve its ancient heritage seemed unbefitting. Those marble stones will eventually come to dust without suffering, while this man was escaping his immediate pain the best way he knew how.
As I continued my walk back to this tiny hotel room, I struggled to find my inner peace, still bewildered. I focused on my body, straightening my shoulders and grounding myself. The city’s sounds faded into the background. Gradually, a sense of belonging washed over me, reminding me of the gratitude I have been feeling since I started nomading and that home is within me.
The interview with Marlena went well despite a few technical and practical hiccups. I pondered whether in-person interviews would be much better, with the added presence and access to more of someone’s body language and emotions. It was my first remote interview, my second interview ever, and I felt no stage fear; it was so natural. Marlena, being the sharp, vulnerable, and endearing woman she is, surely helped. She notably talks about drinking starting at four and those seven seconds of bliss.
I received an encouraging response about a housesitting opportunity in the South of Cyprus from January 18 to 28. The island has been divided since the Turkish invasion in the 1970s. Google Maps indicates a strange zone, a buffer of some sort, between the North and South sides. The red lines for borders I am used to seeing around countries are not there. And I wonder how someone at Google decides to delineate territories of contested land; it must become a geopolitical statement and one with practical consequences for a traveler like me: I am not sure I can cross from the North to the South; I may have to fly or take a boat directly to the South.
In recent months, I’ve struggled with short-term memory issues, but they seem to be fading. My friend Matei, whom I have known since high school and who has been traveling with me for the last few days, hasn’t noticed any lapses. We will go to Mount Athos together, that strange land where women can’t enter-the last one on earth.
If you like my writing, please press the heart button and drop a comment. Share your thoughts and feelings-I’d love to hear them.
Originally published at https://beautyandpain.substack.com.

Title: Here is why I love Athens and you should consider travelling there in Summer 2020
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Athens is the birthplace of our civilisation. The origin of our democracy and cultural hotspot for philosophers and artists. Athens. A place where creativity stands above money. A vibrant hub between the middle east and Europe. A place where people enjoy living.
No matter if you visit for a day, over the weekend or you take your time to explore the city, make sure you see one of its hidden gems and exceptional cultural sights.
But first things, first. Due to Covid-19 a stay at a designated hotel and a negative test followed by a 7 days quarantine was required to enter Greece. In case of a positive test a supervised 14 days stay has been necessary. Since June 15th Greece restrictions have been eased and Greece has reopened its doors for international travel. In the bridge phase till 30th of June guests from risk areas are tested at a designated hotel — again followed by either 7 or 14 days of quarantine. All other tourists undertake random tests upon arrival. From July 1st onwards the rules will be somewhat relaxed. Find more information here. With 190 recorded deaths, Greece has a comparatively low Covid-19 rate — one of the best in Europe.
Ok, now that you know about the common rules, let me tell you why my heart fully opens up when in Athens.
Come with me and I´ll show you my way of exploring Athens — where south african parrots guide you through the National Garden to the small streets of Anafiotika — sit down, relax, have a greek coffee and enjoy the sun. Discover incredibly creative Graffiti’s on your way to Acropolis. The view is breathtaking. Feel the oriental influence at the bazaars around Thissio and check out the Varvakios food market. Taste the rich flavours of greek vegetables and fruits and try a huge variety of olives. Grab a taxi to Piraeus and be part of the chaotic streets of Athens, take the next ferry to a pine covered sunny island and breathe.
This little walk through Athens should get you inspired. Wanna explore more ? In the following lines I will reveal my little secrets and talk about the must sees. Let’s start with my favourite cultural sights.
Besides the typical let´s say more touristy things, let me tell you about a few other spots that I love to visit in Athens, like the Varvakios market, the Stavros Niarchos foundation or the Filopappou hill.
Since 1884 the so-called Dimotikí Agorá Athinón or as the locals call it Varvákios market has opened its doors from Monday to Saturday for everyone who loves fresh local food. Immerse into a world of smells and tastes between Europe and the Orient. Let me guide you through the market hall and follow me on a short walk between fruit & vegetable stands to have lunch in a simple greek taverna.
Skinned goats hanging upside down, a cowhead staring at you, fishrow on ice, a smell of slightly old blood and a marketer screaming at you in a hall filled with active hustle. Doesn’t sound too inviting ? Well, that’s reality here. The market hall shows authenticity to its fullest and gives you a throwback to how it must have been 100 years ago. You won’t find neatly packed beef filets here, prepared fish carpaccio or beautified little packages of ham. It’s raw, it’s rough and it’s real.
What an experience ! Let’s continue our walk to the vegetarian area of the market that extends alongside the square. You´ll find a variety of local and seasonal fruits in the brightest colours and best qualities — varying according to the season. In between you´ll find stands that offer oriental spices and all kinds of nuts, dry fruits and herbs in bulk. So make sure you have some bags with you and fill them with whatever attracts you most.
After seeing all this delicious food, you´ll be hungry for sure. Enjoy a variety of greek specialities on small plates and share with your friends or family in one of my favourite restaurants — it’s so local that not even google finds it — sorry ;).
From raw, rough and real to amazing architecture & art. The Stavros Niarchos foundation is an organisation that makes grants in the areas of arts and culture, education, health and medicine, and social welfare that solely derived from sales of fossil fuels, as Niarchos was one of world’s largest transporters of oil. Granting $860 million in 2017 the Stavros Niarchos cultural center designed by the renowned architect Renzo Piano opened its doors to the public.
This modern monument includes the national library of Greece and the Greek national opera. A meeting point for everyone who wants to experience breathtaking views, state of the art architecture and enjoy the new greek culture. Inspired by the natural greek flora and fauna the surrounding parks are full of lavender, rosemary and olive trees. A fountain accompanied by classical musical played every hour leads to a path towards the sea.
From classical music to the highest of all goods: nature. From the lively streets of Athens to a tranquille refuge. From marble ground to solid earth. The Filopappou hill is one of my favourite places and for sure one of the most beautiful spots of Athens.
Breathtaking views to the Acropolis, Athens mountains and the sea. Sit on an olive tree and enjoy this unique experience with a bottle of greek red wine.
From one of my favourite places to the unconventional areas I love the most in Athens — from Anafiotika, a village-like neighbourhood next to Acropolis, to Exarchia, the center of anarchism to Omonia, an area to be developed. Let yourself be surprised by the variety and distinctiveness of Athens.
Anafiotika is a scenic tiny neighborhood, a tranquil oasis in the bustling heart of downtown Athens. Narrow passageways filled with small houses, bright colors & plants immediately bring you into a relaxed island mood. The village’s name “Anafiotika” means “little Anafi” and is dedicated to its first inhabitants’ home island. They came to Athens in order to work as construction workers in the refurbishment of King Othon’s Palace.
Meet Exarchia ! The most controversial, the most colorful, the most alternative neighborhood in Athens. This area is a creative and lively art hub renowned for being the historical core of intellectual activism. You can find a lot of restaurants & bars mainly located on Stournari street, also called the Greek Silicon Valley. The National Technical University is as well located in Stournari street and among the oldest higher education institutions of Greece — the most prestigious among engineering schools.
Exarcheia has always attracted exceptional Greek and foreign intellectuals, who lived and worked in the area. The alternative and artistic atmosphere is encapsulated in every corner, every wall, and every individual of this unique neighborhood. Famous (and not only) graffiti artists have left their mark and expressed their message for a more equal world.
Omonoia means concord. It is one of the most historical areas in the center of Athens. In recent years, it has raised a lot of interest from investors abroad, as there are hidden gems of unrenovated apartments in amazingly central locations.
The brand new fountain in times of Covid-19 lifted the spirits of the residents and upgraded the whole area. Further projects like re-think Athens show the start of a movement towards a sustainable Greece.
And after a long day in the bustling heart of Athens — it´s time for some drinks.
One thing is sure — Greeks know how to enjoy life. Their open mentality and willingness to celebrate where and whenever they feel like, is like no other. Here are a few bars that I really like and that I can recommend to anyone who wants to have a fun night out.
heteroclito is an one of a kind wine destination in the historic center of Athens. It´s a small place with a great selection of mostly local and organic wines.
Noel, a magical place. Crazily exaggerated christmas decor, vintage furniture and baroque elements inspired by Cuba, Paris and New York, all mixed up. A big melting pot, always crowded and excellent service.
TAF is an innovative cultural platform, that shows artworks ranging from contemporary, performances, film screenings, roundtable discussions and workshops to music projects, works-in-progress and pop-up projects.
Couleur Locale is a hidden gem in the narrow streets of Monastiraki. Enjoy a stunning Acropolis view and well-mixed cocktails.
The warmth of the greek people, delicious food, the sea and the sun. What more could you ask for ? No matter if on a cultural level or when it comes to taking a break — Greece offers hospitality at its highest level. After this little intro you tasted, heard, smelled, saw and felt Athens with all its beauty and authenticity. So, what holds you back ? Book your trip to Athens and enjoy Greece with all senses.
--
--
What drives me is my love for nature.

Title: Day 2: Athens — The Acropolis Museum
Content:

Listen
Share
Carolina: The aftermath of Day 1 was a 12:25hrs sleep. Yes, you read that right, over twelve hours, and guess what? Even after all that sleep, we still woke up feeling like crap. Sorry, Mom, you're not gonna like hearing this but we were both under the weather. No fever but definitely feeling very much out of it, headache, body ache, sore throat, you name it.
Because of that, and because at this point it was 2pm local time, we decided to take it slow. First, we went out to scout some freshly baked bread. We found this bakery that was just a short walk from our Airbnb. Back home, we then cooked ourselves a simple breakfast: 2 eggs and 2 slices of fresh bread toasted in a panini press.
Two DayQuils after, decided that even though we weren't feeling up for the Acropolis, we wanted to do another museum instead. So we made our way to the Acropolis Museum, stopping on the way for some coffee of course.
Will: A broken cash register and a generous Grecian coffee shop owner yielded two free croissants filled with pistachio cream (I enjoyed those for dessert later as they were very much not vegan).
With a cup of coffee in hand, we proceeded to walk up one of the main streets in our neighborhood — Veikou. I kept telling Will how much it reminded me of home. For those who have been in Rio, it looks somewhere between Copacabana and Downtown Rio. There are tons of shops of all kinds everywhere. Camera stores, pharmacies, bakeries, restaurants, cafés, retail, home goods, you name it. You can literally get everything done within a 5 min walk radius.
Another thing that's very prominent in the neighborhoods of Athens is the graffiti. Not the art kind, but the tags (pt: pichagem). It's everywhere you look. It's a bit intimidating at first but it's a very safe neighborhood, mainly elders and a few tourists here and there. Pretty calm overall.
The Acropolis Museum is a gorgeous and modern building. At first glance, it looks like it could be a modern art museum.
The museum was built on top of the ruins of the ancient city of Athens. Underneath it, you can walk around an archeological site with signs explaining what each ruin used to be — a bathhouse, a mansion, workshops... We were the most impressed with how the ancient Greek civilization had a somewhat complex plumbing system with legit pipes and all (keep in mind that this is from the 8th to 5th cent. BC).
Above, in the museum itself, is a gorgeous collection of artifacts from the Acropolis itself and its slopes. They also have a very interesting video on the Persian destruction of the Acropolis in 480 BC and an explanation of how pigments were created using local rocks/minerals (see photo below) — yes, all the ancient Greek sculptures that we know now to be on white marble used to be colored.
After the museum, we went back home, cooked some dinner, and began our work day.
--

Content:
Sign up

Sign up

Share
Before we set off to the Greek Islands for 8 days, we had 2 full days to explore Athens, the ancient capitol of Greece.
We arrived in the late afternoon on a miraculously on-time plane from London. After getting our bags we bought a ‘Tourist Ticket’ from the metro station. This ticket includes return to and from the airport and unlimited use of the Athens public transport system. It cost €22 although we didn’t end up using the metro much. Everywhere we wanted to visit was generally walkable. We used it 3 times in total. A simple return ticket for the airport will only cost €14, and if you’re only staying in the city centre for a few days you’ll probably be fine.
We stayed in an Airbnb in Plaka near the Akropoli metro station less than a 5-minute walk to the south entrance of the Acropolis itself. From here, we could get everywhere in the city centre in less than 20 minutes of walking. The centre itself is dense and full of incredible restaurants, historic sights, museums and shops.
Our host, Giannas, welcomed us to Greece with a shot of Ouzo and some recommendations on what to do in the area. We soon learned that Plaka itself is very much catered to tourists. Whilst very beautiful to explore, we couldn’t help but feel it was all just a big show for tourists. Giannas recommended the Monastiraki area for restaurants and nightlife. Our walking tour guide, Michael, echoed these same thoughts, claiming that no Greek people eat food in Plaka!
Good to know in retrospect, and painfully obvious when strolling through and all you see is touristy shops and restaurants. Although the proximity to the Acropolis was excellent and the area was quiet in the evenings. Everything being in walking distance meant it never became an issue.
We started the day bright and early with a walking tour with Athens Free Walking Tour. When travelling to a big city like Athens, a great way to get a feel for the layout, vibe and culture is to take a walking tour. Across Europe there are walking tours for all budgets. Based on experience, the free ones I have done have all been incredibly useful. Nowadays, they’re an essential part of visiting a new city for us.
Before setting on our way we grabbed a couple of macchiatos from the Coffee Island that was nearby.
We want to avoid spoiling all of the surprises of the tour and just give an idea of what you will be doing and seeing:
Our guide, Michael, was very well educated in ancient history and has a deep knowledge and understanding of Athens.
The tour lasted a little under 3 hours and finished in Monastiraki. We took one of Michael’s food recommendations and had an incredible lunch at O Thanasis. The moussaka we had there was the best we had during our time in Greece.
The Central Market is a noisy and bustling fresh produce market. The main hall sells meat and seafood whilst the surrounding area sells vegetables, herbs and spices.
We arrived in the early afternoon. There was still a lot of activity with plenty of sellers around. The seller’s area feels like a relic of the past and not the kind of thing you’ll see in a central part of a modern city. This authentic and local feel really adds to its charm.
Even if you’re not buying, wandering through the market is an experience for the eyes and nose. Although, if you’re a vegetarian or turned off by the smell of meat you may want to skip this place.
The Acropolis Museum is dedicated to the archaeological discoveries from the Acropolis. It can be a good idea to visit here first before going to the Acropolis itself. But either order works.
This sleek, modern building first opened in 2009 and was a welcome respite for us by the blaring summer heat. Close to 4,000 objects are on display here and there are great views of the city from the restaurant terrace.
Entrance only costs €5 and is a great stop for a couple of hours. If you can, hire a guide and you will get so much more out of it!
After some much needed afternoon rest from a packed day of sight-seeing we headed out to Cinque. This is a place to bring your loved one, sip on some divine wine and talk about your experiences of the day.
We sampled a bunch of different wines and shared a meat platter together. The owner explained the origins and optimal tasting experience of each wine we tried. We aren’t serious wine drinkers but I imagine a wine fanatic would get a lot out of this place!
The staff were cheery and helpful, and our names were printed out and placed in a frame for our table when we arrived. These little details are what makes a night at Cinque an unforgettable experience.
We recommend booking beforehand as it’s a very popular place. We got lucky and managed to secure a booking on the day.
Our day was planned around visiting the Acropolis in the afternoon. This was to avoid the mass of crowds and hot weather. We also didn’t want to get burnt out on ancient sites and monuments beforehand.
We both love Greek food and wanted to sample as much of the local food as possible. What better place to do that than Athens? We hastily researched where we should eat and put together a list.
First stop was O Kostas to try the best souvlaki in Athens. Or so they claim. O Kostas is a family run business that has been around for over 65 years. They serve a simple, old fashioned style of souvlaki for €2 each. An absolute bargain.
We both went for pork and devoured it quickly. It was delicious. We could have easily had several more! We had to leave some room for the other food stops though so it was off to get some coffee next.
The unusual name of this cafe stood out to us and good things happen when you combine art and coffee. This stylish spot was full of Greek people of all ages enjoying a chat and coffee. We ordered a couple of iced coffees from here as that seemed to be what was popular.
The coffees were fine. The space itself, however, seems to be the main draw. It feels hidden away and makes a great escape from the chaos outside.
Next up was sampling some Greek style pastries at Bougatsadiko Thessaloniki. The pastries are known locally as Bougatsa. We tried spinach and feta cheese and minced meat. Both were amazing and started our love affair with these pastries.
They’re a common breakfast meal and we had them often during our stay in Greece.
To put it simply, visiting The Acropolis is an absolute must-do whilst in Athens. In the summer months it can get extremely busy, like most of the big ticket sites across Europe. We were advised to visit in the early afternoon, as the mornings tend to be busier and by then the big crowds have finished up and left to eat lunch.
Another tip we came across was entering via the south entrance, which is closer to the Akropoli metro station and Acropolis Museum. This entrance tends to be much quieter than the main one. We lined up for less than 5 minutes to get our tickets here.
One of the best parts about visiting are the smaller temples and sites you can explore as you ascend to the top, where the visually iconic Parthenon rests. You also get great views of the city.
Our last stop for the day was the Thision Open Air Cinema. Located near the Acropolis, this retro cinema has a lot of charm and ended up being one of our fondest memories of Athens. It was the perfect place to unwind after a long day of exploring.
Tickets are well priced and so is the popcorn (and other snacks) and alcohol. There is an intermission during the middle of the film where you can stock up again also. All of this while you sit under the stars with the Acropolis in the background.
Visiting in the evening is essential, and we imagine it would get quite chilly outside the summer months.
After the movie we went back to our Airbnb for some much needed rest. We had an 8am flight the next morning to head south towards Milos, a beautiful island famous for its rocky landscape.

Title: Running Athens
Content:

Listen

Whenever I travel, I pack my running gear. Partially because I might be training for an upcoming race, but also because there are few better ways to get a true feel for a town.
Running between different places gives you a more accurate feel for scale and distances, something you do not get from travelling by Metro or cab. The Metro makes short distances longer and convoluted, whilst taxis tend to take you through bigger roads, creating a barrier between other people, the terrain, and even the smells.
I enjoyed many things in Athens, from the scenery to the food, but to be fully transparent, the traffic and air pollution were quite off-putting at the beginning. I nearly convinced myself it was a bad idea to go for a run. Aside from the car fumes, we’d barely seen a single jogger on our first day there.
But looking at the map, I noticed there were several large green spaces with fairly little distance between them. So I created an itinerary starting from where we were staying and covering four of the major points of interest, whilst mostly staying off the busy road.
It is worth noting that many of the smaller streets are seldom used by cars, making them much more pleasant than the pavement on the bigger roads. That being said, the pavement is narrow at the best of times and full of obstacles, from holes, steps, parked vehicles, and cats!
Depending on where you are staying, you will need to adapt the itinerary. But wherever you start from, you can keep the general principles and loop through the various sites.
I first started with a large hill close to where I was staying. It is known as Nymph Hill, Pnyx Hill, or Lofos Philopappou depending on which side you are on (at least that’s what I was told). It is about 75 hectares and provides numerous trails partially shaded by pine trees. At the top, you will find the antique ruins of the Prison of Socrates, the Philopappos Monument, and numerous unobstructed viewing points of the Acropolis.
The national observatory is located on the northern side of the park, although I only realised this when spotting the old Doridis National Observatorium from the height of the Acropolis. This side of the hill is also host to the Pnyx Monument. It would be quite easy to complete a 5km run just by exploring the different paths available and going around to see the numerous points of interest.
From there, you can reach the Acropolis in just a few minutes, and run around it mostly on pedestrian streets. At this point, you might want to stop for a quick look at the nicely renovated Odeon of Herodes Amphitheatre situated on the south side, which is accessible without a ticket.
As a next stop, I aimed for the Lycabettus Hill viewing point, which towers over the capital at an altitude of 277m. To reach it from the Acropolis, there is no other way than going across through Plaka, where small streets are busy with shops and tourists, but few cars, at least until you reach the Leof Vasilisis Amaliasthe, which is the busiest avenue. On the other side, you can check the Monument to the Unknown Soldier before going back to smaller streets. At that point, you will have to slow down as the slope gets very steep and the run up zigzags through arid-looking cactus vegetation. It is a breathtaking climb, both physically and metaphorically.
My final stop was the Panathenaic Stadium, which is the only marble stadium in the world. You will need a ticket to get inside and I didn’t have too much time left at that point, but would have liked to run a few laps inside this majestic monument of a stadium.
On my way back, I went for a meander in the Ethnikos Kipos — Athens National Garden. The well-maintained paths are easier than the gravel trail on the hills, and it is worth noting that those gardens are flat as opposed to all previous sites quoted above. Even if you avoid climbing up the Lycabettus Hill, there is no avoiding slopes and stairs when running across Athens. Even though I paused many times to take pictures, I still felt the heaviness in my legs the next day, having totalled nearly 500m of ascent!
One final thought is about the temperature. I visited Athens in November, which was very pleasant and perfect for a run during the day. I know from friends that the heat during the summer is quite unbearable and you would probably have to time your running tour in the early morning hours to escape the beating sun.
Overall, it was a delightful 15km run, which could have been more effective had I not gotten lost a few times. But that was also part of the experience!
My only regret is not having had the opportunity to run the original 42km from Marathon to Athens, which would have been a cherry on this tourist cake. No doubt I will be back for that!

Title: Athens, Αρετή, Alekos Fassianos and My Papous
Content:
Sign up
