Title: An Odyssey Through Time.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
At the entrance to the Acropolis, there is a plaque that commemorates Athens’ contributions to Western civilisation. The city has had an outsized impact in shaping the trajectory of modern democracy, philosophy, architecture, and drama, and I was excited to explore the place at the centre of it all: the Acropolis.
My day started at 9am after a quick breakfast of cold cuts and fresh fruit at the hostel. I had opted for a guided tour of the Acropolis, the Parthenon, and the Acropolis Museum, and I met my guide and our small group at the Acropolis metro station. Though I did spot a number of Indians on my flight to Athens yesterday, my group were all Americans and Canadians, with I being the sole representative from the eastern hemisphere.
Our guide had warned us that its best that we stay together and start the tour early, as three cruise ships had docked at Piraeus the previous day, and they would all descend on the Acropolis today, leading it to be an extremely crowded day to explore. By the time we reached the Acropolis, the crowds had started to thicken, with it being almost impossible to not be accosted by the sea of humanity at every turn.
The term Acropolis is from the Greek words akron, meaning highest point, and polis, meaning city. Though the area has been inhabited since prehistoric times, it was Pericles who coordinated the construction of the buildings that the area is famous for today: the Parthenon, the Erechtheion, and the Temple of Athena Nike. Over the years, countless wars and unthinkable acts of destruction, coupled with quests for religious and political hegemony have seriously damaged these magnificent structures, yet they still stand majestically over the city of Athens to tell their tale.
The Acropolis, though in reality (that honour goes to Lycabettus Hill, which I visited later) not the highest point of the city, rises 150m above the sea level, offering its occupants a commanding view of the city and its surroundings. On a clear day, one can see all the way to the port of Piraeus, enabling the rulers to have enough time to scramble resources in the case of an invasion. The Peloponnesian War between Athens and Sparta was primarily a battle for maritime control, as the victor of the war was guaranteed control over crucial maritime routes across the Mediterranean Sea. As my flight was descending onto the tarmac of Athens’ airport yesterday, I did notice the lack of vegetation across the terrain — the hills are pockmarked with shrub vegetation and the occasional olive tree, a contrast from the lush green vegetation that I’m used to back home in Kerala. Athens’ maritime prowess was thus a result of sheer necessity — the poor soil of the Attica region meant that the city’s only route to power and wealth was overseas trade, making a significant maritime presence key to their domination.
Our first stop on the tour was the Theatre of Dionysus, built between the fourth and the fifth century BC. Walking amidst its ruins, I was reminded of the contribution of the Greek tragedians: Sophocles, Euripedes, and Aesychlus, all of whom staged plays at this very theatre. There is also significant evidence to show that Aristophanes, the Father of Comedy, staged his play The Clouds at the very same venue, which eventually led to the trial and the subsequent condemning to death of Socrates. Artistic expression has always played an important role in maintaining the balance of power in society, and we will always have the great Greek playwrights to thank for their contributions.
A narrow path carved onto the slopes of the hill is the only way up and down the Acropolis, and as time passed by, the entire route became crowded with tourists. In most cities in Europe, over-tourism has become an increasing concern, with Athens being no exception. Our group slowly made way to the top, with the magnificent edifice of the Parthenon slowly coming into view. A former temple dedicated to the goddess Athena, the Parthenon is the definitive epitome of Greek architecture, an enduring symbol of democracy and Western civilisation.
Tired from climbing the modest hill in the Athenian summer, we gathered under the shade of an olive tree for some respite, when my eye caught sight of a plaque detailing the foundation myth of the city of Athens. According to Greek mythology, both Poseidon and Athena wanted to be the patron deity of the city, and with Zeus being unable to resolve the conflict, the competing Gods decided to have a contest and leave it to the citizens of the city to decide which gift was better than the other. Poseidon struck his spear to the ground and a spring sprang up, and Athena gave birth from the ground to a magnificent olive tree. The water from the spring was salty and not very useful, on the other hand, the olive tree provided the citizens with food, shade, oil, and wood, and the city was named after Athena, who then became the protector of this city, which would grow to become the most powerful city in all of Greece.
The Parthenon is a stunning example of Greek architecture, with architectural flourishes adorning all of its surfaces. Only a few of the frieze, mentopes, and pediments, which topped its magnificent Doric columns, now stand, with a few of them now in the Acropolis Museum, and the remaining, unsurprisingly, now housed in the British Museum in London, carefully smuggled out of then Ottoman Greece, by British nobleman and diplomat Thomas Bruce, the Earl of Elgin. The Elgin Marbles, as they are now called, are the Greek kohinoor, and the Greek have also been lobbying the hallways of Whitehall for its repatriation.
We then made our way back down to head to the last stop for the day: the Acropolis Museum. A magnificent structure of glass and steel, the museum houses remnants excavated from the neighbourhood surrounding the Acropolis. Consisting of three levels, the museum is a captivating blend of ancient and modern. The ground level showcases an impressive collection of ancient statues, excavated from the numerous sanctuaries that dotted the area. However, the star of the museum is undoubtedly the Parthenon Gallery, a breathtaking glass atrium constructed in the same dimensions as the Parthenon itself. The gallery holds the famous Parthenon frieze, the metopes, and the pediments, all arranged to mirror their original positions on the Parthenon. During earlier requests to the British for the return of the Elgin Marbles, the British Government made the claim that the Greeks had “no suitable location where they could be displayed”, and the creation of the Acropolis Museum aims to remedy this shortcoming in the Greek request for reattribution.
Our tour ended at 2pm and I felt drawn to explore more of the city’s historic charm. I began by strolling through Makrigianni’s streets and towards Plaka. As I walked the quiet streets of Plaka, the calmness of Athens became evident as birdsong filled the air, a rare sound in a bustling city. After a quick lunch of a gyro, I headed to the Athens National Garden, a green space in the heart of the city. Nestled between the park and the magnificent Hadrian’s Temple of Olympian Zeus is the Zappeion, a palatial building built for the Olympic Games. Named after Evangelos Zappas, one of the pioneers of the modern Olympic Games, it is now used for meetings and ceremonies and holds a place in history as the site where Greece’s ascension to the Eurozone was signed in May 1979.
As I wrapped up my explorations for the day, I found myself ruminating over the city’s striking blend of the old and the new, a harmonious co-existence of historical legacy and contemporary vibrance. Athens is a city that has continued to evolve without losing sight of its illustrious past, and as I continue my journey deeper into this gorgeous city, I’m reminded that every step taken in Athens is a step through time, an experience that only few other cities in the world can provide.

Title: Athens Was Right To Sentence Socrates To Death
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
20
Share
What if Socrates’ death sentence was justified? I’m sure you’re rolling your eyes. After all, he’s likely the greatest philosopher that ever lived and a method of teaching —named the Socratic Method out of reverence—bears his name.
Reverence is a good word to describe the current treatment for the man who possibly lived in 400 BC. Author Donald Robertson points out the presently popular Stoics used Socrates’ ideas as a building block. In fact, words written about him started Zeno of Citium down his path. Plus, Epictetus spoke admiringly about him as well.
The Oracle of Delphi even confirmed no one was wiser than Socrates. So, what could justify his punishment?
The philosopher’s curated story states he annoyed the Athenian establishment with his Socratic Method. In other words, he asked too many questions. Just think about your five-year-old nephew continuously asking “why” as you try to answer. Now, manifest that into a grown man’s frame.
Speaking of children, Socrates’ accusers also charged him with corrupting the youth of Athens. By “corrupting” most proclaim this means questioning their elders.

Title: New faces in old places: revitalizing Athens’ historic center [Podcast]
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The heart of Athens’ historic center is experiencing a revival. The 27-acre district is bounded by three of Athens’ most historic squares: Syntagma, Ommonia, and Monistraki. The Commercial Triangle, locally referred to as “Trigono,” is a working district, with commercial activity dating back to the 19th century.
Despite its historic and geographic significance, the neighborhood fell into disrepair in the 1980s. As a result, many buildings were vacated. By 2016, 17% of ground floor and 45% of upper floor spaces were vacant, while a survey of shopkeepers in the area found that 50–70% believed graffiti, lack of cleanliness, and illegal parking were serious issues. While there were pockets of economic activity, the neighborhood was not pedestrian-friendly and it was struggling to attract new investment.
As a city emerging from an eight-year crisis, Athens is making real progress in charting a new future. Under the leadership of Mayor Giorgos Kaminis, the city is employing creative solutions to improve quality of life, and his focus on cultivating community pride and optimism is making a real impact. One of his cornerstone projects has been the revitalization of the Trigono neighborhood.
Since 2015, Bloomberg Associates has worked with Mayor Kaminis to advance his priority projects by sharing expertise from the global network of client cities. Bloomberg Associates is the international, philanthropic consulting arm of Bloomberg Philanthropies, providing select mayors and city governments with custom consultation and mentorship.
This episode features conversations with Alexandros Kambouroglou, the Executive Director of the Athens Partnership, and Elina Dallas, the Project Manager for the Trigono program. Jake Elder of Bloomberg Associates Sustainability Team joined them in Athens.

Title: The Riddle of C.L.R. James, Classical Athens, and American Civilization
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Many are troubled or have difficulty understanding the meanings of CLR James’s meditations on Classical Athens and his study of American civilization. Far more important than whether antiquity and modern societies consistently embody profound philosophical values is what are our own democratic aspirations. This is the riddle at the intersection of James Athenian meditation within his book American Civilization.
Can Classical Athens be a measure for appraising America? Can the world of Aristotle, Aeschylus, Aristophanes, Cleon, and Pericles illuminate the ethnically and culturally plural United States? How does nuclear power compare with a few thousand Greeks battling in the Peloponnesian Wars, or at Marathon, Platea, and Salamis in the Greco-Persian Wars? As the 1950s began, C.L.R. James, a Caribbean radical scholar, thought this comparative thinking central for clarifying freedom and popular self-government. Perhaps sublimated within the American constitutional struggle for happiness was the class struggle.
Between the Struggle for Happiness and the Class Struggle
CLR James (1901-1989) wrote on diverse topics: Haiti, Russia, France, Ghana, and Hungary. He also purposefully considered Shakespeare, Herman Melville, the Hegelian dialectic, Caribbean women of the barrack yard, and the sport of cricket. Placing Classical Athens in conversation with mid-twentieth century America, this experimental meditation challenges us. Can we think beyond boundaries? This is what James’s book American Civilization (1950) poses to the reader.
James was detained as an undesirable immigrant and a political prisoner at Ellis Island in 1952. His defense strategy, though he never found a fit public platform for it like Paul Robeson, was to explain the dilemmas of American democracy and civilization to the public and overcome official authorities.
Why Compare Athens and America?
James compared tropes of ancient Athens and modern America. He discussed questions of popular self-emancipation that are subordinated by rigid historical materialist views. Whether poor, powerless, alienated, or aware of a conquering force, most observers have a false idea of toiling people's creative potential. This is a result that dialogues about culture, civilization, and democracy generally, assume commoners have no part. Perhaps, their lives are permitted as cultural decoration for society.
A Trinidadian activist and illegal immigrant to the U.S., James believed these ancient and modern societies were valuable comparative referents to unpack this dilemma of freedom. This was so, even though the classical Athenian city-state was probably no larger than the size of the population of 1950s Vermont, one of America's smallest states. And the ancients' economy was probably no bigger than one modern department store.
Who compares a continent-wide modern country to an archipelago of islands in antiquity? Of course, a Caribbean man who admires Ancient Greece. But he was not juxtaposing a small place with an imperial center. James was evaluating world civilizations and clarifying the search for popular struggles within them.
Every Cook Can Govern and the Meaning of American Civilization
We must remember that James’s Every Cook Can Govern (1956) argued that the classical Athenian city-state was a direct democracy. That this could inform rebellious modern politics against elite representative governments, whether maintained by capitalists, communists, or trade union hierarchy. However, in American Civilization, the Athenian meaning was more obscure.
A hint is James’s Greece tells us something about the relations between working people, intellectuals, and artists. Further, it placed the ancient theatrical dramas of Aeschylus and Aristophanes in conversation with the modern popular culture of American films, comic strips, sports, and television. More than what academic literary critics thought, James’s mind was on what the audience or spectators did in response to popular cultural productions in antiquity. Further, what could they accomplish in the present and future?
First, we must understand that at least since the late 1980s and early 1990s, the U.S. has been in a permanent culture war around social identities. The perennial dispute is Anglo-America, that some wish to “make great again,” versus ethnically plural multi-cultural America. American conservatives claim that Greco-Roman heritage is foundational to Western civilization. On this basis, some say America is a civilization. They wish to place the U.S., after World War II, as taking over leadership of the world from Europe. This cultural approach arguably last had free reign in the early 1950s as James was writing shortly before the emergence of the Third World national liberation epoch.
Cultural Wars Around Social Identities
Today the U.S. is seen by most progressive scholars of American Studies as not a civilization but as a harvest of empire. A plurality of many ethnicities and cultures have gathered; American Exceptionalism is not the best means to account for this. Though the idea that progressives are against the empire of capital is most often a cruel joke. This is not irrelevant to understanding James’s American Civilization. For he points out correctly that modern business management theorists during World War II understood, far better than the Moscow-oriented communists, that workers wished to directly govern their industrial workplaces. And the historical evidence of the practices of both, two different hostile visions to popular self-government, prove James’s view accurate. This explains much about contemporary not merely early 1950s America. Still, this issue is what the link to the Ancient Greeks is all about; discovering the sublimation of everyday people’s potential.
James’s Athenian thought experiments for America go beyond the culture wars which is really a misnomer. The question is how will humans live on this planet; this is what the low-intensity, sometimes open conflicts have been about. What values will humans live by? It does not require ancient Greece or modern America to historically maintain a consistent set of values for this meditation to be useful. In fact, creative conflicts in societies can reveal not just chaos through possessive individualism but common futures. Observation of Hegelian contradictions is not about permanent sins or hypocrisy. Rather, the nuclei of the new society and their struggle to be born.
Beyond Culture Wars: American Civilization and Ancient Greeks
James’s American Civilization (1950), posthumously published in 1993, embodied this transition between the old world of looking at things and the new. But not fully as we might expect a famous Pan-African anti-colonial and independent socialist to do so.
James carried on the tradition of the French intellectual Tocqueville, and many other European thinkers who visited the U.S. from abroad. He was perhaps among the last to do his own comparative reflection on how America sustained, or not, the older foundations of Europe, which many assumed were philosophically Greek.
Placing the Athenian Legacy in Support of Popular Struggles
Most Americans, even university professors, cannot process intellectual thought that doesn't adhere to the patterns of the two main American electoral parties that overlord society together. James, counter-intuitively for many, was placing the Athenian legacy on the side of the workers, women, and Black freedom movements. After all, he was writing about civilization.
American civilization needed a coherent political and cultural philosophy. He was aware classical Athens subordinated women, slaves, and immigrants. James was trying to improve on the direct democratic sensibility for modern politics.
Civilization and National Cultures?
Contrary to Andrew Ross’s view, James was not writing about civilization or the prospects of socialism in one country. Instead, he was asking what was behind the cultural front built around Franklin Roosevelt produced by state planners, progressive intellectuals, and trade union hierarchy.
James was writing about a perceived civilization or national culture and incorporating dynamic tensions. It doesn’t matter whether we or James see America as a unified national culture or not. American concerns with disunity reveal this is how the vast majority see things, even where they dispute the American character and purpose.
The struggles for an ambiguous workers' democracy, and Black and women's liberation, he reconciled with the ideals of Greek antiquity that normally was wielded by modern Western elites. James did not strongly emphasize, in this publication, America as foundationally an empire based on African slavery and conquering the Indigenous, and for good reason.
Discarding Historical Trauma for a Renewal of Political Philosophy
The reception of James’s American Civilization is fumbled where it does not center James as an aspiring cultivator of the popular will. Moreover, where it does not illustrate that he is trying to clarify the political philosophy of ordinary Americans.
James was writing for a popular audience, who in the aftermath of World War II, did not easily grasp anti-imperialism. We must remember in real life he agitated against World War II as a clash of racists, imperialists, and authoritarians on both sides. This was something the Moscow-oriented communists did not do. For, like Stalinist Russia, they became allies of Franklin Roosevelt.
Before the Montgomery Bus Boycott: Thinking Beyond Equal Opportunity
This manuscript was an exercise in creative self-expression and not merely disciplined to a radical political movement. More significantly, those who pursue the death of the American nation culturally and intellectually (but not really, it's just an academic trope) fail to posit what should be America's political philosophical basis.
While in the early 1950s, the modern civil rights movement as embodied by the Montgomery Bus Boycott had not yet begun, we must remember something crucial. Equal opportunity to enter the rules of hierarchy has no democratic basis (direct majority rule) and has only renewed the American empire. It can only have a democratic basis for those who wish to diversify the hierarchies of a republic, which by definition doesn’t believe everyday people can govern.
This perennial failure, but intentional act for those who sell past traumas for present decadent collaborations, was far from what James was pursuing. The colonized man from the British empire sojourning within the American empire was trying something different. American Civilization was trying to discover popular self-management beyond voters for electoral politics, aware the vote had not yet been guaranteed to all.
Gathering Fragments Like an Archaeologist
James’s American Civilization is like many ancient Greek texts. Their discovery and publication, as archaeologists and historians comprehend, is a retrieval project of incomplete fragments that only partially indicate the world of their authors. James’s final draft may have clarified and foreshadowed the nature of the American empire. Similar to his Mariners, Renegades, and Castaways (1952), he might have shown the solution was the motley crew, the global toilers of Herman Melville’s whaling vessel, cooperating and aspiring to save the social ecology under arduous circumstances. The preface to James’s Melville book reminded this was one part of a larger study of the U.S.
However, American Civilization articulates a scenario, seemingly outdated from the moment it was written. What if John L. Lewis, the famous trade union leader of the mineworkers, became the next president after Harry Truman? This was an irritating projection for those who knew James was an advocate of workers' self-management, and Lewis was part of repressing such social instincts during the Age of the CIO labor movement (1933-1955). Still, many miss the ancient Greek content of James’s thought experiment.
Learning from Aristophanes's Sausage-Seller
James argued that if American intellectuals in the early 1950s could understand artistic creation, like Aristophanes in his play The Knights, ordinary people could be encouraged to subvert populist authoritarian leaders, such as Cleon in the era of the Peloponnesian War. The "sausage-seller" appears to do this in The Knights; James’s American Civilization uncharacteristically refers not simply to workers, farmers, and cooks but to sausage-sellers, a plebian identity from ancient Greece. Though many Americans eat hot dogs and sausages, ordinary toilers have a difficult time revolting against bureaucracy within their own freedom movements.
James proposed, not an affirmation of the authoritarian trade union leader or progressive politician; rather, an impending confrontation with them by the "sausage-sellers." That Lewis was a Republican, who both sided and clashed with Franklin Roosevelt, and who was a major trade union leader, complicates things nicely. If James’s readers were actually going to think for themselves. Many formally educated have had difficulty since the book was published posthumously. Why write about Greek antiquity or workers at all?
James explained that observers of American civilization, unlike European history (ancient and modern), do not understand that behind great personalities above society (in politics, sports, and entertainment) are the aspirations, the repressed strivings of social classes and groups. While James believed every ordinary toiler could govern society, there was a counter-vailing idea. Those individual personalities who express heroism and creative genius do not mirror the abilities of commoners. But this is a result that society is not arranged properly for everyday people to arrive on their own authority. Many like to live vicariously through great personalities above society. James, the cultivator of the popular will, was trying to draw them out of their shell below society.
The Social Motion Below the Great Personalities Above Society
James felt the classical city-state was approximating or approaching this possibility in a more primitive way before the emergence of modern politics. We must remember the totality of ancient Greece is invented by archaeologists. Classical Athens functioned substantially toward a future without a past.
Behind the statesmen (Cleisthenes, Solon, Cleon, and Pericles) were the emerging “proletarians of Piraeus.” Observing and judging the artistic productions of Aristophanes, Euripides, Sophocles, and Aeschylus, was an audience of rank-and-file citizens. Importantly, not professional experts.
James underscored it was the popular audiences of theatrical productions that thousands of years later were manufactured as “high culture” by American and Western elites that decided what plays were the greatest. And so, the ordinary people of Athens had the capacity for independent judgment. And given the content of the award-winning plays, they clearly had the ability to make political judgments. Therefore, James is saying to his American audience that popular culture is high culture. And the latter is a fabrication unless it centers the judgment and capacities of everyday people. Western and American elites would be surprised to hear this.
Aeschylus’s Oresteia, Dick Tracy, and the Mafia in 1950s America
In the early 1950s U.S., people delighted in Dick Tracy comic strips and films depicting the Mafia. For James, these had something in common. Ordinary Americans were not satisfied with hierarchical government; they wished to live outside the state and its law. Though, of course, these were impositions. Tracy, a private detective, surprisingly had something in common with gangsters. They had guns, took matters into their own hands, and were not police.
American toilers wanted to be their own law-givers. While Plato searched for personalities to discipline the grassroots of the city-state, he felt it was a must, where Athenian commoners, even slaves, walked the streets like they were audacious peers of elitist citizens. It is debatable whether this is structurally true of ancient Athens. Rather, this was James’s Plato observing and fearing, through the trope of Socrates, the popular self-emancipating potential. This is our audacious Caribbean radical scholar's concern.
Vendettas, Patriarchy and Popular Courts
James loved Aeschylus’s Oresteia Trilogy. The meaning of its series of vendettas is disputed. Does it justify patriarchy or suggest a rebellion against it? Does it point to popular courts as the meaning of justice or the state as an argument for containing the Furies? Nevertheless, the audience decided these plays were award-winning. More crucially, as citizens, the audience had to decide, after the play the meaning of popular justice and their role in carrying it out.
James explained you can only relate to this if you have the sensibility of the ancient Greeks. Ordinary people’s actual social status in ancient Athens, or in modern America, was not decisive. Paramount was, how in culture and politics, commoners found means to think beyond their leaders and act on their own authority. What was revealed in Greek culture, sublimated in plays by Aeschylus or Aristophanes and their audiences, could also be seen in American popular culture. This told James something about mass audiences. Despite their surface psychology, they possess explosive potential.
The Odes of Pindar, Bureaucratic Politicians, and Business
James points to the poetry of Pindar implying it tells us about the commoners of ancient Greece and the U.S. What could he mean? He means a society that celebrates sports and competition, whether in the Olympic games or in modern baseball and football stadiums, where writing odes to the winners, confesses the true character of their nations. This cannot be embodied by politicians and businessmen. The barefoot and poor, with state sponsorship, little league uniforms, or playing in the street, express creative capacities in games that society is not organized for them to do so in politics. This can suggest a decline and fall for America or an emerging new beginning.
The comparative conversation about Athens and America does not move in straight and predictable patterns, especially for those who think like a voter for elite representative government. But even if the reader is starting to enjoy this meditation, how do we account for James’s celebration of Phidias and Praxiteles? What do ancient sculptors and architects say about the American proletariat? Further, James often did not make clear what the Peloponnesian War and Greco-Persian wars said about the potential of commoners in Greece and America.
What Can Be Accomplished in a Time of War?
Many scholars recognize that the Peloponnesian War (the battle between Athens and Sparta, which Sparta won) revealed an imperial tendency in Athens just as much as it embodies the search for federation. It is debatable what the meaning of the earlier Greco-Persian wars should mean for America. However, America, following World War II, was coming out of the experience of both foreign wars, and race, gender, and class struggles within.  James is saying great art and great heroism cannot fulfill themselves during war; society can only support them when it has put war behind them. Still, ordinary people’s instincts toward popular democracy, initially suppressed, can emerge in times of war as well. Even, if the rulers above society don’t wish this to happen. For James, the Athenian direct democracy presided over by Pericles between these ancient wars, was a new beginning where all citizens took part in popular councils and assemblies. There were no specialists and experts that dominated James’s Athens. Contrarily, this had been the vision of Franklin Roosevelt's planners and cultural apparatus.   The average Athenian citizen made decisions on economic planning, judicial affairs, and foreign relations, all matters the community faced. The Athenians knew everything was political, and art, science, and philosophy were integrated with politics and government, not in a dogmatic ideological way. But in the sense that, Greek citizens made the decisions directly that governed their lives. James was searching for a future America with these ideals and principles; certainly, the American conservative only pretended to do this for white men alone.
James did not believe Aristotle's politics should guide 1950s America. Though one should read him to understand politics and philosophy. Aristotle's Poetics interested James where the latter clarified what Athenian drama had been about when society was not menaced by war. The plays of Aeschylus and Aristophanes were about purging their audiences of pity and terror. Where the masses had pity for heroes, and felt society was stalked by doom, they might emerge to take matters into their own hands after witnessing such theatre.  However, to relate to this proposition, we must reject tragedy as fate or some catastrophe beyond our control. When an actual play comes to an end, what is at issue for James’s Aristotle, is what will the audience do afterward. James’s American Civilization felt progressive cultural critics in the U.S. instead attached themselves to hierarchical regimes instead of the unfolding impulses to popular self-management.
American Labor: Wartime Strikes, Wildcat Strikes
We must remember that during World War II, most trade union leaders signed contracts with the bosses for a no-strike pledge for patriotic sustaining of war production. As Martin Glaberman has documented, then the rank-and-file, through their wildcat strikes, took greater initiatives than they had, even during the early CIO labor movement. We must remember that the first March on Washington Movement that strived to forge African American civil rights, despite its zig-zags, was a wartime strike.
Ordinary Americans’ apparent consciousness and psychology yesterday were no indication of their independent insurgent action tomorrow. James made clear in American Civilization that if workers followed John L. Lewis or Walter Reuther, the auto workers’ leader today, this was not an indication of what may happen tomorrow. Where leaders follow the instincts of everyday people below society (or not), it does not mean commoners cannot rupture with them.
What Do America’s Wartime Strikes Have to Do With Ancient Greece?
What do American wartime strikes have to do with Ancient Greece? The Greeks who took part in the Peloponnesian War and the Persian Wars had their own racial, imperial, and patriarchal impulses. They lived through times of crisis where they did not know exactly what they wanted. It is these same people, who forged the first aspiring direct democracy. Separate from ideals associated with ancient Athens is a reality: imperfect people with blind spots were the foundation of an impressive civilization. This is so cross-culturally, when considering any world civilization, the search for profound autonomy must be drawn out of barbaric circumstances.  James’s American Civilization aspired to show that the purported genius of American organization was not a penchant for national production or industriousness. Rather, the main currents of American character are the capacities for popular self-government among ordinary people. Intellectuals who cannot see this, James says, commit treason. Our capacity to grasp this has something to do with how we understand Classical Athens.
Re-Reading Classical Athens Beyond the Affirmative Action Empire
A proper understanding of James’s Greek antiquity studies is still emerging. And aspects of how he grasped the United States are still obscure. Can ancient Athens, or its spirit and ideals, be a model for America as a civilization, or a comparative reference for our understanding of American freedom and popular self-government? Do we inherently clash with contemporary dispositions in such pursuit? Where it forces us to move beyond making America “great again,” but also the affirmative action empire and the ethnically plural police state, James’s legacies deserve reconsideration.
--
--
independent scholar of Africana Studies, World History, and political philosophy

The history of Athens is closely tied to the history of Greek democracy. It was in Athens that this form of political regime, which contributed to the city’s greatness and spread throughout the Greek world, developed. However, the early history of Athens remains obscure. It is known that there was a palace at the future city’s location during the Mycenaean period, surviving the destruction at the end of the second millennium. This allowed Athens to be a refuge for Greeks who settled in Ionia in the early 11th century. Little is known about the city’s history before the late 7th century. Aristotle, in the first part of the Constitution of Athens, reports that the original royal power was divided among three archons, later joined by six thesmothetes. Initially appointed for life, then elected for ten years, and finally annually, these archons governed with the assistance of a council of elders on the hill of Ares, known as the Areopagus. Two events marked the late 7th century: Cylon’s attempt to establish tyranny, thwarted by archon Megacles of the Alcmaeonid family, and Draco’s creation of a legal code regulating punishment for crimes of bloodshed. Aristotle also attributes a constitution to Draco, which modern critics consider a forgery from the late 5th century by those opposed to democracy.

Title: Athens
Angular Athens
A Cab Ride in Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Worth your time.

--
Listen
Share
I just arrived in Athens. My cab driver’s name was Christos.
His father was from Greek Macedonia, his mother from Crete. Men in Crete wear all black as a symbol of respect, he told me, “for the men who fought and lost their lives in the many wars, ‘fighting for our freedoms.’”
“Greece has so much history for such a little country.” “Look at you, you have such a big country and so little history.” (Ahem… I had been reading Thomas Jefferson’s biography on the plane.)
Christos had a construction company with over 25 employees before the Economic Crisis. As work started to dry up, he continued to pay his workers and had to lay them off gradually as the money ran out. He still has a company “on paper” but there has been no work for years. The company was started by his father who, he said, cries because he thought he had given his son a livelihood and now there is nothing.
I asked if he was against Greece being in the European Union. “No, I am not against Europe, I just want Europe to care about Greeks. Not Greece. Greeks.”
Cristos has three children so, he said, what was he to do? He spent money buying a taxi license. Two years ago, it cost him 100,000 euros (from 250,000 before the crisis.) Now the price has dropped again to 50,000 but Christos can’t recover the money he has already paid. He says that there is no work and even if there were, no one would hire him because he has several diplomas — he is too qualified.
He was rushing to finish up and get home before tonight’s World Cup soccer match started. Brazil-Colombia. I asked who he was for. “Brazil, of course.”
“You know they have the most expensive player in the world: Neymar?” (I did know.) “One hundred million euros. That is what they paid for a futbol player,” Christos said. “We — this humanity — we have to change. We have to change because we have children.”
As he pulled into the hotel, he apologized, “So much history. Such a much bigger conversation.”
But, sometimes the only way to start big conversations is with small ones — like a short chat with a stranger.
--
--
Worth your time.
POPVOX CEO and co-founder. Entrepreneur, lawyer, recovering Congressional staffer. Former Harvard Ash and New America California fellow.

Title: The Turk Who Made Athens Happy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
“The Parthenon Marbles are part of the Parthenon Temple, the most important work of ancient Greek architecture, considered the highest sculpture and artwork of its time. Of course, its importance doesn’t end there; what happened afterwards contributes to its story” said Zeynep Boz from the eastern side, bringing joy to the western coast of the Aegean.
Boz, a prehistoric archaeology graduate with art, law, and ethics degrees, represents Turkey as the Head of the Anti-Smuggling Department of the Ministry of Culture and Tourism. She previously served as a contact person for UNESCO with the UN Security Council. When she declared that there was no evidence supporting the claim that the Parthenon Marbles were taken to England legitimately during the Ottoman Empire, she became the person of the week in Greece, making Athens happy. But what is the story of the Parthenon Sculptures, which pit Greece against England? What does Turkey’s cultural support for Athens mean?
The bust of Nefertiti, extracted by German archaeologists from Egypt and brought to the Neues Museum in Berlin; the Rosetta Stone, discovered by a French soldier during a fortification excavation in Egypt and sent to the British Museum; the statue of Emperor Lucius Verus, returned to Turkey after being smuggled abroad in 1972… History, discovery, and plunder… All have been intertwined for centuries. The fate of the marble sculptures friezes, and architectural pieces taken from the Parthenon Temple in the Athenian Acropolis was no different.
Dedicated to the Greek goddess Athena, these sculptures went from Athens, then part of the Ottoman Empire, to England in the early 19th century. It was claimed that the artefacts were taken with permission, thanks to a decree obtained by British diplomat Lord Elgin from the Ottomans. Support for returning this significant historical treasure, which has often caused diplomatic tension between Athens and London, came from Turkey on the other side of the Aegean. Zeynep Boz, the Turk who made Athens happy, answered questions.
Your speech about the Parthenon Sculptures at last month’s UNESCO meeting attracted attention. Is Turkey’s support for Greece’s efforts to retrieve the Parthenon Sculptures from England unexpected?
Frankly, Turkey’s support is not unexpected. The Parthenon Marbles is already a matter on which Greece is never alone. Turkey’s support is both sincere and deep-rooted and not new. It has continued uninterruptedly with a non-political approach. Likewise, Greece’s support for Turkey in combating cultural heritage smuggling is equally vital.
I think the reason behind making Athens so happy is your statement about a controversial document. For years, the United Kingdom has claimed an Ottoman decree granted permission for the artefacts to be taken to England.
Absolutely. The difference in this year’s session was Turkey coming forward and saying, “There is no such document.” England claimed that these artefacts were purchased legally from the Ottomans, according to Ottoman laws. As in Turkey, we had to respond. I needed to correct this. Otherwise, as a member of a country holding the Ottoman State archives, I would have accepted this claim.
We need a document showing that the Parthenon was legally acquired during the Ottoman period. There is only one translation mentioned in England. I need to see the original alongside it to call something a translation. So that there is a reference point. There is only something written in Italian on paper… No Ottoman seal, no sultan’s monogram…
So, it’s like a piece of note?
I wouldn’t want to say it like that, but in a way, yes. At least I can tell, “It has no official status.” I know Turkey’s stance had a significant impact.
It is perceived as if it changed something. However, over the years, I have seen the great sacrifices and efforts the Greek delegation has made.
What if England says, “Then let’s look at your archives”?
Many British researchers have already come to Turkey. Not just at the government level. Many academics have come to Turkey and conducted research in the state archives. The Ottoman State Archives are already open to the public. This is not something we are hiding. So, I say to England in response to this claim, “If we don’t have documentation, wouldn’t it be better not to make such a claim?”
You represent Turkey at the ministerial level. However, you are primarily a cultural person. You say, “You don’t discriminate based on religion, language, or race; we unite in the effort to reclaim our cultural heritage; friendship transcends borders.” Are the recent developments a concrete result of the détente policy in Turkey-Greece relations that began towards the end of last year? Or is it an ongoing cultural collaboration that is independent of this?
I support the second option. The first option also influenced the growth of the second. When relations between the two countries are better, when the winds of friendship blow, the manoeuvring areas of every nation naturally expand; this is a fact. But believe me, it would have been said earlier if this had happened. It was a very natural comment made by Turkey. It was related to the moment; it was not planned. As you know, Turkey’s Minister of Culture Mehmet Nuri Ersoy recently visited Greece and met with his counterpart there. Following these meetings, his Greek counterpart briefed him on the matter.
When the Minister returned to Turkey, he requested information from us. He said, “Let’s always continue this support; I want to be informed of all developments. This is a global issue where Turkey needs to show its stance.” These are not insignificant developments. However, on an expert level, Turkey and Greece have always supported each other in a non-political, technical manner.
Is the British Museum now obliged to return the Parthenon Sculptures?
We know how much the habits of collecting and collection practices have harmed cultural assets and how much they have fragmented and destroyed them. I wish the British Museum would return them… We are used to seeing moves related to England that will be turning points in human rights and many other areas, milestones in world history.
Of course, we would like to see one of these regarding the Parthenon. We would also like to see this with artefacts belonging to Turkey. So, is the British Museum obliged to return them? The obligation can be debated. But at least in an era where apologies are being made, I would very much like to see the British Museum return these artefacts to Greece.
--

Title: Ancient Athenian Ostracism
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Thousands of pieces of ostracon have been uncovered in Athens.
These ostraka are pieces of pottery that acted as voting tokens during an ostracism. In an ostracism vote, people (free men) would scratch the name of someone who they believed threatened democracy onto ostraka and if 6000 or more votes were cast, the person with the most votes was banished from Athens for a period of 10 years.
The men who voted in this decision were part of the Athenian Assembly (Ekklesia), which was made up of adult citizen men. These men made up a fairly small percentage of the 30,000–60,000 large population which was also made up of women, enslaved people and foreign-born residents.
Ostracism did not happen automatically, the assembly had to vote each year in favour of holding one and often they were not called. In the 71-year period that ostracisms took place (487 BCE — 416 BCE), only 13 individuals were ostracised.
If the vote was to be held, the actual ostracism poll would happen two months later. The voting process was called the ostracophoria, meaning ‘election to ostracise’.
The unlucky individual who ‘won’ the vote had 10 days to put their affairs in order before they had to leave with no* possibility of return before a decade was up. If one did try to reenter Athens during this time, they faced the possibility of the death penalty.
Despite these harsh terms, an ostracised individual was still allowed to keep any property they owned and could still be considered a citizen of Athens, which, as stated earlier, was a privilege which was not extended to everyone. Further, on return to Athens, it seemed that little changed for the outcast and they could return to politics with significant social status.
No politician was safe from ostracism and it was extremely common for a senior member of the state to have to take a 10-year ‘break’ from Athens due to the vote. One such example was Themistocles, a non-aristocratic politician and general of the 5th-6th centuries BCE who had succeeded in leading Greece to triumph over their enemy, Persia. At one point, Themistocles was one of the most famous and important politicians in Athens, meaning that he was a threat to democracy.
The pieces of ostracon above hold the names, top to bottom, of Pericles (politician and general), Cimon (politician and general), and Aristides (politician). Pericles is the man who put into motion the building program that created the Parthenon and other structures on the Acropolis. Aristides is one of the lucky banished men who actually got to return to Athens before his ten years were up. Aristides was ostracised in 482 BCE but was recalled to the city-state in 479 BCE to help Athens get ready for the upcoming war against Persia.
Although the purpose of the ostracism was to vote out somebody who became too powerful, it’s likely many people just voted for the person they liked the least. Some of the votes found in ancient rubbish dumps seem to have had a message of personal grievance. Some names had the added epithets of “traitor”, “slanderer” or “adulterer”. The politician Cimon, whose name can be seen on a piece of ostracon in the above picture, had his personal scandal alluded to by at least one angry voter. Smithsonian Magazine writes that one ostracon had the words “Kimon Miltiadou, take Elpinike and go!” etched onto it, Elpinike being the half-sister he was rumoured to have had an affair with.
For better or for worse, the last ostracism took place in Athens in 416 BCE.
Should we bring ostracism back? It seems like a much faster and more efficient way of non-violently removing people from authority, than the bureaucracy that keeps politicians in check today. I, for one, am a fan.
Gannon, M. (2020, October 27). Ancient Greeks Voted to Kick Politicians Out of Athens. Retrieved from Smithsonian Magazine: https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/ancient-athenians-voted-kick-politicians-out-if-enough-people-didnt-them-180976138/
Ostracism in Ancient Greece | National Geographic Society. (n.d.). Retrieved from National Geographic: https://education.nationalgeographic.org/resource/ostracism-ancient-greece
Ostracism: ‘Cancel culture’ Ancient Greek-style. (n.d.). Retrieved from Sky HISTORY: https://www.history.co.uk/articles/ostracism-cancel-culture-ancient-greek-style

Title: How to Think Like a Greek: A Journey to the Agora of Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Empowering voices, igniting minds. Atlantis is your platform to share knowledge, express yourself freely, and connect with a community of passionate learners. Write, share, and be heard!

--
Listen
Share
Imagine walking in the footsteps of the greatest thinkers of all time, witnessing their lively debates, learning from their wisdom, and participating in their democracy. This is what it was like to visit the Agora of Athens, the heart and soul of ancient Greece.
The Agora was more than just a marketplace. It was the hub of civilization, where philosophy, democracy, and religion flourished. It was where the ancient Greeks shaped their culture, their values, and their legacy.
In this article, we will take you on a virtual tour of the Agora of Athens, and show you how you can think like a Greek. We will explore the fascinating world of the philosophers, who challenged the status quo, questioned everything, and sought the truth. We will also discover the secrets of the citizens, who practiced direct democracy, exercised their rights and duties, and defended their freedom. And we will admire the beauty of the gods, who inspired awe, devotion, and art.
Are you ready to embark on this journey? Then let’s go to the Agora of Athens, and learn how to think like a Greek.
The Agora was the birthplace of Western philosophy, where Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle taught and debated. These three philosophers are known as the founders of the classical tradition of philosophy, and their ideas have influenced countless thinkers and fields of study throughout history. But who were they, and what did they teach?
Socrates was the oldest and most controversial of the three philosophers. He was born around 470 BC, and he spent most of his life in the Agora, engaging in conversations with anyone who would listen. He did not write anything himself, but his words and deeds were recorded by his followers, especially Plato.
Socrates was famous for his method of questioning everything and everyone, often annoying the authorities and the public. He believed that the only way to find the truth was to examine one’s own beliefs and assumptions, and to expose the contradictions and ignorance that lay beneath them. He once said, “The unexamined life is not worth living.”
Socrates was interested in ethical and political questions, such as what is justice, what is virtue, and how should one live. He claimed that he did not know the answers, but that he was seeking them with the help of his interlocutors. He also claimed that he was guided by a divine voice, or a daimon, that warned him of what not to do.
Socrates’ relentless questioning and criticism of the established norms and values of his society earned him many enemies, especially among the powerful and the wealthy. He was accused of corrupting the youth and impiety, and he was brought to trial in 399 BC. He defended himself with eloquence and wit, but he refused to compromise his principles or to escape from prison. He was found guilty and sentenced to death by drinking hemlock.
Socrates’ death was a tragic and heroic event that marked the end of an era, but also the beginning of a legacy. His followers, especially Plato, continued his mission of seeking the truth and questioning the conventional wisdom. Socrates became a symbol of courage, wisdom, and integrity, and his example inspired generations of philosophers and thinkers.
Plato was the most devoted and influential student of Socrates. He was born around 428 BC, and he came from a wealthy and noble family. He was interested in poetry and politics, but he abandoned these pursuits after meeting Socrates and becoming his disciple. He followed Socrates everywhere, and he recorded his dialogues and teachings in his writings.
Plato was the founder of the Academy, the first institution of higher learning in the Western world. He established the Academy in 387 BC, near the sacred grove of Academus, outside the walls of Athens. The Academy was a place where students and scholars could study and discuss various subjects, such as mathematics, astronomy, music, and philosophy. The Academy attracted many brilliant minds, such as Aristotle, Euclid, and Archimedes.
Plato was the author of many dialogues, which are considered the most important and influential works of philosophy. In his dialogues, he used the form of a conversation between Socrates and other characters, such as his friends, enemies, or famous figures. He used this form to explore various topics, such as the nature of reality, knowledge, morality, beauty, and justice. He also used this form to present his own views and arguments, often through the mouth of Socrates.
Plato was an idealist, who believed that there was a higher and perfect realm of ideas, or forms, that existed beyond the physical and changing world. He believed that the forms were the true essence and models of everything that exists, and that they could only be known by reason and intuition. He also believed that the forms were the source of goodness, beauty, and justice, and that the goal of human life was to achieve harmony and alignment with them. He once said, “Philosophy begins in wonder.”
Plato was also a visionary, who imagined the ideal state and the ideal ruler in his most famous dialogue, the Republic. In the Republic, he argued that the state should be governed by the philosopher-king, who had the knowledge and the virtue to rule wisely and justly. He also argued that the state should be divided into three classes, according to their natural abilities and roles: the guardians, who were the rulers and protectors; the auxiliaries, who were the soldiers and helpers; and the producers, who were the farmers and craftsmen. He also argued that the state should provide education, censorship, and eugenics, to ensure the harmony and stability of the society.
Plato’s ideas and writings have had a profound and lasting impact on the history of philosophy, science, art, and politics. He is regarded as one of the greatest and most original thinkers of all time, and his legacy is still alive and relevant today.
Aristotle was the most brilliant and prolific student of Plato. He was born in 384 BC, in Stagira, a small town in northern Greece. He was the son of a physician, and he had a natural curiosity and interest in the natural world. He joined the Academy when he was 17 years old, and he stayed there for 20 years, until the death of Plato. He then left Athens and traveled to various places, such as Asia Minor, Lesbos, and Macedonia. He became the tutor of Alexander the Great, the king of Macedonia, who conquered most of the known world. He returned to Athens in 335 BC, and he founded his own school, the Lyceum, where he taught and wrote until his death in 322 BC.
Aristotle was the author of many works, which cover almost every field of knowledge, such as logic, ethics, politics, biology, physics, and metaphysics. He wrote in a systematic and analytical style, using observation, classification, and deduction. He was the first to develop a comprehensive and coherent system of philosophy, which aimed to explain the nature and causes of everything that exists.
Aristotle was an empiricist, who believed that knowledge was derived from experience and observation of the physical world. He rejected Plato’s theory of forms, and he argued that the essence and form of a thing were inseparable from its matter and substance. He also argued that the world was composed of four elements: earth, water, air, and fire, and that each element had a natural place and motion. He also argued that the world was governed by four causes: the material cause, which was the matter of a thing; the formal cause, which was the shape and structure of a thing; the efficient cause, which was the agent or force that produced a thing; and the final cause, which was the purpose or goal of a thing. He once said, “It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it.”
Aristotle was also a practical and ethical thinker, who was interested in the best way of living and the best form of government. He wrote the Nicomachean Ethics, which is considered one of the most influential works of moral philosophy. In the Nicomachean Ethics, he argued that the highest good and the ultimate goal of human life was happiness, which he defined as the activity of the soul in accordance with virtue. He also argued that there were two types of virtue: intellectual virtue, which was acquired by learning and reasoning; and moral virtue, which was acquired by habit and practice. He also argued that virtue was a mean between two extremes, or vices, and that it required practical wisdom and moral judgment.
Aristotle also wrote the Politics, which is considered one of the most influential works of political philosophy. In the Politics, he argued that the state was a natural and necessary institution, which arose from the human need for social and political association. He also argued that there were different types of states, according to their constitution and their aim. He classified the states into six categories, based on the number and the quality of the rulers: monarchy, aristocracy, and polity, which were the good forms; and tyranny, oligarchy, and democracy, which were the bad forms. He also argued that the best form of state was the polity, which was a mixed and balanced constitution, where the middle class had the power and the common good was the aim.
Aristotle’s ideas and writings have had a tremendous and lasting impact on the history of philosophy, science, art, and politics. He is regarded as one of the greatest and most influential thinkers of all time, and his legacy is still alive and relevant today.
The Agora was also the center of Athenian democracy, where citizens voted and served as jurors. Athens was the first city-state to adopt a system of direct democracy, where every male citizen had the right and the duty to participate in the government. The Agora was where they gathered to elect magistrates, pass laws, and decide on war and peace. The Agora was also where they held trials, where citizens acted as both judges and jurors. One of the most famous trials was that of Socrates, who was accused of corrupting the youth and impiety. He was found guilty and sentenced to death by drinking hemlock.
But what exactly was democracy? And how did it work in Athens?
The word democracy means “rule by the people” in ancient Greek. It was a radical and revolutionary idea, that challenged the traditional forms of government, such as monarchy, aristocracy, or oligarchy. It was based on the principle of equality, that all citizens had the same rights and responsibilities, regardless of their wealth, status, or birth. It was also based on the principle of freedom, that all citizens had the liberty to express their opinions, to choose their leaders, and to hold them accountable.
Democracy in Athens was not the same as democracy today. It was a direct and participatory democracy, where citizens made decisions by themselves, without representatives or intermediaries. It was also an exclusive and limited democracy, where only adult male citizens had the right to vote, while women, slaves, and foreigners were excluded. It was also a fragile and unstable democracy, where factions, conflicts, and coups threatened its survival.
Democracy in Athens was practiced mainly in two institutions: the Assembly and the Courts. The Assembly was the main legislative and executive body, where citizens met at least once a month, and sometimes more often, to discuss and vote on various issues, such as laws, decrees, taxes, treaties, and wars. The Assembly was open to all citizens, who could attend, speak, and vote. The Assembly was also the supreme authority, that could elect, appoint, or dismiss magistrates, such as generals, treasurers, or archons. The Assembly was also the sovereign body, that could revise, amend, or abolish the constitution, or the fundamental laws of the state.
The Courts were the main judicial body, where citizens served as judges and jurors. The Courts were divided into several types, according to the nature and the amount of the cases, such as civil, criminal, public, or private. The Courts were composed of a large number of citizens, who were selected by lot, or randomly, from a pool of volunteers. The Courts were independent and autonomous, that could not be influenced or controlled by the Assembly or the magistrates. The Courts were also powerful and decisive, that could impose penalties, such as fines, exile, or death.
Democracy in Athens was a remarkable and unprecedented experiment, that inspired and influenced many other states and civilizations. It was also a challenging and demanding system, that required the active and informed participation of the citizens. It was also a noble and admirable ideal, that sought to achieve the common good and the public interest.
The Agora was also the place where temples and altars were dedicated to various gods and goddesses. The ancient Greeks were polytheistic, meaning they believed in many gods, each with their own personality and domain. The Agora had shrines for Zeus, the king of the gods; Athena, the patron goddess of Athens; Apollo, the god of the sun and music; Ares, the god of war; and many others. The Agora was also where religious festivals and ceremonies were held, such as the Panathenaia, the most important festival in honor of Athena. The festival included athletic contests, musical competitions, sacrifices, and a procession that carried a new robe for the statue of Athena.
But who were these gods and goddesses? And how did they influence the life and culture of the ancient Greeks?
The gods and goddesses of the ancient Greeks were the personifications of the natural forces and phenomena, such as the sky, the sea, the earth, the sun, the moon, the stars, the wind, the fire, the thunder, the rain, and the seasons. They were also the patrons and protectors of various aspects of human life, such as love, war, wisdom, justice, beauty, agriculture, commerce, and art. They were also the ancestors and relatives of the heroes and the legends, such as Hercules, Perseus, and Jason.
The ancient Greeks had a complex and rich mythology, that explained the origin and the history of the world, the gods, and the humans. They believed that the world was created by Chaos, the primordial void, from which emerged the first gods, such as Gaia, the earth; Uranus, the sky; and Tartarus, the underworld. They also believed that the gods were involved in a series of conflicts and wars, such as the Titanomachy, the war between the Titans and the Olympians; and the Gigantomachy, the war between the Giants and the Olympians. They also believed that the gods interacted and intervened in the affairs of the humans, sometimes helping, sometimes harming, and sometimes falling in love with them.
The ancient Greeks worshipped and honored the gods in various ways, such as building temples and altars, making sacrifices and offerings, performing rituals and ceremonies, and holding festivals and games. They also sought the favor and the guidance of the gods, by consulting oracles and diviners, by making vows and prayers, and by following omens and signs. They also feared and respected the gods, by obeying their laws and commands, by avoiding their wrath and punishment, and by accepting their fate and will.
The ancient Greeks also expressed their admiration and devotion to the gods through art and literature, such as sculpture, painting, pottery, poetry, and drama. They created magnificent and realistic statues of the gods, such as the statue of Zeus at Olympia, one of the seven wonders of the ancient world. They also depicted the gods and their stories on various objects, such as vases, coins, and jewelry. They also composed epic and lyrical poems about the gods and their deeds, such as the Iliad and the Odyssey by Homer, and the Theogony and the Works and Days by Hesiod. They also wrote and performed tragic and comic plays about the gods and their relations with the humans, such as the Oresteia by Aeschylus, the Oedipus Rex by Sophocles, and the Bacchae by Euripides.
The gods and goddesses of the ancient Greeks were the sources of awe and art, that inspired and influenced the life and culture of the ancient Greeks. They were also the symbols and the expressions of the values and the ideals of the ancient Greeks, such as courage, wisdom, beauty, and justice. They were also the reflections and the projections of the hopes and the fears of the ancient Greeks, such as love, war, fate, and death.
The Agora of Athens was more than just a marketplace. It was the hub of civilization, where philosophy, democracy, and religion flourished. It was where the ancient Greeks shaped their culture, their values, and their legacy.
The Agora of Athens witnessed the rise and fall of the Athenian democracy, the glory and tragedy of the Greek civilization, and the birth and development of the Western thought. It was the place where Socrates questioned and challenged, where Plato dreamed and idealized, where Aristotle observed and analyzed, where citizens voted and debated, where gods were worshipped and honored, and where art and literature were created and celebrated.
The Agora of Athens is a place that still inspires us today, and that we can learn from and admire. It is a place that reminds us of the achievements and the challenges of the human spirit, of the values and the ideals of the human society, and of the hopes and the fears of the human condition.
If you ever have the chance to visit Athens, don’t miss the opportunity to see the Agora for yourself. You will feel like you are traveling back in time, and you will discover the roots of Western civilization. You will also feel like you are connecting with the ancient Greeks, and you will understand their worldview and their legacy.
The Agora of Athens is not just a historical site. It is a living and breathing museum, where you can see, touch, and feel the history, the culture, and the philosophy of the ancient Greeks. It is also a vibrant and lively square, where you can meet, talk, and interact with the modern Greeks, who are the descendants and the inheritors of the ancient Greeks.
The Agora of Athens is a place where you can think like a Greek, act like a Greek, and be like a Greek. It is a place where you can experience the past, the present, and the future of the Greek civilization. It is a place where you can find yourself, lose yourself, and rediscover yourself.
The Agora of Athens is a place that you will never forget, and that you will always remember. It is a place that will change you, and that you will change. It is a place that will challenge you, and that you will challenge. It is a place that will inspire you, and that you will inspire.
The Agora of Athens is a place that awaits you, and that you await. It is a place that welcomes you, and that you welcome. It is a place that invites you, and that you invite.
The Agora of Athens is a place that you should visit, and that you will visit. It is a place that you should see, and that you will see. It is a place that you should know, and that you will know.
The Agora of Athens is a place that you should love, and that you will love.

Title: Analyzing The School of Athens by Raphael
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This artwork contains the presence of humans. There are many people gathering up against each other while doing what seems to be studying. Proven by the books they carried and read, these figures represent all of the greatest mathematicians, philosophers, and scientists that lived in that specific decade. Dozens of these geniuses all gathered around to discuss, sharing their ideas, expressing their opinions, and learning from each other. The architectural yet enormous building is mostly painted white. Some figures lay on the ground, reading and conversing. Some are upstairs gathering together, making a little crowd. The color palette was mostly vibrant, but washed out. Yet you can still see the soft contrast between the people’s clothes and backgrounds.
The artist used shapes such as cubes, rounded, and curved to create perspectives on the architectural building. At the front, we can see the building’s perspective from the curved line on the roof. But the overall structure of the building was probably cubed or a block. These different and neatly spread types of shapes made the artwork look more composed. The whole composition looked like it was moving. Because the artist made designs of people interacting with one another, they also made the color palette soft, so it radiates peacefulness. The central interest of this artwork is the two main characters that were painted in the middle of the commotion. It was obvious to spot them since the other individuals were all gathering around them. The artist succeeded in gaining my attention to the two by highlighting the middle of the painting. As you can see, the area where they stand is a bit lighter than the rest. Such little details make the biggest difference when it comes to painting.
The painting took place during the historical era of Plato. Let’s analyze the most distinctive element, which is the two people that were standing in the middle. Research claims that the two characters happen to be Plato and Aristotle. Plato was wearing red and purple. This color symbolizes the color of spirituality. A color that inspires reflection and self-awareness. While Aristotle was wearing blue with brown, which symbolizes the sky, sea, and earth, it also represents reliability and wisdom. These are the two main elements that the artist wanted to show through the main characters. The overall mood of the painting has a sign of coolness and warmth at the same time. The cool color tones that were used actually made the mood warm because the amount of commotion made the painting somewhat peaceful and relaxing to see. The landscape came off as natural, as the painting used a little bit of green for the building, so the piece itself was naturalistic. The object of the monument was already perfect because it holds and completes the inside of the painting, which is the people.
Paragraph one explains what is happening in the painting. We already knew they were discussing and trying to express their thoughts. This represents all of the different opinions and answers between people. The painting shows us geniuses. Mathematicians, philosophers, and scientists. Yet they are gathering together, trying to find and gain answers. This shows that everyone can disagree with one another. They can have different thoughts and philosophies about one case. The artist is trying to say that even if we are concerned and confused about a single matter, humans will try to find a way to solve it. The main theme behind this piece is the high Renaissance. If I were inside The School of Athens, I would probably try to catch up on the topic that was being discussed, so I wouldn’t feel left out. The story behind this art is that it’s positioned facing Disputa and symbolizes philosophy, setting up a contrast between religious and lay beliefs. The painting is abstract because it looks at other non-objective artistic elements of shape, form, and color. The artist explored his ideas beyond the canvas and physical reality. I would explain this artwork as a painting where people gathered up all their ideas. As proven by the painting itself and the dozen people there.
Raphael had created a masterpiece and expressive drawing. The soft and cool tones he used added to the overall feeling of composure, calm, and relaxation. The unseen movement between the people makes me feel at ease just by looking at it. The faint green tones developed a sign of liveliness and nature. For me personally, this artwork does not need any improvements, as it is already perfect and has met the criteria for being the aesthetic theory of Renaissance art.
