Title: ‘‘Cricket,Cricket,Cricket’’ — Welcome to Athens!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
My partner and I love to travel! (I mean who doesn’t?) Therefore we decided to visit the magnificent Greek city also known as Athens! You may be sitting there questioning the title, (Cricket, Cricket) and some of you may have guessed by now. Even though Athens is the capital city of Greece and a place that's crowded with shopaholics- the sound of crickets fill the air all day long. However, I am sure the locals are used to it.
When it comes to travelling we always try to budget and can always stick to it! (That is a complete lie.) We think about the places we want to visit and places we want to stay. Wherever in the world you may visit — you do not always get to visit each and every corner of the city, so our top attractions/activities depend on the amount of time we have in that city.
How many days is enough to visit Athens?
The time spent in a city all depends on the reason for visiting. For example you may visit for the beautiful sceneries, the outstanding history or you just love to open up your wallet and get straight into those bougie stores. However, in our case we just wanted to wallow in to delicious food and visit the still standing historical attractions. We had spent just under 2 nights in Athens. That is more than enough time to see the top attractions and indulge in all the finest foods Athens has to offer.
Two nights? Run me through your itinerary…
Sure. We arrived midday of August, and as soon as we landed and stepped foot outside the airport- the August heat lashed onto our skins! This may sound overdramatic- but do bare in mind we are from England and the sun does not do us great favours! As I was saying, the heat was a lot and we had to find transport to reach us to our accommodation. I love to use public transport when we travel to a foreign country and I am slightly against using taxis all the time unless it’s needed. Only because it takes away the enjoyment of feeling what it is like living like a local. However, I did regret this as soon as we reached because :
BUT mainly because
2. Public transport was not looking promising- it was overly crowded and that’s not what you want when you are carrying around your suitcase and a few other bags. So eventually we found a cab (baring in mind this took up to an hour) that took us straight to our accommodation.
Once we reached our apartment — we freshened up and gushed ourselves with sunscreen lotion! (Wearing sunscreen lotion sometimes feels like you are going to war with the sun — I mean you kind of are if you think about it.)
We decided to visit the most famous attractions of Athens first- I mean it would be an insult not to! The Acropolis and The Parthenon. On the way there I was imagining what it would look like — of course I knew the scenery would be beautiful but photos do not do justice — it looked incredible! ( Now for those of you that do not know what the The Acropolis is — well then you will just have to Google it.) It was a sight that caught my eye. Stairs took you straight to the top of the attraction and there you could take in the breath-taking views. (I will leave some helpful tips at the end, so do have a look.)
Next, we were starving — so we decided to take our last few photos and get some lunch/dinner (can we call that chinner?) We wanted to try Greek food- however, when it comes to being a vegetarian it is not that simple, especially in Europe.
First stop: Street Souvlaki — Gyros time! How was it? Personally, I liked it. It was stuffed with aubergine, courgette, halloumi cheese and chips and drizzled with chilli jam. Ok, for those of you that don’t love their vegetables this may not sound appealing — but it was good, I liked it. My husband on the other hand, ‘eh’. For those of you that don’t know what that means, it means, well it means ‘eh’.
Next cheeky stop: crêpes anyone? Yes please! Whatever happens on holiday stays on holiday and in your belly. Dessert is a must on holiday so we found a cute little dessert shop that were making crêpes and the smell dragged us in! We bought a crepe to share, (which we don’t usually do, but hey sharing is caring.) The smell of Nutella tickled by taste buds and to top it of with some Strawberries.
Day 2: Don’t cha wish you girlfriend liked to shop like me? Don’t cha… (no not really)
The above title is giving mixed messages to you all — Yes, Athens is great for shopping — but we visited a few stores and we were done! I guess shopping isn’t for everyone. But for those of you that love shopping the main place to visit would be Ermou Street.
Next, we decided to visit: The Acropolis Museum
Which was filled with historical artefacts from the ancient times. It was fascinating and definitely worth the visit. Below the museum lay a phenomenal ancient civilisation which has been preserved very well. Archaeologists had used the remains of what was found to get an idea of what the different areas were used for.
Lastly, we decided to go for dinner before we called it a night. We decided to fill our bellies with indian food, so we visited Namaste — which is a walking distance from the museum. The food was delicious. Authentic? Yes, very much.
That was all for Athens. Next stop — Naxos! But hey that’s for another day.
Check out the helpful tips below:
2. Keep a hat, sunglasses, water and sunscreen with you at all times. ( if you didn’t guess so already — it gets kind of hot.)
3. I would recommend to book a taxi when arriving in Athens to take you to your accommodation. Taxis were a nightmare to find/contact. (Uber does work in Athens — so we used this. For the rest of your trip you can use public transport but the scheduled times are not always correct.)
4. There is a lot of walking involved when you want to visit the main attractions — I do recommend hiring a car. Unless you love to walk — then go ahead!
5. Greek Salad is amazing! Definitely try it out.
6. Baklava is popular in Greece so I would try this too.

Title: (Greece)Breathing in Ancient Echoes: A Journey Through Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Stepping off the metro and into the sun-drenched streets of Athens feels like opening a history book with the pages still whispering secrets. The air carries a warm, dry breeze laced with the scent of jasmine and grilled souvlaki. You turn a corner, and there it is: the Acropolis, standing guard over the city like an old friend greeting you after years apart.
No photograph truly captures the magic of the Acropolis. The way the Parthenon’s marbled columns glow rose-gold at dusk, or how the ancient stones hum with stories of philosophers and poets cannot be fully conveyed. Standing before this magnificent ancient structure, you can directly feel the wonder created by human creativity and perseverance. The Parthenon, standing firm for 2,500 years, is not merely a building but a symbol of human civilization that transcends time, offering a moment that stays in your heart.
Lose yourself in Plaka, Athens’ old neighborhood nestled at the Acropolis foot. Cobblestone lanes twist between pastel houses draped in bougainvillea, their wobbly pavement echoing every step you take. Every corner reveals a tiny kafenío spilling laughter and card games, a cat sunning itself on a doorstep, or an artisanal shop selling hand-painted ceramics. Stay close to a map, but feel free to get delightfully lost — each turn brings a new discovery.
In Monastiraki, the pulse of modern Athens beats alongside relics of every era. Street musicians serenade you near the flea market, where you can barter for vinyl records, vintage postcards, or a well-loved leather bag. Perch on the marble steps of Hadrian’s Library, feeling centuries-old stones under your fingertips while absorbing the vibrant energy of the streets.
Walking through Athens, you’ll discover the remarkable coexistence of modern and ancient. You might be strolling down a busy shopping street and suddenly encounter the ruins of a Roman-era amphitheater, or see columns of the 2,000-year-old ancient Agora standing right next to a modern coffee shop. Especially at sunset, the ancient ruins take on an almost living quality in the golden light that embraces the city.
With every step, the pavement beneath your feet seems to tell stories of the past. When you place your hand on an old stone wall, the warmth of the stone that has stood in that place for thousands of years creates a connection to the past through your palm. In Athens’ narrow alleyways, echoes sometimes reverberate, sounding almost like the whispers of ancient Greeks.
During my stay, I had the opportunity to visit the historic Piraeus Port on a business trip. As Athens’ main harbor for over 2,500 years, Piraeus offers a fascinating blend of maritime heritage and modern commerce. The bustling port, one of the largest in the Mediterranean, serves as Greece’s gateway to the world and a reminder of the nation’s enduring connection to the sea.
Walking along the waterfront, I watched massive cruise ships and cargo vessels docked alongside traditional fishing boats, their colorful hulls bobbing gently in the harbor. The scent of salt water mingled with the aroma of fresh seafood from tavernas lining the marina. Locals call this area “the heart of Greek shipping,” and it’s easy to see why — the energy here is different from central Athens, more cosmopolitan yet deeply rooted in maritime tradition.
After my meetings concluded, I explored the charming neighborhoods surrounding the port. Mikrolimano, with its horseshoe-shaped marina lined with seafood restaurants, offered stunning views where I watched fishermen mending their nets — a practice unchanged for centuries. In Pasalimani, elegant yachts suggested modern luxury while the nearby Archaeological Museum of Piraeus housed bronze statues recovered from the harbor’s depths, a testament to the port’s ancient significance.
The contrast between Piraeus and central Athens provided a fuller understanding of Greek identity — while the Acropolis represents Greece’s philosophical and cultural heritage, Piraeus embodies its seafaring spirit and commercial prowess that have sustained the nation throughout history.
On my last evening, I climbed Filopappou Hill just as the sun dipped below the Aegean horizon. The city sprawled beneath me — rust-red rooftops giving way to olive groves and distant azure. A street musician began to strum a haunting melody on his bouzouki, each note drifting through the twilight haze. I closed my eyes and let the music, the breeze, the ancient stones all blend together. In that instant, Athens wasn’t just a city of ruins; it was a living masterpiece, forever echoing with the laughter, dreams, and tears of everyone who ever called it home.
Athens isn’t about rushing from one selfie spot to the next. It’s about pausing to feel time fold onto itself — sharing sweet moments with locals at dawn, or watching street life unfold as light dances across the Acropolis. It’s a place that invites you to slow down, to breathe in history, and to savor both the grand and the minute details of daily life. When you leave, you carry a piece of that magic with you — a sense of grounded wonder and the comforting knowledge that some moments are eternal.
Safe travels, dear friend. May your heart be as full as mine was, and may Athens whisper its stories to you, too.

Title: AYS SPECIAL FROM ATHENS: One night in Exarcheia
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Daily news digests from the field, mainly for volunteers and refugees on the route, but also for journalists and other parties.

--
Listen
Share
The night I slept in Exarcheia was perhaps the turning point. My phone had been stolen, I had been caught at the airport six times, each time returned. I had even once dyed my hair blond and worn coloured lenses to appear more ‘European’ — it seems so ridiculous now.
In Exarcheia I was surrounded by hashashin, every nation, class and colour united in smoking weed, perhaps the best form of integration there is. It was cold, January 2017, and I was lucky, because it was the only night that I slept outside, unlike so many others.
I woke the next morning and came across another guy, also young like me, with green eyes, from Latakia. He had also slept on the street that night, but he looked so clean I could not believe he was sleeping rough. Seeing him, a guy more or less my age in the same situation, made me realise that I was not alone and that there were so many others like me trying to find a way to survive. After so many failures, sleeping on the street, losing so much money on wasted attempts to smuggle myself out of Greece, I began to understand that this was not the path for me.
That morning at 5am I went to Katekhaki (the Greek asylum service) and I also received my first fine for not paying my metro ticket. I took the fine, smiled, said, ‘efharisto poly’ (thank you very much in Greek) and kept on towards Katekhaki, throwing away the paper fine on the way.
This was the first fine of forty similar fines I would receive over the next two years, thanks to the incredible Greek system of fining people who clearly cannot pay their tickets. As a conscientious member of Greek society now, I pay my monthly transport, but those fines amounted to 1,200 euros. Of course, I never ever thought of that at the time.
Why did I go to Katekhaki? Because six months previously I had not attended my asylum interview — I had been far too focused on the idea of getting out of Greece to find my brother in Sweden. Besides, no one helped you in Greece, there was no accommodation, the only option for me was the squats. It did not feel like a place that offered stability, or a future. But now it seemed like I needed to change my plan, and so I went to Katekhaki and took my asylum card and the date for my interview, which was to be three months later. I returned to Exarcheia, managed to stay in a squat for three days and there met a group of Spanish people who were to offer me my first place to stay.
I began to plan. To me, the most important things was finding a job, and so I thought about what seemed to me to be a previous life, but one that had given me experiences that now I could draw upon.
In Damascus I had always been interested in technology — my brother had bribed me to do well in my exams with the promise of a laptop. He tricked me and gave the laptop to someone else, but then relented and bought me a newer one; he could see how much it meant to me I think.
I had studied technology in college for a while and then in Turkey I had managed to get some work at Vodaphone and had started to study coding. Whenever I needed to learn something I went to one place: youtube. Since Damascus, through Turkey and here in Greece, it is always the place I go to for learning new things, for inspiration and motivation.
I began to work, buying old phones and then mending and updating them and selling them on. I even made money online — just imagine 989 euros in my paypal, untouchable because there was no account for it to be transferred to. No one would accept my Greek Asylum white card as valid ID. I felt as if I was some sort of ethereal phantom, magically working online, but for no material benefit, except for the personal satisfaction of seeing the numbers on the screen and dreaming about what I would do with the money if it was physically in my possession.
Many things have happened since then, many of which we will all experience in our lives as refugees — the struggle to find a job, a home, a way to build a life. I realise I am not unique in this sense and this motivated me to try and help others in any way I can.
For a year I was lucky to be involved with a youth centre which gave me accommodation in exchange for volunteering there. I was always trying to think of new ways of making money within the narrow confines of Greek law where you cannot have a bank account unless you have a job. I helped people write CVs, gave courses on computer software, computer literacy, anything that I felt could be helpful for people like me looking for a future here.
I got a job, went to the training and got 99% on my coding exam, although to be honest it was my third retake. Then the company told me to go home, because the Greek system did not issue my AFM (tax number) fast enough. I tried everything, applying from different offices, with my company (which arranges all the necessary visas, AFMs and accommodation for their foreign workers), on my own, with a Greek person, anything! In the Exarcheia office where I originally registered I went with a Greek friend to check on the progress of my AFM which I had submitted a month previously. Eventually one clerk at the office whispered to my friend, ‘the person you need to talk to is in the toilet. Wait until he comes out and try and get him before he goes into the office.’ A couple of minutes later a large man with an even larger belly waddled out of the toilet, sideways. My friend tried to speak with him, but all she received was a dismissive gesture and a grunt. I had felt as if I had done everything, I had never given up, I had given so much of my time to learning and teaching others and had got this job, only to lose it because of a stupid bureaucracy.
It seems so funny now, looking back on it, because a month after that we returned and I managed to get my AFM, from the same toad-man. It had arrived maybe 10 days after I had visited the first time, but they had never bothered to call me.
In my despair my Greek friend put it in perspective. She too had suffered from this system, it was not specifically discrimination because I was a refugee, but rather an inefficient system that makes it impossible even for ordinary Greeks to do apparently simple things. Obtaining an AFM was my right as someone with residency, I had to be reminded that it would come eventually, that this was part of the journey, even if it felt as if Greece wanted me to personally suffer.
That was two months ago. Now, one AFM, a bank account and a 1,200 euro fine later, I am working as a software developer in a company that I dreamed of working for when I was in Syria. I could not have done this in Germany, France, Belgium or Holland, and so, although I spent so much time and money trying to escape this country, it turns out that this is one of the few places I can actually get the experience I need to continue my career.
What kept me going after that night in Exarcheia, before that in Turkey and Lesvos, was always having a plan and working out how to make it happen. In every situation, even if it is new, or potentially stressful and unfamiliar, I see opportunities to explore, make new contacts, learn something new. I truly believe that anyone can do what I have done, they just need focus, flexibility and a willingness to learn.
Be independent, do not follow the bad habits of others, and recognize that sometimes what works for others may not work for you. Make the most of your time and plan your day, week, month, even your year. Wherever you go there are opportunities to learn. Even in Athens, where I thought there was nothing, there are lots of different places that offer amazing training in languages and other skills.
Live in the present, but always think about the next step, and trust yourself. And use youtube!
(Written by one of many asylum seekers living in Athens)

Title: 3.4 Coming of Age in Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

See educational website firstphilosophers.com

--
Listen
Share
Socrates’ borough or deme was Alopece, located in the immediate suburbs of Athens to the southeast. In his constitutional reforms of 508 BC, Cleisthenes identified and distributed the hundred and thirty-nine demes among ten administrative “tribes,” replacing four mutually hostile kinship tribes. He designed the new mapping to break up family dynasties and regional interest groups, so as to force people from different regions of Attica to work together (ch. 2*). The new tribes were given important political functions; for instance, each tribe annually elected a general to serve as one of the commanders of the Athenian armed forces for that year.
Each tribe also contributed fifty members to the Council every year, and each deme received proportionate representation within their tribe’s cohort of members. Socrates’ Alopece, belonging to the tribe of Antiochis, sent ten citizens to the Council annually. Socrates himself would serve his deme as a Council representative in the year 407/6 BC (see ch. 19.4*).
After the deme system was configured based on the geographical location of boroughs in Attica, one’s membership in it became hereditary. Consequently, the son always belonged to the deme of his father, even if he moved to another location and resided within the geographical boundaries of a different deme. In reality, however, people tended to remain in the same villages for centuries, as was often the case in Europe before recent times. Socrates’ deme in the suburbs of Athens was convenient for a man who frequented the city streets, so it seems likely that he continued to live in his ancestral home in Alopece.
When he was eighteen, Socrates was presented to the demarch or borough chairman as a candidate for citizenship. Since the city of Athens kept no vital records, family members and close acquaintances had to swear that he had reached his eighteenth birthday. They also had to swear that his father was a citizen. In the year that Socrates came of age, Pericles pushed through a bill that required that not only a man’s father, but also his mother must be Athenian in order to qualify for citizenship. Socrates must have met the more stringent requirement, for his name was duly entered in the deme’s register of youth eligible for citizenship.
After the deme certified Socrates and his age-mates, they sent the records to the Council, which conducted a review (dokimasia) to verify that the information was correct. After this last step, Socrates would have become a citizen and, therefore, eligible to participate in civic processes, except those with an age requirement. For instance, to hold some offices a citizen must have attained the age of thirty. Public records henceforth would certify his age and thus eligibility for office — and for military service.
Hereafter he was officially known by his “demotic” name, Socrates of Alopece, a designation meant to identify citizens with their boroughs more closely than with their families, so as to counteract the powerful influence of family groups (indicated by the patronymic, for instance, Socrates son of Sophroniscus) on the politics of the city.
Socrates now became a cadet or ephebe (ephēbos), subject to military training and assignment. In the fourth century, cadets received rigorous military training, performed in parades and exhibitions and served in garrisons around the city for two years. Spartan cadets had received rigorous military and survival training from an early time. It is not clear, however, how much formal training Socrates received in his time as a cadet in mid-fifth-century Athens. He may have served on garrison and patrol duty in the city and the borders of Attica but with little formal training.
Fortunately for Socrates, around 451 when he’d come of age, Cimon was invited to return early to Athens from his exile and negotiated a five-year truce with the Spartans whom the great statesman favored (see ch. 2.5*). Cimon then led an expedition to raid Persian territory in Egypt and Cyprus while Socrates was still serving at home as a cadet. About the time Socrates finished his two-year training, Cimon died and a treaty was negotiated with the Persian Empire, initiating a period of relative peace for several years.
As Socrates completed his military training, after having finished his brief formal education some years before, he succeeded at the age of twenty to the estate of an independent citizen in 449. He came of age just at the time when a thoroughgoing democracy was being instituted in Athens for the first time. Socrates would continue his education by participating in a government that called on the talents of all its citizens to carry out its business. As we shall see, Socrates never aimed at political leadership, but he could not escape holding offices or, in what was considered an equally political responsibility, participating in the armed services of Athens. He would serve bravely in the army and would, by chance or by fate, hold the very highest office in the government — for one day.
In Socrates’ time, Athens led the Greek world in drawing on the talents of all its citizens to govern the city. As Pericles would say some eighteen years later in his famous funeral oration, speaking of the comprehensive Athenian experience with excusable pride, “In summary, I declare that our whole city is the school of Greece.”

Content:

Welcome to Athens — a city where ancient history intertwines with modern life. Come along with me as I take you on a journey through this fascinating metropolis and share my thoughts on the emotions it evokes along with my flight and Airbnb costs to my trip to Athens, Greece.
Walking along the streets of Athens, one can sense its bustling energy and the aromatic smells emanating from its eateries. Amidst the savory scents and laughter of locals, I felt a strong sense of camaraderie and liveliness. Athens is the kind of city where every street corner seems to hide a culinary treasure, and every meal is an invitation to savor life’s simple pleasures.
As I wandered through the city center, I couldn’t help but feel disoriented by the maze of narrow alleys and busy squares. However, amidst the chaos, I sensed a constant undercurrent of contagious energy and enthusiasm. Athens has its own unique rhythm that encourages exploration and embracing every moment. The city’s vibe is invigorating and creates a desire to keep moving forward.
While Athens is known for its bustling urban life, it also offers moments of tranquility in its parks and green spaces. Being surrounded by nature, I experienced a deep sense of inner peace and contemplation. These green oases serve as a retreat from the city’s fast-paced lifestyle and a reminder of the importance of maintaining a harmonious balance between urbanization and the natural world.
Visiting the Acropolis was an awe-inspiring journey through time and history. As I ascended the ancient steps and stood before the Parthenon, I was overwhelmed by a profound sense of reverence and wonder. The sheer magnitude of this iconic monument and its enduring beauty left an indelible mark on my soul. Athens is a city that envelops you in its vibrant and ever-evolving embrace. It’s a place where you can’t help but feel alive, where the blend of history and modernity creates an electrifying tapestry of emotions.
I flew from Riga, Latvia, and the roundtrip flight cost to Athens was $300, and my Airbnb lodging was $300 for 4 nights. This article (and its video counterpart) has been a quick and simple overview of my time in Athens. Still, I will be creating in-depth and analytical videos on my time in Greece to help you make a better purchasing decision when it comes to planning your next European adventure, along with tips and tricks on maximizing your experience in the city of Athens.
My in-depth video on Greece is coming soon, so please stay tuned by subscribing to my YouTube channel, and if you want a sample of what my in-depth videos look like, watch the video below where I give my recommendations on Slovenia after my 30 day stay.

Title: Athens’ Neighborhoods: Monastiraki
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

--
4
Listen
Share
Hello there! My name is Nick Iakovidis and I live in Athens, since I was a baby. I would like to take you on a trip to my home like no other will ever take you! I’ll share with you the secrets of my city, that gave birth to Socrates and Plato, and guide you through her streets. So, prepare yourselves for a great adventure and walk with me in one of the oldest cities in Europe!
We start with the most famous neighborhood of Athens, Monastiraki.
Monastiraki is the heart of Athens. You can reach it either by bus, train or metro, so it is pretty easy to get there without getting lost. Once out of the train station, you will reach the “Monastiraki Square” which you can see in the photo below. It is always filled with people, locals, street artists, and tourists from every place on earth.
See that church in the left corner? This is the church of “Panagia Pantanassa” (“Mother Mary — Queen of the World”). It may seem insignificant, but it is in fact one of the oldest churches in Athens, built around the 10th century AD! It was originally part of a much larger monastery, which covered the entire square. When the monastery was destroyed during the 19th century, the church became known as “little Monastery” or “Monastiraki” in Greek, thus giving its name to the neighborhood! Look closely at its corners and you will spot parts of ancient Greek pillars, which were used for its building, proving how old it really is!
While the train station is a common meeting point with our friends, family, or dates, the locals don’t like spending much time here. There are plenty of routes to choose from and wander into the streets! Also, I would like to advise you not to fall into temptation and sit in one of the many roof gardens like “360", “MS Roof Garden”, “Anglais”, and “Citizen”, neither have souvlaki at the restaurants found in Mitropoleos street, near the square! These places are tourist traps and overcharge everything.
Instead, take the Ifaistou street and go on a trip to the Flea Market of Athens, also known as “Yusurum”. Originally created by Jewish immigrants in 1863, this market is where you can find anything you ever wanted. Vinyls and CDs at “Zacharias”, rock, punk, and heavy metal accessories at “Full Moon”, leather sandals and silly t-shirts, lots of hippie clothes, cannabis products, and souvenirs. Whether you want to buy a mini-Parthenon or a cool-looking set of leather boots, this place will get you covered.
But if you want to dig really deep while in there, and find valuable treasures, unlike anything else, you need to go to “Abyssinia Square”, located at the end of Ifaistou. Named after the Africans from Ethiopia, who settled there during the Ottoman occupation, it is where numerous antique shops are located. Here you will find comic books, posters, memorabilia, collectibles, rings, and telephones, all coming from decades ago! Here, laying on wooden tables in front view you may find things like broken clocks, old musical instruments, even valuable coins from 100 years ago! It is the perfect place to find a unique gift to take back!
Extra tip: every Sunday there is a bazaar of antiques here, so don’t miss it!
Are you tired from your trip and need a drink?
Then spend your time in one of the many bars, hiding around the Flea Market! Unlike those found in the central square, here you will have a great time, enjoying your drink like a true Athenian!
Need a place where you can marvel at the Parthenon while drinking your favorite cocktail or coffee? Then, allow me to introduce you to “Couleur Locale”, or as it is known here, “one of the most beautiful terraces of the city”:
Beautiful, isn’t it? “Locale” opened in 2014 and since then, it has become a favorite place for university students to party. Be sure to check out its signature cocktails like “Gin Basil Smash”, “The Surfer” and “Sleep no More”, made with gin and unique Greek flavors, like mastic, basil, and lemon. So, take your friends and go have the party of your lives under the attic night sky!
Perhaps you prefer a more quiet approach! Like a small green garden inside an old neoclassical house! Well, then say no more, and knock on the wooden door of the building right next to “Locale”. Don’t be afraid, it is not abandoned! It is just camouflage!
This is “Taff: the Art Foundation”:
Yes, this is real. Yes, it is in Monastiraki, hidden in plain sight.
TAF opened its doors to the public in May 2009 and since then it remains one of the most active and creative organizations in the city. It hosts a variety of cultural events, like concerts, galleries, and art exhibitions, all made by local artists. If you seek an artistic, bohemian paradise, right in the heart of Athens, you’ve found it!
Still, want more?
Then, take out your phone and prepare to update your Instagram! It’s time to visit the most instagramable cafe in Monastiraki!
This is “Ellyz Cafe”
“Ellyz” resembles more a pink paradise, straight out from a Disney movie, rather than an actual place. Once inside, you will find yourself enjoying your brunch on a cozy couch, while hundreds of flowers are hanging over your head. Its menu could make even Willy Wonka himself green from envy! Try chocolate pink hearts, creamy lemon tarts with flowers, and tasty rose cheesecake, which will melt in your mouth! Coffee lovers don’t forget to try a pink cappucino or a fredo latte with a large pink donut on top!
Extra tip: make sure you go to Ellyz with a friend who knows to take great photos!
Of course, Monastiraki is a multicultural neighborhood. Besides the above cafes and bars, you will find exotic places to travel you in faraway lands. Don’t miss to check out “James Joyce Irish Pub” (which is a personal favorite) and enjoy a Guinness with juicy chicken wings, while watching sports on one of the many tv screens. Or how about a visit to exotic Cuba? Seek the “Buena Vista Social Bar” and have a Latin party on its vintage decorated terrace!
It is time to share with you one final secret. Go to the end of Adrianou Street and start walking towards the centrer. In front of you, you will see one of my favorite spots in Monastiraki. On your right lies the ancient Agora of Athens, covered in a green dress of trees and bushes. You might spot the temple of Ifaistos and the Stoa of Attalos, graciously standing above all the others. Perhaps you might hear the sound of trains arriving at the station.
On your left there are the numerous cafes and restaurants of Adrianou, always filled with people. You will see elders reading their newspapers while drinking ouzo, tourists laughing and carrying their luggage, children loudly playing on the street next to people, who are selling antiques. A young couple might pass next to you, enjoying ice cream while holding hands, or a company of college students, eager to plan their night party at one of the bars mentioned above. You will hear Greek, Russian, and English, all mixed together in multicultural harmony. Perhaps, if you are lucky enough, you will feel the light summer breeze of Athens cooling your face, as the sun makes its way down to the West.
This is Athens. This is Monastiraki!
A Crossroads of Civilizations!

Title: Athens, Greece Street Art Map And Inner City Suburb Guide
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Splatrs is dedicated to bringing street art to those who love it with the best content on where to find street art around Australia (and sometimes abroad), as well as who you need to know and what is happening in the street art scene across the country.

--
Listen
Share
Athens, Greece, the birthplace of democracy, the freddo espresso, and saganaki cheese (all that is good in this world), is also said to be the motherland of graffiti.
The origin of the word graffiti is derived from Greek “graphein,” meaning “to write,” “draw,” or “scratch.” But moreover, the practice, as we know it today; to take to the streets to paint or tag, allegedly started with a Greek national in the US whose practice caught on and then made its way back to the homeland.
The accuracy of this tale, I wasn’t able to validate, but it makes for a good story, and with Athens density of street art — floor to ceiling, wall to wall — you feel that this must be the source.
In 2017, I had the pleasure of calling this ancient city home; soaking in the sunshine, the food and, of course, the art! When it comes to documenting street art in the Greek capital, the greatest challenge is that there is simply too much to accurately map.
One street in Athens can house more great art than an entire city elsewhere. So, I have tried my hardest to do it justice. I have broken my map into the main artistic regions of Athens and pinned spots where there is a large density of art, or significant murals to check out.
Use the map as a guide, but keep your eyes peeled from place to place, there is gold everywhere on the streets of Athens.
When first arriving in Athens, I was lucky enough to call this area home. There is a young modern crowd here with oodles of bars, restaurants, and cafes to be found. And, on basically every street, you will find painted walls.
Artists featured: STMTS, exitonwall, Achilles, INO, and Dreky the Pirate. Follow them!
Psyri is possibly the hippest neighbourhood in Athens. Again, bars, restaurants, and cafes a-plenty and an even richer density of street art. There is one street — Sarri — where you can find epic pieces from almost every prominent artist in Athens.
Artist featured: Yiakou, Achilles, David Selor, Vasmou, and Hambas.
I fucking love Exarcheia. If you Google it, you will see lots of talk about anarchy and riots. That’s not why I love it, of course, but I love the vibe of people who are passionate about fighting against the system if it is not serving the people. As soon as you enter Exarcheia, you’re destined to see political graffiti, Antifa symbols, and expressions of rage, as well as an array of murals, posters, and paint.
Artists featured: Wild Drawing, Olga Mavrommati, MOTA, and STMTS.

Title: Greece, Checked! Exploring Athens, Santorini, and Crete
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
“It takes a lifetime to discover Greece, but it only takes an instant to fall in love with her.” — Henry Miller
Starting my unforgettable journey through Greece, I’m excited to finally check it off my bucket list while diving into its stunning beauty and fascinating history.
Thanks to my travel agent’s help, who carefully put together a package including visits to Athens, Santorini, and Crete, along with accommodations and airport transfers, all I needed to do was book a flight.
I started my journey in Athens, a city that effortlessly blends ancient history with modern culture. As I walked through the streets of Plaka, I was captivated by the combination of ancient ruins and bustling cafes, which revealed the city’s rich history and culture at every corner.
During my stay in Athens, I visited the Parthenon atop the Acropolis, one of the most iconic landmarks in the world. Standing beneath the ancient temple, I was awestruck by the sheer scale of its history and significance. The Parthenon’s towering columns and intricate carvings are a true testament to the brilliance and craftsmanship of the ancient Greeks.
To fully immerse myself in Athenian life, I chose to stay in the heart of downtown Athens. This allowed me to walk everywhere, making it easy to explore landmarks such as Syntagma Square, Monastiraki Flea Market, and the vibrant neighborhoods of Psiri and Exarchia. Being centrally located made me feel part of the city’s pulse, and I enjoyed soaking up the vibrant atmosphere that surrounded me.
“I want to have an ‘Eat, Pray, Love’ experience where I drop off the face of the planet and move to Greece.” — Jennifer Hyman
My journey then led me to Santorini, a destination that had long captured my imagination. As the ferry approached the island, I was greeted by a breathtaking panorama of white-washed buildings clinging to cliffs, adorned with blue-domed churches. The striking contrast between the pristine whitewashed architecture and the deep azure of the Aegean Sea was truly mesmerizing, creating a scene straight out of a postcard.
Exploring Enchanting Villages:
Stepping onto Santorini’s shores felt like entering a dream. I embarked on a journey to explore its enchanting villages, starting with the iconic Oia. Its narrow cobblestone streets led me on a whimsical journey, lined with charming cafes, boutique shops, and art galleries tucked away in every nook and cranny. The village’s crowning glory, however, was its unparalleled sunset views. Joining fellow travelers atop the cliffs of Oia, I witnessed nature’s masterpiece unfold as the sun dipped below the horizon, painting the sky in hues of gold and crimson.
Continuing my exploration, I ventured to Fira, Santorini’s bustling capital perched atop the caldera cliffs. Here, I found a vibrant atmosphere pulsating through its labyrinthine streets. From chic boutiques to traditional tavernas, Fira offered a delightful blend of modernity and tradition. And no visit to Fira would be complete without a stroll along the cliffside promenade, where panoramic views of the caldera stretched out before me, offering a glimpse into the island’s volcanic past.
Embracing the Island’s Natural Beauty:
Santorini’s allure extends beyond its picturesque villages, beckoning travelers to immerse themselves in its natural wonders. I embarked on a trek along the caldera rim, traversing rugged terrain and ancient pathways carved into the cliffs. With each step, I was rewarded with sweeping vistas of the Aegean Sea and the neighboring islands, a reminder of the island’s volcanic origins.
Moreover, Santorini’s beaches are not to be missed. From the black sands of Perissa and Kamari to the red sands of Red Beach, each shoreline offered its own unique charm. I spent my days lounging on the sun-drenched shores, taking refreshing dips in the crystalline waters, and soaking in the Mediterranean sun.
A Word of Advice: Bring Comfortable Walking Shoes:
As I navigated Santorini’s enchanting landscapes, one thing became abundantly clear: comfortable walking shoes are an absolute must. Whether exploring the winding streets of its villages or trekking along the rugged coastline, sturdy footwear ensured that I could fully enjoy all that Santorini had to offer without any discomfort.
Finally, I set sail for Crete, the largest of the Greek islands, and a place of myth and legend. Exploring the Palace of Knossos, I felt like I was walking in the footsteps of ancient kings and heroes, with the echoes of the past reverberating through the labyrinthine ruins. I also took the time to unwind on Crete’s beautiful beaches with their crystal-clear waters and golden sands, which offered the perfect respite after days filled with exploration and discovery.
In conclusion, my Greek odyssey exceeded my wildest expectations, offering a tapestry of experiences that will remain in my memory for years to come. I am grateful for the opportunity to have experienced Greece’s natural beauty, rich history, and vibrant culture. I know that Greece will always hold a special place in my heart, beckoning me back to its shores time and time again.
“There are two kinds of people. Greeks, and everyone else who wish they were Greek.” — My big fat Greek wedding
--
--
Alka Mehta is a published writer for The Motley Fool and NerdWallet, with degrees in finance and computer science.

In May 2023, my family and I embarked on a memorable trip to Greece.
We had the incredible opportunity to explore the picturesque islands of Santorini and Mykonos. We saved the jewel of our adventure, Athens, for last.
There are direct flights from Athens to the United States, so we were able to spend a few nights in this historic city before returning to the US.

Entry 150. Athens, GreeceThursday, April 20
After some seriously rocky adventures on Kefalonia, I was kind of looking forward to heading back to big-city civilisation. The Greek islands have great potential but they can be quite hard work, especially so if you visit outside of high season.
To be honest I felt the least welcome of any place on my travels whilst being in these islands because of grumpy locals, over-priced food and accommodation, difficulty in getting places and the slapstick level of service.
Maybe it’s a Greek thing, maybe it’s just that they’re sick of tourists because we’ve been coming here for thousands of years. Whatever. All that has resulted in collective fatigue which means I’m in less than an optimum condition to write this entry about Athens, which needs to cover many weird, wonderful and important things. I hope I do it justice, so please bear with me.

Title: 10 reasons to live in Athens, Greece
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
People are always surprised when I say that I live in Greece. To tell the truth I have never imagined that I was going to live here… and neither when I initially came to spend 3 months was I planning to stay for that long. Three years and a half have passed and here I am. Before getting to know Athens and Greece I didn’t have an image in my mind of what I was going to find here, and in different ways and little by little the city and the country have conquered me. Today I can say much more than 10 reasons to live here, but I will just give you a taste.
1-Weather
Greece is in fact a blessed country for the weather that it has. The only thing that I would change would be to add some humidity in the air, since sometimes it is so dry that it causes irritations. Other than that, the seasons are very well defined and never reach extremes. Of course in the North it is more cold during the winter, and in mountainous areas. In Athens, the winter hardly has temperatures below zero, normally it is between 10 and 20 degrees until April, May, and then it starts to rise. It snows mostly three times during the winter, and normally it does not accumulate on the ground. During summer, the temperature can reach more than 35 degrees, especially in July and August. My favorite seasons are spring and fall, both with pleasant temperatures, although during fall it rains a bit more. Still, in general it rains quite little in Athens (in the summer we spend three months with the sun shining intensively).
2-Islands
Who has never dreamed of visiting the famous Greek islands? Or spending the honeymoon around here? As a matter of fact, the islands are one of the most incredible reasons to live in this country. And Athens is in advantage because it has the biggest ports and it is quite close from some of these paradises. It is very curious to talk about trips with Greeks, although many of them have never visited some of their neighbor countries, every summer they go to two or three different islands and they love to talk about what each one has that is special, and to compare them. In three years, I could already know some of these enchanting places, and each year choosing becomes more difficult, as the more you listen about the places, the more you want to visit them.
3-Safety
Ok, Greece is no Denmark, and organization is not Greek’s favorite word, neither it is law. But one thing that is very respected around here, is the space and freedom of each individual. Theft is common, as also in every other corner in Europe, but here we can walk the streets at dawn without worrying if we will manage to come back home safely. Athens, being a big city and with more than three million inhabitants, might not be the best example in safety of the country, nevertheless it is rare to hear about murders or general violence against people in the streets, and even the protests during the crisis are somehow pacific.
4-Food
Unmissable! Just with this word you can have an idea of the Greek cuisine. In the last three years I have gained some kilos (and I don’t complain because I was skinny before), something that in 25 years of life I have never achieved, regardless the place I was living. Yes, the food is delicious, and there is great variety. In Athens, besides thousands of taverns, you can find Mexican restaurants, Arabic, Japanese, Chinese, Italian, Russian and so on. From Greek food, features the olive oil, the olives, feta cheese and the famous souvlaki (the Greek acarajé, as I usually compare, with this delicious dish from Bahia).
5-Nightlife
Again the weather here helps a lot. There is nothing like a bad winter that makes the Greeks stay at home instead of enjoying the night. Either for dinner (normally after 9pm) or drinks at some bar, or a club, the Greek nightlife is very exciting. Athens has different neighborhoods that concentrate these clubs for different tastes, and the best thing is that it costs nothing to enter these parties. You only pay what you drink. For the typical Greek clubs, the parties called buzukia, you pay a more expensive entrance, but it includes food and drinks. And the night never ends, you only come back before 3am if you want to.
6-People similar to Brazilians
Greeks are very different from the typical European from the North. Besides being Mediterranean, they have mixed up with Turkish, and this mix has given origin to a joyful and lively people. They love gathering to eat and talk, spending hours sitting at the table after a meal. Besides that, normally they are friendly with strangers, maybe in Athens a bit less since it is a big city. They are also passionate about music and arts in general. The only thing that I miss about the joyful Greek life style is the dance. They don’t do it like Brazilians. Although they get excited with the typical Greek dance, they are usually not moving so much at parties and clubs.
7-Peaceful life
Even though Athens is the capital of the country, it has this air of a small town. Despite having great movement and quite a hectic nightlife, busier than other European capitals, you can easily find quiet neighborhoods in the suburban areas, like small villages. Having an older population contributes a lot to that.
8-Prices and courtesies
Greece is not a cheap country, but comparing to others in Europe the cost of life is interesting. You can buy a bottle of water with less than 50 cents of Euro. And to have a nice meal here can cost between 5 and 10 euros. Besides, it is very common at restaurants to offer free water and sometimes free dessert. Apartment rentals are also cheap comparing to capitals like Paris, and even cities in Brazil, like São Paulo and Rio, and, in general, there are not big social differences. I know, for instance, people working as maid at hotels and living in a very good apartment in a noble area of the city.
9-Cafes
Athens has cafes in every corner of the city. And it is a Greek habit to go out to have coffee and chill at any moment of the day. Their happy hour is much more connected to coffee than to beer as in Brazil. OK, to me, since I am not a big fan of coffee this could be a disadvantage somehow, but most Brazilians would certainly enjoy this routine a lot.
10-Culture/History
Who does not know that Greece is one of the richest countries historically and culturally speaking and that a lot of what we inherited as western civilization come from here? Even words from Portuguese have origin in the Greek language, and they are a lot! It is amazing to go around Athens and to visit the ruins and monuments, and at any place that you go to visit in the country, you will certainly find a piece of this history.
*The text originally published in Portuguese can be found at: http://www.brasileiraspelomundo.com/grecia-10-razoes-para-viver-em-atenas-201727512

Here’s what you need to know if you’re thinking about taking on a real bucket-list marathon race and running the original, Athens Authentic Marathon!
A year later than initially planned, I got to run the 38th Athens Authentic Marathon. It’s known as the ‘Authentic Marathon’ as it follows the fabled route of Greek messenger Philippides, who ran to the town of Marathon and back to Athens to bring news of a Greek battle victory against Persia, dying after he’d relayed the news.
Gladly, I only ran this route one-way and I’m still alive to tell the tale, so if you’re thinking about running the Athens Authentic Marathon in the future, here’s what you can expect.
You’ll discover to expect at the expo, how the race unfolds on the day and an overview my own race strategy that brought me a new personal best and my first ever time qualifier result.
But first, let’s get started by looking at the pre-race organisation.
The first thing you’ll notice when you start to check-out the information online about the Athens Authentic Marathon is that the quality is rather poor.
The Athens Authentic Marathon website is dated and doesn’t work well on mobile. The content is also usually out of date, with information about previous runnings easily available but little to nothing about the upcoming event. It also doesn’t help that there are several other events that share the same website, so you’ll frequently find information about the half marathon, 10k and 5k races taking place around the same time as the marathon.
It’s rather frustrating.
The social media accounts aren’t much better. They’re basically dormant until a few weeks before the race, then burst into action covering all the ribbon-cutting, permit-acquiring activities runners really couldn’t care less about. Like the website, the socials were also extremely poor.
But, on the day of the Athens Authentic Marathon itself, the organisation was perfect.
I took one of the coaches to Marathon departing from Syntagma and had zero problems. There must’ve been 20–30 coaches lined up, and when the front coach was full (or full-ish) it pulled away.
After arriving at the starting point in Marathon, it was a short walk to the stadium and a 90-minute wait until the race got underway. So as on-the-day organisation goes, there was zero anxiety. It’s just a shame that level of organisation and reassurance wasn’t present on the website and socials in the build up to the race.
This was the first Athens Authentic Marathon since COVID-19 struck so unsurprisingly there were changes from previous runnings and additional protocols in place.
At the time of running, Greece was experiencing a surge in COVID-19 case numbers so everywhere you went shops and restaurants were very hot on mask-wearing and COVID-19 certificates to prove you’re either fully vaccinated, recovered from COVID-19 or have a recent negative COVID-19 test (even to the extent of having to show a vaccine certificate and wear a mask to enter a cheap souvenir store!). At the marathon expo, you had to show your vaccine status (or other acceptable status) to enter, and you had to wear a mask while you were inside.
Masks had to be worn on the coach from Athens to Marathon on the day of the race, and the coaches left sufficient room for social distancing by departing when they were probably around 60% full.
Marathon Stadium is all open air, so there was no need to wear masks while you were there, and this year there was a staggered start over two ‘races’ and eight waves, which gave space between blocks of runners. That said, the start wave had zero social distancing and even with the best attempts of the marshals, not everyone maintained a safe distance while waiting for the starting pistol…
And speaking of waves, each wave set off about three minutes after the previous one, so as I was in Wave 3, I was over the start line by about 09:06.
I was running with a friend who was much faster than me and he was placed in Wave 1. There was a lot of very strict communication about not being able to change waves, but we managed to get it sorted at the expo so he could start with me in Wave 3. Apparently, your timing chip was calibrated to activate according to your wave start time, so, if you started in a different wave, your time wouldn’t be recorded.
Overall, the COVID-19 arrangements felt safe and proportionate and in line with what everyone else was doing in Greece at the time.
The Athens Marathon expo — known as the Ergo Marathon Expo — is located at the Faliro Indoor Hall & Exhibition Centre (previously known at the Taekwondo Centre). It’s south of the city on the coast and makes for a nice day out to watch the sailing after you’ve collected your bib.
As the expo was a straight line walk from our apartment, we decided to take an easy stroll to the exhibition centre, which was about 4km away and all downhill. It was a lovely walk and excellent weather, but when we saw the Faliro Indoor Hall & Exhibition Centre we literally ran out of road — several busy motorways and lots of excavation sat between us and the expo hall with no obvious way of crossing them.
We ran into a group of Greek guys who were also on their way there, but even they didn’t know which way to go! After about a kilometre detour, we eventually ended up on the correct side of the motorways and got into the expo after showing our vaccine certificates.
Picking up our race packs was quick and easy, you just had to show your confirmation email and photographic ID. We also managed to sort running in the same wave together, which was also very easy. My friend had the back of his bib signed and stamped to show he’d been approved to run in a different wave, while his registration was updated as well so that his timing chip would work in Wave 3.
The expo offerings were pretty good, with two floors of stalls and very well attended, even if the official marathon stall was pretty small (about 30sq m) and running low on stocks of small and medium merchandise.
We spent around 45 minutes at the expo, which was enough, then grabbed some lunch before heading back into the City Centre.
On race day, it was a fairly early start as the coaches to Marathon began leaving from various points throughout Athens at 05:30, with the last coach scheduled to depart around 06:15. There were dozens of coaches lined up near Syntagma where we boarded our coach, so it was very quick and easy to get on the transport.
And even though it was before sunrise on a Sunday, the Greek parliament guards were still doing their routines, and with only a handful of runners around it was an excellent opportunity to take photos or a short video!
On the coach, there was an information tape playing, explaining in Greek and English what to expect, as well as giving a little history behind the race. So by the time you reached Marathon about 45 minute later, you’re fully briefed and raring to go.
Marathon Stadium is the ‘start village’ for the race and is virtually all outdoors. There is a small indoor area at the back, but unless you were queuing for toilets you were ‘strongly advised’ to go outside (COVID, and everything…).
The stadium itself is a bit run down but there was plenty of room, and if you arrived early enough, you could get a cheeky Strava Segment in round the running track.
There were dozens of toilets and portaloos everywhere round the stadium, so you never had to queue long for the toilet (although some did… while others decided to go al fresco…). Free water and bananas were available so you could keep fluid and carb levels topped up.
The Olympic Flame is also at Marathon Stadium, and if you time it right you can go and hold the torch. Unfortunately, we were in our start pen by then so could only look on in envy.
Running the Athens Marathon requires planning for three very different sections, which I’ll refer to as the First Half, the Hill and the End Bit. While it frustrated me a lot planning my race strategy, as conventional wisdom is to run even or negative splits that just aren’t feasible on this course, it made for a very exciting race in the end.
And don’t read the map left-to-right like a lot of people mistakenly do — the route starts in the east and heads south then west into Athens, not the other way round!
The Athens Authentic Marathon has one of the highest elevation gains of any major international marathon, with a total of 332m (1,089ft) elevation gain across its 26.2 miles. Most of that elevation gain comes in a brutal 8-mile section that begins about halfway through the race and continues relentlessly until you pass kilometre marker 31 (about 19.5 miles in).
But the good news is that the rest of the race — the End Bit — is virtually all downhill, including one of the most charitable last 800m I’ve ever experienced at a race.
After the 5km mark there are water stations every 2.5km in line with international race standards, as well as frequent toilet stops and aid stations. So from a provisions perspective, it was extremely well appointed.
The first half of the Athens Authentic Marathon is pretty much flat. There are a couple of minor climbs, but these only last for a few hundred metres, so they can be safely taken at a constant pace.
After leaving Marathon Stadium the route is fairly straight, save for a dog-legged detour about 5km around the Marathon Tomb. On the wide-open road — made less congested by the staggered start waves — it was easy to find a comfortable pace and lock it in, following the blue racing line as closely as I could.
I even made a friend during this section, getting to chat to a Greek guy who was aiming for a similar finish time to me. So it was nice to be able to chat while grinding down the miles.
The support through this section is sporadic as the setting is quite rural, but when you run through a village there’s a massive surge in energy as the whole place seemed to be out supporting the runners. There were also children and ladies handing out olive twigs for luck, so I took a small one and stuffed it into my pocket. It was a unique souvenir for a finish line selfie!
About halfway, The Hill starts. I clocked it starting at 13.5 miles, and it went on for the next 8 miles with only a couple of short sections flattening out a little.
I was nervous about The Hill, even though I’d trained on a lot of hills back home and had simulated an 8-mile, 180m (580ft) elevation gain run a few weeks earlier. But I’d never attempted something like this after running a fairly pacy (for me!) half marathon beforehand.
My coach had recommended I do ‘something’ while running up the hill to take my mind off it. ‘Counting to four’ and ‘pretending to click pens with my thumbs’ were two techniques he suggested had been shown to take the mind off pain, so I planned to give them a go. The ‘count to four’ suggestion fit well with a breathing technique Jack Daniels, PhD recommends of using two strides to breathe out and a two strides to breathe in.
So I applied the ‘count to four’ and breathing technique for a good part of The Hill, but also took the opportunity to learn a bit of Greek from my Greek running friend. I learned how to say ‘thank you’ (‘Efharisto’ or Ευχαριστώ) and tried it out on the crowds, with him correcting my terrible pronunciation so I could try again later.
I think I got it in the end!
For all the worry I had about The Hill beforehand, it turned out to be absolutely manageable. My highest elevation gain over one mile was 138ft (42m), but most miles had an elevation gain of just 50–60ft (15–18m).
My race strategy worked a treat through this section and I was actually ahead of schedule by the time The Hill ended at kilometre marker 31… but not before the most brutal segment, where you run down — and then back up — a motorway fly-under, which was a killer. But once you’re over the top, the road bends to the left and you can see it’s all downhill from now on.
At this point in the race, more than 20 miles in and knowing the hardest part was probably over, it was a bizarre feeling. But I’d had some sage advice from people who’d ran the Athens Authentic Marathon before, who told me:
Don’t put your foot down too quickly after the top of The Hill as many people who do this end up collapsing
After running uphill for so many miles, the sudden change in terrain puts a strain on different muscle groups as you head downhill, and for many people their knees just give way, and they collapse. After running so closely to my race plan up until this point, the last thing I wanted was to put my foot down too hard and fall over, so I gave it half a mile or so before increasing my pace.
The End Bit isn’t all downhill, there are flat sections and a sneaky incline just before the final turn, but the support really ramps up to cheer you on. Entering Athens was an incredible buzz, with massive support either side of the course and a lot more cheer stations as well.
And after that last turn, it’s another downhill segment straight into the Panathenaic Stadium and finish line. This must be one of the most charitable ends to any race I’ve ever ran as you can give it all you’ve got left without worrying about making it up another hill or round a tight bend.
It was fantastic!
And ending in the Panathenaic Stadium — location of the first Modern Olympic Games in 1896 — really is something to behold. And you’ll want your best smile/ grimace on as you enter the stadium as the finish straight is littered with photographers snapping away at your sprint finish.
Then it’s time to grab your medal — the 38th running has a fabulous double-sided medallion with Philippides on one side and the Panathenaic Stadium track on the other.
I can honestly say this race is up there with the very best, a cracking course and an exceptional finish line. I’d do it again without hesitation!
Coming back to my race strategy, I’d pondered it for months as The Hill means you must adapt your race plan from what would be considered ‘best practice’. Running even splits isn’t possible on this course as the elevation changes so vastly, while keeping your powder dry for later in the race seems like a waste considering the first half is flat as a pancake and you’ve got the benefit of miles of downhill segments at the end to sweep you through to the finish line.
My target was a Chicago Marathon time qualifier time, so I needed to come in sub-3:20.
I’d also ran a PB in a virtual marathon the previous year in 3:18, so my goals for Athens were to nail a Chicago Marathon time qualifier spot and, if possible, chalk up a new personal best. This meant my goal pace was about 7:34 mins/ mile over the marathon distance, but even splits were out of the question due to the 180m (560ft) of elevation on the 8-mile stretch of The Hill.
I didn’t know how much The Hill was going to take out of me, so I set a pace range for the last 5–6 miles, knowing if I was in that ballpark I’d hit my goal.
My race strategy looked like this:
· First Half: 7:00 mins/ mile
· The Hill: 7:30 to 7:45 mins/ mile
· The End Bit: whatever I had left in the tank, but as close to 7:00 mins/ mile as I could manage
This left quite a bit of wiggle room at the end as I knew I’d tire but didn’t know by how much.
The First Half went 100% to plan, I maintained a steady 7:00 mins/ mile throughout (even having to pull back my pacer friend at times to stop me from running too fast!) and hit The Hill bang on target.
To my utter amazement, The Hill turned out to be a lot kinder than I’d anticipated. I managed to hold a 7:20 mins/ mile pace for large portions of it, slowing only to 7:45 mins/ mile for the really steep sections, which were thankfully few and far between.
And for the End Bit, I managed to pull back to 7:00 mins/ mile for a couple of miles before fatigue set in and I dropped back to 7:30 mins/ mile. But hitting that last 800m downhill home stretch I accelerated to 6:45 mins/ mile to cross the finish line, which shows you just how charitable that last segment is!
I finished in a time of 3:08:31, way ahead of both my goals. My time was also a Boston Qualifier time and would’ve got me into the 2022 running but unfortunately the Athens Authentic Marathon was 48 hours after the close of the Boston Marathon qualifying period.
But there’s always another chance to improve my time and get that BQ next year!
I can honestly say this was one of the best races I’ve ever experienced. The course was incredible, gave you lots to think about and was an energising mix of quieter segments followed by raucous support as you ran through the towns and villages — and then Athens itself.
If this race is on your bucket list, I’d highly recommend signing up and living your dream.
You won’t be disappointed!
If you’ve liked this race report, you can check out my other reports on Running the New York Marathon and Running the Great North Run.
Follow me on Instagram and share your own running journey with me.
