Listen
Share
Introduction
The 2000’s have been to Greece what the 60’s were to Northwestern Europe. An era defined by strong growth & debt-financed consumption. Unsustainable. Doom to fail. We’ve all read that Greece suffered a huge blow from the economic crisis. But did know that Athens is also very much alive? With very little money, art and culture flourished in the capital. So much so that it attracted many artists from around the world, spawning a creative exodus in the country.
This dynamic was noticed by the artistic community and brought forth in the fourteenth edition of one of the world’s most ambitious contemporary art exhibitions: documenta. In 2017, for the first time in its history, the German quinquennial was split between Germany and Greece, between Kasse,l its main location, and Athens.
Over the course of 4 months, from exhibitions and events to encounters and friendships, we have permeated Athens’ artistic ecosystem to see this shift in dynamics and surge of creative energy. How to explain this dynamic? By understanding its causes.
From the social, political, economical, cultural and historical standpoints, this immersion has given us a certain picture of ​​Greece’s soul and identity. This creative effervescence cannot be understood without understanding Greece first.
Athens Artlife is a journey into the Greek soul of 2017 through its artistic scene.
Genesis /// Meeting a superstar
A chance, an evening, an encounter, a woman. Ingeborg Beugel. Dutch journalist, war reporter, a cigarette in one hand, glass of wine in the other, we discuss. A family friend, she tells us about Greece, the new life of Athens, the art scene, the influx of international artists, documenta.
She has some perspective. She’s been living in Greece for 30 years. She was married to the right-hand man of singer, actress and former Greek minister of culture Melina Mercouri. She knows the Athenian art scene. She is fascinating, we love her, she invites us to Athens to see for ourselves.
Fascinated by the thought that “less money means more art” we start our research. The New York Times, the BBC, the Guardian, le Monde, they all write about Athens and its new dynamics in arts and culture at large. Searching for a documentary on the subject, we cannot find one. The idea of ​making our own emerges. After 2 months of research, prep and the launch of the non-profit Odyssée Production, we fly to Athens in April 2017.
http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20170509-can-athens-become-europes-new-arts-capital
Synopsis & Intention
Life, energy, wisdom and beauty can arise from the worst moment of crisis, doubt and hardship. Athens Artlife is a journey into the contemporary Greek soul through its artistic scene in Spring and Summer of 2017.
Athens Artlife aims at exposing the links between the thriving local art scene and the unshakeable Greek identity through and in spite of national challenges.
Athens Artlife aims at showcasing and promoting the city’s artistic soul and new dynamics.
Athens Artlife wishes to support Greek artists by giving them visibility.
The Team
Arthur De Poortere
Director, scriptwriter, journalist/interviewer, 1st camera, copy-writer & AD for communication, and directed the editing of the trailer.
He dreams of being creative, he is passionate about everything defined as artistic or cultural, except “performances” (he is not sufficiently educated to grasp their depth) and Greek Rebetiko (quite sadly).
https://www.linkedin.com/in/arthurdepoortere/
Alexandre Meeùs
Director, scriptwriter, journalist/interviewer, researcher/interview preparation, 1st camera assistant, academic editor.
He is passionate about journalism, politics and contemporary history. He wants to work in the cultural field at European and international level (UN, EU, NGO…). He’s fascinated by Greece and the Mediterranée.
https://www.linkedin.com/in/alexandre-meeùs-23a5b63a/
blog : https://medium.com/@Odysseeprod
Project Guides
Ingeborg Beugel — Journalistic Guide
Crazy superstar Dutch journalist & documentarist, Inge has been supervising our project. She actively helped in setting up the frame of our research as well as developing an angle.
Her wikipedia page: https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ingeborg_Beugel
Isidora Charbila — Cinematography Guide
Greek director, cinematographer and film editor based between Athens and Edinburgh. Crazy Isi taught us the basics of cinematography and was our second camera for the interviews.
Her work here: https://vimeo.com/isicharbila
Artists / Casting
Blind Adam /// Thanos Kyriakides — ArtistFormer fashion editor, his visual impairment challenged him to move towards art. His work: http://blindadamvision.com
Cacao Rocks — Painter & Street ArtistBoth in galleries & streets. His artsy profile: https://www.artsy.net/artist/cacao-rocks
Panos Charalambous — Artist, Dean, Painter, PerformerDean of the Athens School of Fine Arts & documenta exhibited Artist. His work: http://www.documenta14.de/en/artists/13576/panos-charalambous
Elli Tringou — Award winning actressPlayed the supporting actress role in “Suntan”, greek movie internationally primed.http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3954660/
Niki Vakali — Rising ActressPlayed in the Hollywood movie “Worlds Apart” starring J.K. Simmons. http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3909336/combined
Dreyk the Pirate — Street Artist & Illustratorwww.dreykthepirate.net
Maria Mavropoulou — Visual ArtistStudied Fine Arts, chose photography as her main medium. Member of Depression Era Collective, which artistically documents the impact of the crisis on Greece.https://www.mariamavropoulou.com & http://depressionera.gr
Fikos — Iconographer, Painter, Muralist, Street ArtistHe applies byzantine technique & Orthodox graphic Identity to contemporary movements such as street art. Unique.http://fikos.gr
Artanc — Nota Kalagia & Sofia TheofilaktidisPop Up International Art Exhibitions, Founder & Curator.https://www.facebook.com/artanc.co.uk/
Bengoa Blindstitch — DJ, House Producer & Label FounderProminent night life actor, toured all around the world with the great Kevin Yost.His music: https://www.discogs.com/Bengoa-What-You-Give/release/6818992
Augustus Veinoglou — Snehta ResidencyArtist, Painter, Sculptor, Installations, Augustus is also the founding director of Snehta Residency.http://augustusveinoglou.com & https://www.snehtaresidency.org
Σtella /// Stella Chronopoulou — Indie Pop SingerStudied fine arts, worked as an editor for an art magazine, ended up in music.http://stellathemusic.com

Stefania Strouza — Artist, Sculptor & Installationshttp://www.stefaniastrouza.com

Title: When Athens Held a “Coolest Person” Contest (and the Loser Got Banished)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Imagine living in a city where every year, the citizens gathered, not to elect their leaders, but to decide who was getting kicked out of town. Sounds like a reality TV show gone wrong? Actually, it was ancient Athenian democracy in action, around the 5th century BC. They called it ostracism, and it was their way of saying, “You know what, maybe you’re too popular for your own good.”
Let’s set the stage. Athens is buzzing. Democracy is the hot new political trend, philosophers are debating in the agora (marketplace), and everyone’s got an opinion — loudly voiced, of course. But with all this freedom and debate, there was a nagging fear: what if someone got too powerful? What if a charismatic leader charmed their way into tyranny, just like in the bad old days before democracy?
Enter ostracism. Think of it as a pressure release valve for Athenian society, a way to prevent any single person from becoming too influential and threatening the democratic balance. Every year, the Athenians would hold a vote. But instead of voting for someone, they voted against someone. Each citizen could write a name on a piece of pottery shard (an ostrakon, hence the name). If a name got enough votes — and “enough” was a hefty number, around 6,000 — that person was ostracized.
Now, here’s the kicker, the part that’s utterly hilarious from our modern perspective: ostracism wasn’t about punishing criminals or banishing enemies. It was about temporarily exiling people who were too successful, too well-liked, or simply too ambitious for the comfort of the democratic crowd. Imagine being so popular you get voted off the island… literally!
Picture the scene: The Athenian Assembly is packed. Citizens are nervously clutching their pottery shards. Whispers fill the air: “Is it Pericles this year? Maybe Cimon? He’s been awfully successful lately…” It’s like the ancient Greek version of the Met Gala red carpet, but instead of fashion critiques, careers are on the line.
And the punishment for being too awesome? Ten years of exile. That’s right, a decade-long timeout for being a bit too good at life. The ostracized individual had to pack their bags and leave Athens, although thankfully, they didn’t lose their property or citizenship. It was more of a “take a break, cool off, and maybe come back less… you.”
From our 21st-century perspective, this is comedy gold. A democratic society banishing people for being too popular? It’s like holding a “Most Likely to Succeed” contest in high school and then expelling the winner. We can almost imagine the ostracized Athenians grumbling as they packed their bags, “Seriously? I get punished for being good at things?”
But behind the humor, there’s a serious point. Ostracism, while seemingly absurd to us, reflects a deep-seated concern in ancient Athens about the dangers of unchecked power and the fragility of democracy. They were so committed to preventing tyranny that they were willing to temporarily sacrifice even their most capable citizens, just to be safe. It’s a drastic measure, born out of a very real fear.
Who was involved? The entire Athenian citizenry, from farmers to philosophers, participated in ostracism. Famous figures like Themistocles and Cimon were ostracized, proving that no one, no matter how accomplished, was immune to the public’s popularity anxieties. How did people react at the time? It was a regular part of Athenian political life, accepted, though probably not always happily, as a necessary safeguard for democracy.
This quirky practice from ancient Athens, while funny from our viewpoint, serves as a potent reminder of the constant balancing act between individual ambition and the collective good. It subtly underscores themes of resilience — the Athenians were constantly innovating to protect their democracy — and critical thinking: what are the potential downsides of even the most well-intentioned systems? And perhaps, it’s a cautionary tale about the fickle nature of popularity and the occasional human tendency to cut down the tallest poppies in the field.
So, next time you feel a pang of jealousy at someone else’s success, remember the ostracized Athenians. It could be worse — at least you’re not getting banished for being too awesome. And maybe, just maybe, it’s a good thing we don’t have popularity-based exile in our modern democracies. Although, thinking about some reality TV stars… just kidding! (mostly).

Title: Travel Unplanned: An Adventure from Athens to Ohrid, Macedonia
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Travelling from Athens to Ohrid, Macedonia was probably one of the more adventurous backpacking experiences I had. I got on the road unplanned (and without mobile data) except booking a one-way train ticket from Athens to Thessaloniki. Then, I left the rest to the universe! The journey involved two train rides, a taxi ride, a police officer, and a car ride with a complete stranger (!) In this post, I am sharing the travel details of how I got to Ohrid from Athens. You can copy my route, but it might not be your cup of tea.
Pin it to read it later!
Why I wanted to visit Macedonia
The reason may sound funny to you. I heard the name of this small country in the news when I was 11 years old. My country Taiwan donated millions of dollars to Macedonia hoping to build a solid friendship, but all the money went into the pockets of corrupted Macedonian politicians (!) Well, I was 11, so none of the political matters was relevant to me. However, the name of Macedonia did get stuck in the back of my brain because it sounded like macadamia! (Yes, Macadamia, the nuts.)
Besides that, to be honest, I knew nothing about Macedonia except the capital Skopje was the birthplace of Mother Teresa. I wanted to go to Skopje from Athens but realised there wasn’t any direct trains/buses. I couldn’t arrive Macedonia without going through Thessaloniki! My Couchsurfing host in Athens suggested me to go to Ohrid first because it would be a pity to miss it. And I’ve never heard of Ohrid before that afternoon.
From Athens to Thessaloniki
I wanted to hitchhike at first, but my Macedonian host suggested me not to due to the rising crime in kidnapping/human trafficking (if I remember correctly.) I tried getting the train ticket in the morning of, but it was completely sold out, so I ended up travelling a day later. Taking the overnight train saved me a night of accommodation.
It was 2015, the year which thousands of Afghanistan, Syrian, and Iraqi refugees flooded into Europe through Macedonia. Many of them took the same train, and from their outfits and bags, it was quite clear that they weren’t going on a vacation. The train was noisy, packed, and the toilet was smelly, but I ain’t complaining because at least, I still had a seat and there was air conditioning.
I arrived Thessaloniki at dawn and was thinking to stay there for a day or two, but the exhaustion from the overnight ride got me. All I wanted to do was to charge my way to Ohrid. I followed the instruction my host in Athens gave me before I departed and asked the ticket booth for the next train to Florina.
From Thessaloniki to Florina was a smooth ride. The short distance local train was pretty empty in contrast to my last leg. My plan was to find a bus that would bring me to Ohrid, but of course, that idea fell through.
From Florina to Bitola, Macedonia
Florina is a small town at the border of Greece and Macedonia, and the train station was tiny, too. In fact, there wasn’t a “train station.” All I saw was a small blockhouse. I walked in there and asked who I assumed as the ticket agent about how to get to Ohrid, and here came the problem: He could barely understand English, and he has never heard of Ohrid before! At this point, I had already travelled for more than 10 hours.
I walked out and looked around but saw no one besides a taxi driver and a police officer. I walked up and asked about how to get to Ohrid by bus.
“You want to take the bus? It’s in the centre. Very far away,” the police officer said.
Great. I wondered how if there are any other ways I can get to Ohrid. He then exchanged a few words with the taxi driver.
“He can take you to Bitola, 14 euros.” That’s a pretty good deal, I thought to myself. How about Ohrid? I asked. “120 euros.” Hmm, that’s a drastic difference. I guess I’ll go to Bitola first, then figure out the rest.
I tried to make a conversation with the taxi driver, but he didn’t talk much English. When we were crossing the border, he took down his taxi sign and put it in his trunk. I supposed it’s illegal for him to operate as a cab driver in another country. It was miles of nothing on the way to Macedonia. When we finally made it to Bitola, I gave him 20 euros and waited for him to give me my change.
“One more.” He shook the bill I just gave him in his hand.
“Isn’t it fourteen euros?”
“Fourteen! Fourteen! Pen!” Then he took out a piece of paper and wrote: 40.
“Wait, I thought it was four-teen euros! Not for-ty! Can we do thirty instead?” I realised what went wrong here but proposed an alternative. He unwillingly agreed. I couldn’t help to feel bad, but I was on a budget. In the end, he did drive to another country and had to drive back.
From Bitola to Ohrid
There were a few buses parked at where the taxi driver dropped me off. An old man walked up to me and said he could drive me to Ohrid. I knew he wasn’t going to do it for free. I saw another blockhouse-looking building and wanted to see if it’s a ticket booth for the buses, but this one was worse than the one in Florina — It was abandoned with no one inside.
“How much?” I walked back to the old man. “20 euros.” “Okay, let’s go.” I got into his car.
His old stick-shift might be as ancient as him, and it was making squeaky sounds when we were driving. We were going 40km per hour on bumpy, curvy roads with Balkan music blasting through the almost broken radio. Again, I was trying to chat with him to keep myself awake, but that failed also. And there was no way for me to know how long the ride was supposed to take. The ride felt like forever! The man picked up a mid age woman on the road who waved him down when we were closer to Ohrid. It seemed like they knew each other.
Ohrid
After 12+ hours, I finally arrived Ohrid. I didn’t exchange any Macedonian Denars in Greece since I had no idea I would make it to Ohrid the day after. The old man waited for me outside of a currency exchange office and drove off after I gave him the equivalent of 20 euros in MKD. (I only had 100 euros, and he didn’t have any change in euros, of course.)
Where did I stay?
I arrived Ohrid at noon, and it was extremely hot! a few locals approached me and wanted me to stay at their hotels/B&B or whatever it was. I wondered around with my backpack in the city centre and found a hotel lobby that would let me use their free wifi. Then I found The Art Hostel Ohrid via Hostelworld. It was a bit far away from the city centre, but that was okay. I went without a reservation and got myself a bed! They didn’t ask me how many days I wanted to stay, and I received the warmest hospitality!
And that’s the story of how I travelled from Athens to Ohrid.
I travelled 802km and spent a total of 80 euros. It probably wasn’t the cheapest way, but it was an unforgettable experience. And Ohrid is definitely a hidden gem of the Balkans. I had the most pleasurable memories and met some wonderful people there. The town itself deserves its own post, so I’ll save the stunning photos of Ohrid in the next one!
If you like my travel stories, leave a comment and let me know! I would really appreciate that. Also, feel free to subscribe! and follow me on Facebook to stay up to date!
Originally published at Notes of Jo.

Ancient Athens was a center for the arts, learning, and philosophy, the home of Plato’s Academy and Aristotle’s Lyceum, Athens was also the Birthplace of Socrates, Plato, Pericles, Aristophanes, Sophocles, and many other well-known philosophers, writers, and politicians of ancient Greece. It is widely referred to as the Cradle of Democracy, and Western Civilization mainly due to the impact of its cultural and political achievements during the 5th and 4th centuries BC on the then-European Continent.
Pericles (495–429 BCE), came from an illustrious aristocratic family and was an Athenian statesman, general, orator, and arts patron. He was Pivotal in the development of Athenian democracy and the Athenian empire.
He helped establish democracy in Athens and is considered the first citizen of a democratic Athens. He transformed its alliances into an empire. Rebuild the Acropolis after it was destroyed by the Persian invasion. And many more.
He believed in the wisdom of the goddess Athena, the guiding spirit of Athens. And lived by his rational ideologies

Content:
Sign up

Sign up

Listen

Athens, the historical and cultural capital of Greece, is a city steeped in history located on the shores of the Aegean Sea. Known as the birthplace of ancient Greek civilization, this city exudes an atmosphere filled with history at every corner. On my recent trip, I embarked on a journey to explore Athens, and I couldn’t help but be enchanted by this unique experience.
Journey to the Acropolis:
Upon arriving in Athens, my first stop was, of course, the Acropolis. This ancient citadel, a symbol of Greece, is perched atop a high hill and greets visitors with the splendor of the Parthenon Temple. As I ascended to the Acropolis, walking among the historical ruins, I felt the excitement of traversing through time. Rediscovering the captivating beauty of the ancient era against the backdrop of the city’s panoramic views filled me with profound admiration.
Plaka District:
Descending from the Acropolis, I visited the heart of the city, known as the Plaka District. With its narrow cobblestone streets, colorful shops, and traditional taverns, Plaka is one of the liveliest and most charming neighborhoods in Athens. Here, while savoring local delicacies, I found myself immersed in a unique blend of ancient and modern atmospheres.
Ancient Agora and Old Town:
To delve deeper into Athens’ historical fabric, I made my way to the Ancient Agora. This was the place where philosophers like Socrates and Plato once walked. Roaming among the ruins of the Agora felt like embarking on a journey through the past. Afterwards, getting lost in the narrow streets of the Old Town and wandering among the traditional houses made me feel as if time stood still.
Modern Athens:
Athens not only boasts the legacy of ancient times but also thrives as a modern city. Central points like Monastiraki Square and Syntagma Square are lined with modern cafes, restaurants, and shopping centers. Exploring these areas allowed me to discover the modern and dynamic side of the city.
As I strolled through the streets of Athens, I savored the experience of exploring a city intertwined with history. Following the footsteps of ancient Greek civilization while experiencing the vibrant atmosphere of a modern capital was an unforgettable experience. Athens was not just a trip for me; it was a journey through time. A bridge between the past and the future was built before my eyes, and this experience will forever leave a lasting impression on me.

What makes a civilization great? A civilization achieves greatness when various facets of humanity — physical, intellectual, emotional, and spiritual — are allowed to blossom and find full expression.
When you look at the ruins of Athens, you see evidence of this greatness.
Many impressive cities in history have made great contributions to the growth of human civilization, but few have come close to what Athens came to achieve and represent. When I visited the city I found the testament of its greatness written in stones; in its broken columns and fallen walls.
As you reach Athens, you see its skyline dominated by a cluster of massive structures on a hilltop. These were magnificent temples, now only ruins, which towered over the city in its glorious days.
The most impressive among the structures is the Parthenon, a temple dedicated to Goddess Athena. Its imposing columns striving to kiss the sky stir within one the ever-present yearning to transcend our earthly limits and reach for something beyond.

Ancient Athens is often referred to as the birthplace of Western thought. Whilst we have a lot to thank the Athenians for in terms of the invention of education as we know it, critical thinking, science, democracy, technology and architecture, everyday life looked a lot different back then. There were vast inequalities depending on gender, political and economic standing, for one only free men were classed as citizens, with females and slaves living a much more restrictive life.
In this article, we’ll delve into what life would have looked like as an inhabitant of Athens, in terms of their occupation; diet; how they socialised; where they lived and what family life looked like.
Athens, as a thriving and bustling coastal city boasted a vast array of different occupations of all skill sets and familial backgrounds. Content:

Talking with User Interface & User Experience Designers

--
Listen
Share
Matt D. Smith is the owner and Design Director at Studio Mds, a small independent design studio in Athens, GA. He created the Float Label Pattern for digital form input fields, which is now a design standard in Google’s Material Design Guidelines. He’s a proud father of four and has led creative work for agencies and brands in the US and Singapore including NBC, AT&T, Sprint, Home Depot, Lowe’s, Dwell, Razorfish, Sapient and more.
When your friends or parents ask to you what job do you do, how do you answer?
I tell them I’m a designer and work mostly on websites and mobile apps. Everyone knows what those things are so this answer proves most digestible for a layman.
What is your background, how did you train?
I was always drawing when I was a kid. In college I gravitated towards drawing and painting and eventually made my way into the Graphic Design department at the University of Georgia. There I learned a lot of the fundamentals of design–typography, white space, color, contrast, etc. After graduating I got heavily involved in the Flash community and taught myself Actionscript 2.0. This sparked my passion for digital design.
What the web can do to make this world a better place? How did the web improve your life( if it did)?
The web can’t do anything on its own–it needs people. It’s a powerful tool to connect humans all over the world around a specific thing. The possibilities are endless.
Can you show us three examples of interface that in your opinion improved human life?
“Improving human life” is definitely subjective depending on whom you ask. I’d say a few that make my life easier are iMessage, Fantastical, and Dropbox. iMessage for short specific bursts of communication. Fantastical for its natural language input to create events. And finally, Dropbox that reliably keeps all of my digital stuff wherever I go.
On quora.com, time ago there was a long discussion in answer to the question “what is the most intuitive interface ever created?”; according to Felipe Rocha it is the nipple, in your opinion instead? (http://www.quora.com/What-are-the-most-intuitive-interfaces-ever-created)
Hmm, maybe fruit. It appeals to most of your senses–sight, smell, feel, taste. It serves a core human need, hunger. It’s also nutritious. =)
How is your work day type?
I get into work around 8 AM and try to write first thing in the morning before email, jumping into design, or anything else. From then on until around 5pm, it’s design, emails, etc. all day.
What is the most stimulating and challenging project you have accomplished?
The most challenging project I’ve worked on so far has been Shiplify, a commercial transportation management system. There are huge amounts of information along with the constraint of a mobile device that really leveled up my thinking and skills.
What is, among the existing digital services, the one you wanted to do?
Hah, I’m still trying to figure that out.
Many designers commit the mistake of starting a project directly from Photoshop, is there a perfect design method? What is your approach to the creative process?
Starting in Photoshop is a good way to create art, but not solve a problem. The more experience I gain as a designer, the more time I wait before jumping into a design. I start with lots and lots of questions about the problem we’re trying to solve and why.
The “design” is an important part of our analogic life. What is the role of the designer in our digital life?
The core role of the designer hasn’t changed much from analog to digital. It remains to communicate visually. The trick is to find out what you’re trying to communicate and why.
Do you believe it is important for a designer to have a deep knowledge of matters as User Experience, Interaction Design, Product Design, and Front-end development?
It depends on what the designer wants to do with her personal career, but I if she wants to be the best she can possibly be, she’ll need to have a relentless pursuit of knowledge of her craft. Learning to code, etc. will only help her connect dots easier and gain a better understanding of digital products overall.
In which way do you make a difference between User Interface and user experience?
The UX is the design in its entirety– the alpha and the omega. From the words on the very first entry screen, to a payment receipt sent via email, UX covers it all. It is holistic, from business strategy to behavioral design. The UI is a smaller portion of the broader picture that deals specifically with the parts people touch and click. The two are deeply intertwined and should be considered in parallel. Sometimes UX decisions can be enhanced by UI design and vice versa. The best UI designers will also be great UX designers. I’m not a big fan of segmenting the titles of UX and UI designer, which is why I call myself simply a designer. I do both.
What is your relationship with the developers? There are people that have a relationship of continuous confrontation and other of deep friendship, where do you collocate with respect to this question?
If you want to work well with others, there needs to be friendship and common ground. If you find yourself constantly at odds with developers or anyone else for that matter, you’re doing it wrong. There’s a degree of humility that needs to be present for people to work together harmoniously.
How do you think that your career and job will evolve in the next 5 years?
I’ll always design things. It’s my thing, ya know? With that said, I do see myself transitioning to more strategy, planning, and writing to build my own products as opposed to only doing client work.
A famous quotation of David Carson (noted American graphic designer) says: “Graphic design will save the world right after rock and roll does”.Will the User Interface Design save the world, before, at the same time, or after the graphic design?
After. UI is no savior.
What do you think about Dribbble? Is it a good way to get a job? What’s the best way to find a job as designer?
Dribbble is amazing. I’ve met great people there and it’s delivered lots of job opportunities. People often mention Dribbble as a place where people focus on shallow design and getting likes, but that’s not Dribbble’s fault, that’s people’s fault. Look at Facebook, it’s an amazing communication tool, but it becomes mind-numbing after too much exposure–not because of the software, because of the content.
Dribbble is what you make it.
What book would you advice to a Junior Designer?
Hmm, that’s tough. There are so many great books; my suggestion would be to read constantly. There isn’t a magic bullet. You have to progress gradually. One book that I’m really enjoying at the moment is Peter Thiel’s, “Zero to One: Notes on Startups, or How to Build the Future”
Always as far as advices: what tools for the design?
Beyond wireframes, I’ve become a big Sketch fanatic for UI design. I still use Photoshop regularly for different things, but Sketch is now my goto for layout out UI for a website or an app.
What tools for the projects management?
For wireframing, I swear by Adobe Illustrator. I’ve tried out most software for this purpose and Illustrator is by far the fastest and most versatile vector editor there is. In fact, I’ve created a whole blog series devoted to rapid UX design with Adobe Illustrator, which can be found at http://aiux.co
Dribbble : https://dribbble.com/mds
Website : http://mds.is/
As the meeting point of design, technology and everything interactive, this year we’ll dive deep through innovation and disruption in Banking, Health and Retail industries.

Title: Neither Athens nor Jerusalem
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In 1867 Matthew Arnold wrote a book titled Culture and Anarchy in which he held up two saving springs of our civilization: Athens — from which we get the inner urge to “see things as they really are” — and Jerusalem, from which we get the directive “to set doing above knowing.”
I don’t know if I would draw the contrast between these two civilizational sources in the terms that Arnold used. But I do know that, in studying, teaching and loving philosophy as I do, while at the same time feeling myself to be Jewish at my self’s core, I must in some sense resemble the human type that Arnold was talking about.
On my last day of teaching at Brooklyn College, I passed around the attendance sheet for the Intro course and later found that the students had penned their own farewells. Since those attendance sheets now hang in my study, I can quote a line or two: “I am sure that, speaking for everybody, you touched many minds and lives. Thank you for portraying philosophy in such a user-friendly way …” or again, “Just know that you made a difference in many peoples’ lives, especially mine.”
It’s in the light of recent developments on university campuses that I’ve cast this backward glance over the terrain of my working life. What did it feel like to me, to work in the precincts of the academy — the House that Plato Built? What did it mean to me, teaching philosophy to students at Brooklyn College — that is, to young people from all over the world? My graduate school teacher of philosophy, the Straussian Stanley Rosen, described it as the disclosure of “beautiful and sacred things.” I remember Leo Bronstein — who was a celebrated teacher of art history at Brandeis — marveling, in his Russian/Catalan accents, that “the kids are forced, fo-r-r-rced (!) to learn sublime matters!”
In my turn, I viewed teaching philosophy as the transmission of a civilizational power and presence. If it was an Intro course, I would make the case for the importance to each of them of this transmission. “This will help you to decode the life you will face. It’s not true that you are what you eat. You are what you think! When you notice the way people behave, the way they frame their challenges, and the reasons or rationales they reference in explaining their decisions — you will be better able to lift out the thinking that lies back of all that.”
Sometimes I referred to the saying of Socrates that the unexamined [i.e. philosophically unsituated] life is not worth living. He meant, you’re not making the best use you can of your time here if you can’t identify and make good use of its philosophic assumptions. It’s not about choosing the “best philosophy” to live and steer by. They all have limitations or shortcomings, as does any attempt to understand a topic. No topic can be plumbed to every depth conceivable. But to know how to get to the available depths and to plumb that is a great power — empowering in the best sense — provided that (as with any power) it’s not used for harm.
So much for recalling what it was like for me to teach philosophy to real students. That said, we can fast forward to the present. What is it like to perceive young people who wear the name of “student” but mask their faces, menacing fellow students and teachers, injuring the working people who keep their academic classrooms and buildings functional? To what can I compare the predicament of a real teacher facing such defilements? Perhaps to the situation of a farmer whose field has been sown with salt and rendered barren by those means?
And what would I say to the so-called students who seem to relish doing precisely that kind of harm? If you attack the precincts of learning and teaching, you desecrate your own ability to learn or later to teach what you learned. You will still be able to be indoctrinated, and to indoctrinate others, but you can’t learn and you can no longer teach what you learned. And it’s not merely self-harm that you inflict. You injure your city, your country, your civilization. The wound you inflict has concentric circles of wounds that lie all round it.
And as for me, I wouldn’t know how to cure such wounds. Whatever healing modalities I possess — they don’t stretch that far.
At present, I have yet to reroute my life so that the powers I’ve acquired have some further riverbed channel down which to flow. I can’t just stand at the river’s edge and forever shed tears for what’s been lost.
Related Content: Two Types of Intelligence
--
--
Abigail Rosenthal is Professor Emerita of Philosophy, Brooklyn College of CUNY. She is the author of A Good Look at Evil, a Pulitzer Prize nominee.

Title: Hypatia and her revival in Raphael’s School of Athens.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The renowned masterpiece “The School of Athens” by Raphael captivates viewers with its iconic central portrayal of Aristotle and Plato, gesturing downwards and upwards, respectively. The canvas is a tapestry of intellectual luminaries, featuring figures like Heraclitus in a crouched pose beside a sturdy marble cube, and the revered Socrates and Pythagoras. The room is further enriched by the commanding presence of two statues in the corners — Apollo, the god of light and music, gracefully holding a lyre, and Athena, the goddess of wisdom (or her Roman counterpart, Minerva). Intricately weaving together the threads of knowledge, Raphael’s brushstrokes breathe life into the embodiment of wisdom.
As aptly articulated by Ralph Waldo Emerson, “Raphael paints wisdom.”
However, there is a lesser known ( and more disputed — arguably the most interesting) figure, dressed all in white, almost set apart from the rest of the painting and looking straight at us, as if Raphael was inviting the viewer to look more closely at this figure in his crowd of mental giants. This figure is often noted as Francesco Maria della Rovere, duke of Urbino (1490–1538). However important being a condottiero might have been, it seems that this particular persona would be a misfit in the room of eternal wisdom. Others argue that the feminine presence of this figure is indisputable, and that figure is in fact Hypatia of Alexandria, a Neoplatonist philosopher, astronomer, and mathematician, long forgotten and being revived by Raphael.
Hypatia has been described as a universal genius, but she was probably more of a teacher and commentator than an innovator, and best known to have edited the existing text of Book III of Ptolemy’s Almagest (treatise on the apparent motions of the stars and planetary paths). As noted, her philosophy was Neoplatonist and was thus seen as “pagan” at a time of bitter religious conflict between Christians (both orthodox and “heretical”), Jews, and pagans. Following the accession of Cyril to the bishopric of Alexandria, Hypatia’s fate suffered a brutal death.
“They dragged her into a building known as the Kaisarion, a former pagan temple and center of the Roman imperial cult in Alexandria that had been converted into a Christian church. There, the mob stripped Hypatia naked and murdered her using ostraka, which can either be translated as “roof tiles” or “oyster shells”. Damascius adds that they also cut out her eyeballs. They tore her body into pieces and dragged her limbs through the town to a place called Cinarion, where they set them on fire Unfortunately, all Hypatia’s work is lost except for its titles and some references to it by some of her students, reconstructing thus her contribution.”¹
However, back to Raphael’s painting — how can we know that is truly a woman being depicted there when the very figure of Hypatia was emblematic of heresy in the circle of the church ?
“At the same period, there was a common practice artists used, Raphael, Leonardo and Michelangelo each sketched full-sized cartoons of their large murals on the paper and pricked tiny holes along the contours. They then would blow charcoal through tiny holes onto the walls beneath. Each charcoal “sketch” blown onto the wall would lay the figured groundwork for the intricate painting that followed. When the mural was complete, the cartoons themselves would often be destroyed.”²
However, luckily, Raphael’s complete cartoon for School of Athens has survived and is considered “the most remarkable object of its kind surviving from the Renaissance”. In the cartoon, in a roomful of men, there is only one figure wearing a veil, a classic and common article of clothing used in depicting women in Renaissance paintings. The same veil is not present in the final painting — given that most final works needed somehow the approval of the ruling caste.
In fact, The School of Athens is part of a much larger masterwork, representing only one wall of the most brilliantly illustrated room in history — the Stanza della Segnatura, one of “Raphael’s Rooms” in the Papal Palace of the Vatican. For the first two centuries after it was created, this stanza, a private library to the popes and was only seen by the eyes of the few elite elders in the heart of the Vatican Church.

Title: Is America Repeating the Mistakes of Ancient Athens?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We bring readers together with up and coming writers sparking thought and conversation through stories on Medium. 18th Fastest Growing Publication On Medium https://ko-fi.com/thoughtcollection

--
1
Listen
Share
It takes place in silence, mainly as the people who are supposed to safeguard it remain too preoccupied to see what’s going on.
And that is the bitter lesson of Ancient Athens. Now America is suffering from the same blind spots.
It’s history repeating itself and rhyming with a harsh cadence.
Here’s why two democracies, old and new, might be more alike than we realize.
Athens made something radical: a body of language nobody on this planet had ever seen or heard.. government of the people, by the people.
Voting assemblies. Citizen juries. Laws that treated everybody the same, that is, at least if you were male and free.
By today’s standards it was not fair but it was a beginning.
Like America’s beginning wasn’t perfect — but it was constructed to get better.
Both systems were built on faith as much as bricks.. after people stopped caring, everything wobbled.
Lowerclass Athenians were given a voice by Pericles, who paid them to serve. That widened access.
But what it opened is the door to louder voices, not smarter ones.
As the conversation of leaders descended the crowd was humored.
Applause lines started wars. Justice was about winning a popularity contest.
It was all spectacle. And spectacle requires a villain.
America’s founders were obsessed with history.
They saw what had gone wrong in Athens and tried to slow things down through checks, balances and staggered elections.
The system functioned when people believed in it.
And now the crack is beginning to show in the walls.. Rules that are not violated but rejected.
There’s a rhythm to the drift of democracies. The lyrics are different, but the chorus strikes the same chords.
Athenian Breakdown
American Parallel
These are not symptoms in isolation. They’re a trendline.
Although this time around Athens surrendered to oligarchs after losing a war.
The Thirty Tyrants ruled brutal and short-lived, but that’s all.
The people fought back. Democracy returned.
But it limped.. not marched. What came back wasn’t what it was.
Athens was then given a second chance. It simply wasn’t strong enough for them.
There aren’t any mobs storming the assembly with swords.
No decrees, no coups..just slowbmotion neglect.
Democracy crumbles not when buildings fall in one big blow but when cracks are left unfixed.
And the tools to repair it aren’t glamorous. They’re tedious. Uncelebrated. Necessary.
Athens didn’t fail because it was flawed.
It dropped because too many trusted that it wouldn’t.
America has its warnings. They’re loud.
The resolution depends on whether we are listening to them or are the ones scrolling past.

Title: The Dave Red in Athens, just off Omonoia Square.
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

Review of The Dave Red Athens — April 2025
Check-in was smooth, especially considering my name has a special character and often gets misspelled —I checked in online - No hassle this time, Plus points — which was a nice start. The hotel was clean and looked freshly presented, but there are some serious downsides you should know about before booking. Totally outside the control of the Dave hotel !
There is a hidden door in the ground floor library, You open it to a store room and a stain well come oncome on -dave red guys- like it a Bar.
The hotel is only a few hundred metres from Omonoia Metro Station, but walking those few hundred metres feels like crossing a dystopian wasteland. Junkies and people clearly struggling with addiction are everywhere — shooting up in doorways, passed out on the pavement, or stumbling around in a daze. One man ahead of me was swinging a syringe around like it was a cigarette, in broad daylight. I didn’t feel directly threatened, but the general atmosphere was intense and unpleasant.
You also see severely unwell women loitering — prostitutes— in what looks like a desperate state. Some stood motionless at corners like statues, others circled the same block over and over. It was deeply sad. The whole area feels forgotten and unsafe. If you’re not used to this kind of street scene, it’s genuinely shocking.
The room was fine in terms of cleanliness, but definitely unfinished. It had a clean, modern look — no carpets, just polished flooring — but the detailing wasn’t great. The major issue was the shower: it simply doesn’t drain.
The major issue was the shower: it simply doesn’t drain. I’ve worked in construction and can say with confidence — the floor of the shower area has no angle, no lip, and no waterproof tilting detail. It’s just a flat surface, of latex paint so the water spreads quickly across the bathroom floor. After five minutes of showering, you’ll find yourself standing in a puddle with water edging toward the bedroom. A proper fix would involve cutting a groove or sloping the floor slightly toward the drain — basic stuff that just wasn’t done.
Breakfast at The Dave red left a lot to be desired. Compared to nearby options — for example, The Stanley Hotel just around the corner — it was dismal. The Stanley offers a proper buffet with a rotating toaster, beautiful sour cherry syrup,for your Greek yoghurt, fried bacon, tiny sausages, scrambled eggs, and a few other hot items. The Dave, by contrast, felt like a bit of a cost-cutter.
They had boiled eggs, but no scrambled eggs — maybe because that would’ve required just a bit more effort. Overall, it gave the impression of trying to appear trendy while quietly cutting corners. if it cn be wheeled out of a room that what we got
The breakfast room is nicely styled, but it’s let down by the details. The felt on the pool table is shredded, the plumbing is noisy and should of only int the breakfast room be covered up (you can hear when someone above flushes), and coffee is served in paper cups — . On my first morning, I managed to get a proper mug, but by the second, it was back to takeaway cups. For a breakfast I had to pay extra for, it felt more like a quick hostel setup than a hotel experience.
The Dave red clearly leans into quirky style — and to be fair, it succeeds in that. The building used to be the Communist Party headquarters of Greece, and I really think they should lean into that history more. There’s a massive mural in the breakfast room, but no real explanation or story told about the building’s past. That would’ve been a cool addition — Athens has history at every corner, and this building has a unique one.
The Dave is trying to be hip and alternative — and inside, it mostly succeeds. But the location is grim and the construction quality isn’t there yet. If you’re familiar with Athens and know what to expect, you might manage. But for most travellers, especially first-timers, I’d strongly recommend looking elsewhere.
Safer, better alternatives: try Psiri, Koukaki, or Plaka — all still central, with far more charm and far fewer needles.
Bottom line: cool hotel, bad street, broken shower. staying in the Plaka next time.

On the southern tip of the Balkan Peninsula, in Southeast Europe, is the nation of Greece. It is renowned for its illustrious past, vibrant present, and iconic locations including the Acropolis in Athens, the Palace of Knossos in Crete, and the historic settlement of Delphi. Greece is renowned for its mouthwatering cuisine, which includes meals like moussaka and souvlaki, as well as its stunning islands, like Santorini and Mykonos. Greece has Greek as its official language, and it is a parliamentary republic, and the currency used is the Euro.
In the Attica region of Greece, Athens, the country’s capital and largest city, is home to more than 3 million people. With a history that dates back more than 3,000 years, Athens is one of the oldest towns in all of Europe.
The Acropolis, the Parthenon, and the Ancient Agora are just a few of the famous sites that can be seen there. It is noted for its rich cultural heritage. Aristotle, Plato, and Socrates are just a few of the philosophers and well-known thinkers from antiquity who were born and raised in Athens.
Numerous institutions, including the National Archaeological Museum and Acropolis Museum, are also located in the city. Athens is a contemporary city with a thriving arts and entertainment…

Title: Artist Spotlight #3: HER
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Fofi: I have been heavily involved in the music industry for the past 25+ years as a DJ, radio producer, consultant and music journalist in various media outlets, specializing in electronic music. I started DJing professionally when I was 16, so I experienced the difficulties that a girl had first hand, trying to make it in a (local) man-dominated industry, needless to say female DJs were a scarcity at the time — it was so difficult to find a role model to be inspired by, look up to, reassure in some way that there was a future, a possibility for a career out there for me. I had to work extremely hard, rely only on myself, constantly prove that I deserve to be there, belong there over and over (and maybe still do today), until I finally got to a point of being able to exclusively live by my profession.
Greece is quite behind in matters of equality, so at some point I decided that I had to give back, I did not want other people and especially girls having to go through what I went through to get somewhere. So, I created HER project. It was a very lonely ride at first, but luckily I met Virginia at a HER party. I detected her drive, our common values and ethos, which led me to decide to invite her on board. With HER project and our trajectory in music as starting points, we were more than excited to launch the Athenian chapter of shesaid.so in April 2020, elevating our initiatives and efforts on a wider and larger scale, belonging to a like-minded larger and international community.
Virginia: I started DJing and producing quite recently, my journey began in 2018 though I did listen to electronic music before that. One night I met Fofi at a HER party, where we discussed about the concept of HER as a female empowerment initiative in music. I immediately resonated with it, because I had experienced gender biased inequality and sexism from one of my mentors. HER felt like a safe outlet to me, and the fact that I am able to utilize my art to offer a safer space to minorities and do something good for our society is the utmost purpose. From then on I joined HER and along with Fofi we are trying to involve more and more women into it, and raise awareness locally. Until now there isn’t a similar initiative as HER in Greece, neither in electronic music nor in other genres. This is why we also initiated shesaid.so Athens, to reach out to the music industry cluster in general, including other genres and professionals beyond artists only.
We regularly collaborate with Athens Pride, both as representatives of gender minorities, but also as members of the LGBTQI+ community. We are always on the lookout for new, inclusive collaborations. World Pride House in Malmo had an open call for proposals, and we decided to sent in a triptych, which included a livestreamed HER DJ set along with drag performances, a live HER DJ set with VRGN, and a very interesting panel discussion on gender equality in the music industry. We were extremely happy that all of them passed. At the discussion, we are hosting 3 brilliant speakers, event planner and curator, Mirca Lotz, from Germany, psychologist and gender equality advisor, Maria Rodriguez, from Spain and Dina Liberg of shesaid.so Sweden, all of whom gave us their own valuable perspectives on current issues and future actions we could all take.
The Greek scene is buzzing — Athens is becoming a very interesting and intriguing art hub, which has been characterized as the “new Berlin”. However, the music ecosystem, as a whole, is light years away from the Berlin scene. Starting from the lack of basic state support and funds, legislations, unions, statistics, lack of professions such as artist managers, music marketers and communicators, label management, agencies, and more. Needless to say, the music industry is still not as equal and inclusive as it should be with minorities. It was only recently that the issue was even a matter of discussion — shesaid.so Athens organized the FIRST panel that addressed the subject in September 2020.
Representation of women is still not enough and the arguments range from “there aren’t enough women musicians to begin with”, “there is no equality problem, women are the ones who do not want a career in music”, to “currently the top DJs are women, so there is no need for gender equality initiatives” and more.
Greece lacks basic education on what gender stereotypes are, on what ways gender inequality appears, what actions, comments and behaviors spark inequality. It is really funny, until it was not anymore, there are many times that as HER project we have felt that we have to actually convince people here that there is a problem with equality in music.
At the same time, Greece is experiencing a huge societal crisis with a constant and very alarming rise in femicides and gender violence, especially during the pandemic, while the patriarchal system is still strong in our society. Therefore, gender initiatives are needed more than ever, and that does not apply only to music.
On a positive note, more and more people speak up, more women and minorities express their own experiences and there is less fear in sharing one’s own story. In In that sense and in order to shed light on the matter of equality in music, in early 2021 we started a video series called #HERwords, where we invite women DJs and producers to answer a few questions in a 5’ video, sharing their own experiences and advice.
Last but not least, in 2021 the #MeToo movement also made its “debut” in the country — it created a sense of shock in the general public, but at the same time it gave a tremendous feeling of strength, support and hope not only to the victims, who boldly went public with their stories, but also to women and gender minorities in general.
What we have noticed from our collaborations with international artists and professionals, as well as members of the shesaid.so community, is that even though the needs are the same, each country and region has a very different perspective in terms of equality in the music industry, and consequently the respective actions each one takes lead to different sets of milestones we need to reach, so as to achieve working in a safer scene.
Everything begins and ends with education in our opinion. Firstly, we need research and statistics — numbers to show what is really happening in each area and profession, to understand each society and then to set up a localized approach and a clear strategy based on local needs and current social situations.
Raising awareness is also a great starting point, by simply advocating for gender equality and sharing experiences. Digital outlets, like social media, have much power that we can all exploit in that sense. Storytelling has become so much easier now, and if one’s story can affect and change just one more person, then it can create a snowball effect. E.g. Rebekah’s #ForTheMusic campaign sparked discussions and gained followers ranging from artists, to promoters, to clubbers and more. This demonstrated a suppressed need, which surfaced and engaged several professionals in the industry, even though it was a bit strange that it took so long for it to happen — since it was a subject we were all discussing constantly behind the scenes -, but thank the Universe it finally did.
Taking this as a starting point and using the Morillo extremely sad incident as an example, we have to really think why it took so long for mouths to open, even though it was made clear that people knew, why we saw so many people standing by him and not the victims, in the first place, but also after his death. This has to change. We need to start talking more and on a wide scale about safe dancefloors and booths, we need more men allies. We know the problem, we need viable solutions.
Finally, actively supporting communities is also an action we can all take in our daily lives. It is not enough to remain impartial anymore. In order to improve the music industry we need to radically change our daily habits, behaviors, collaborations — we need to actively include minorities in shows, we need to actively protect them and support them, until there is no need to do so anymore.
Fofi: I am an introvert, but very skilled at socializing. Music has always been the means to express my feelings through sound, vibrations and words. I have been doing this since I can remember myself, so it was extremely difficult for me to accept that new “normality”. I hold the longest-living residency at a club in the country, being the resident of Sodade2 for the past 21 years, so I did not only lose my outlet for communication, but also my coexistence with my friends and chosen family. I cannot pick one set as my favourite, I am blessed to have had so many. My latest favourite ones are the b2b sets by me and Virginia at Sodade, when after 4 am we usually set the club on fire, but also our performance as HER project at the first Sonar Athens.
Virginia: What I love about performing live is this non-verbal vibe exchange with the crowd, a give and take, while they are trusting us and letting loose to our music. We have had some of our best nights at a local club where Fofi resides, called Sodade, where we play for hours and experiment with house, electro and techno tracks, mixing genres and classic tracks, too. Also, our set at Sonar Athens is one that I will never forget! The stage, the people, the music, the honor of being part of Sonar, it was truly a night I will never forget.
Virginia: I simply won’t do anything that makes me feel uncomfortable, disrespected, insulted, dehumanized. There is an inner voice, I believe we all have, that reminds us of who we are and warns us when we are about to compromise that. I lately listen to this voice more and more, and it tells me that I am enough for those who respect and enjoy what I have to give, and I would never compromise my values and dignity for anything further.
Fofi: Music is my life, so the way I approach music and my career is actually the way I carry myself in this world: with the utmost care and respect.
The fact that we belong to this amazing global network that consists of exceptional people changing the game in the music industry, coexisting with extraordinary, talented, vigorous, dynamic and driven people, sharing the same mindset and ethos is actually a pure privilege and gift. shesaid.so is shaping the future that transcends the music industry and we want to help in that with all our being.
Virginia: I would pick “Rub” by Peaches. Peaches has been one of my favorite artists since I was young. As a woman, listening to an artist like Peaches, her strength, her expression, her I-dont-give-a-f*ckness, has been truly inspirational. Rub specifically, was published in 2015. It has brilliant lyrics, which are an ode to what is (still) happening today. I would absolutely love to have contributed with techno versions, distortions and beats.
Fofi: “Lifeforms” by Future Sound Of London. I consider it a pure piece of art, a pivotal moment in the electronic music history that shaped the things to come. I think that listening to it, when it was released, I could actually feel my brain being reprogrammed to another dimension. The way they stretched genres and combined ambient with techno is phenomenal. Plus, if I was a part of it, I would actually be in the studio with Elizabeth Fraser of Cocteau Twins and then die of awe silently and peacefully at the corner.
Fofi aka Fo is a leading figure in the Greek dance music scene. She has played at all major clubs in the country, shared the decks with several international DJs and she holds the longest living residency at a club in the country, being a resident of Sodade2 BackStage for the past 20 years.
Brimming with curiosity and passion for electronic music, Virginia aka VRGN is an upcoming talent to watch. Within 2 years she has already played in some of the biggest venues in the Greek scene, sharing the decks with both Greek DJs and international ones such and also performed at the first edition of Sónar festival in Athens, in a B2B session with Fo.

There’s nothing like the open road. Possibilities unfold as the terrain whizzes by your window.
Hailing from the second largest country in the world means that road trips were a rite of passage. There’s a lot of ground to cover in Canada. Packing up and jumping in the car for a long drive to a different destination, through ever-changing seasons is a core memory for me. Driving several hours or even days means that I’ve logged a lot of kilometers on Canadian roads over the years — traversing those expansive landscapes with awe. These road trips stretched into married life for family gatherings, special events, school holidays, and glorious weekends at the cottage.
Our road trips took on a whole new dimension when we moved to Izmir, Türkiye in 2021. The roads no longer looked familiar. We drove with a sense of uncertainty and with, I must say, a slight feeling of trepidation.
Can traffic circle procedures really be that different here? Why is everyone speeding? Will small country lanes based on centuries old trails be wide enough to pass through? What if we get lost and we don’t speak Turkish?
Once we adjusted to the local norms of driving we revelled in the fact that our road…

Hello! I am Panagis Sarantos and this is the story of how the GDSC program and Harokopio University of Athens met each other for the first time — and it was quite a journey!
It all started in the summer of 2021 when I was chosen as Lead. It all happened thanks to Angelika Zaucha, community manager for the GDSC program in Europe.
Here’s an interesting story!
It was the summer of 2021. I was hanging out with my friends on a nice evening in the beautiful city of Athens in Neo Iraklio. While we were talking about our summer plans, I got a notification about a new email. I looked it up and saw the name “Angelika Zaucha” for the first time. She reached me via her personal email to ask me if I would accept the lead position because it was the last day to do that, and they did not get the response from my side.I was positively surprised. I rushed out and found all the other emails that had gone to the spam folder. I finalized the paperwork and became the GDSC Lead & Founder of Harokopio University of Athens (GDSC HUA).So… Thank you, Angelika!
First task, of course, was to form our Core Team. As a student of software engineering, I knew I could reach many developers and people in tech. But I also knew that our Club will need others to help with communications, planning and social media. After making my choice, I came up with these few useful tips on selecting core team members:
I have to say that I didn’t follow all the steps that I mentioned above, but now I know better and you should too.
It’s also important to establish a good relationship with your university and the faculty. Introduce yourself and the program to the authorities. We managed to do it, and our university fully supported all our plans and initiatives. At times it was difficult because of the pandemic, but we managed to overcome any obstacles. For example we managed to do a virtual event about AI & Blockchain for more than 260 unique viewers!
Yes, that’s right. Our first virtual event themed as “Applications of AI & Blockchain in Society & Industry” managed to hit more than 260 unique viewers. I have to tell you that I was really nervous at the beginning. We were live streaming on YouTube, Twitch and other platforms. We had guests from the industry and academia. It was quite a big hit and a pretty good experience for me personally as I got to work on my communication and public speaking skills. I’m always nervous making speeches, especially in front of a big audience. This time, I managed to overcome my fears and really learn a lot.
Solution Challenge, organized yearly by Google Developer Student Clubs, was something I knew I wanted to join right from the start, either by myself or with other members of our chapter.I felt that rush of excitement when I was watching the Top 10 chapters of 2021. I loved the idea of making a positive impact on the target group or the society in general.
We joined the competition as a team and worked hard on our solution. And we did it! Our team called “Bloodcall” got to the Top 10 Finalists of Solution Challenge 2022! It was amazing when we heard the news. Who would have thought, first year of GDSC HUA and we managed to have such a strong representation competing with so many other chapters across the world. Also for the record, we were the only Greek chapter to the Top 10, even the Top 50!
What a journey we had! GDSC was a fun and enriching experience from many different aspects:
I have to say that if you have the time during your time at the university, you should join the program, even if it seems hard at first glance — trust me, the experience is priceless. That was the journey of GDSC HUA on how it was founded and how we did in the first year of our existence. And the journey continues to the present — with new faces, fresh ideas and 2 co-leads. GDSC HUA is still active on campus and in the program. Pretty cool!
From my end, I want to thank all the members of the first core team for the amazing job we did for the chapter while also doing our best as students. Thanks: Manos, Mitsos, Thanos, Nikos, Thanasis, Alexandra, Petros and again Thanos!
I want to thank Harokopio University of Athens for a great cooperation and support. Special thank you goes to our Rector Mrs. Mara Nikolaidou and our Department Head Mr. Thomas Kamalakis.
Lastly I want to congratulate and thank again the Bloodcall team for the amazing job they did. Thank you: Thanasis, George, Stefanos and George.

The 2004 Olympic baseball stadium in Athens is currently not a baseball venue but a soccer venue. I went by in late 2012 and it looked ok. At least they are using it for a sport! See a lot of articles lately saying all the venues are falling apart or abandoned.
There is only one “main” olympic stadium still being used for baseball which is in barcelona host of the 1992 games. The 1996 olympic stadium was Fulton county stadium which was torn down,the 2000 olympic main stadium in Sydney was a showground for cattle and was only a temporary venue for the games. However west of Sydney is the 2nd olympic venue and it has been resurrected by mlb and is used in the abl league. The 2008 wukesong baseball olympic stadium in beijing and both Practice fields were reduced to rubble shortly after the games. So the Olympic baseball stadium in Athens below is still there. Maybe someday it will see a baseball game again.

For the next piece of my President’s Day getaway to Greece and Israel, I flew from Athens International Airport on Aegean to Tel Aviv, giving me a chance to check out the Aegean Business Class Lounge and the Aegean ground experience at its primary hub airport ahead of my flight to Tel Aviv.
If you are just joining, catch up on my flight on Emirates from Newark to Athens, the Emirates ground experience at Newark, SAS Lounge at Newark, and stay at the InterContinental Athenaeum Athens.
I booked Welcome Pickups for my transfer from the InterCon to Athens International Airport (ATH). I scheduled a 2 pm pickup for my flight departing at 5:20 pm. The driver arrived promptly at around 1:45 pm. The ride to Athens airport was smooth and the traffic wasn’t too bad.
I booked the flight using American Express Membership Rewards earned on my American Express Platinum Card transferred to Aeroplan.
I found the check-in area quickly. Aegean had dedicated lines for its business-class customers as well as Star Alliance Gold customers. The line wasn’t too long when I arrived and I was served quickly.
I was not advised of any priority passport control or expedited security lanes for premium passengers. They also didn’t inform me of any lounge access despite its inclusion in my business class ticket.
There was no fast track for immigration, but I made it through pretty quickly. I didn’t initially see the signage for business class security so I got in the main line. When I did eventually notice signage for the business class line, I was already in the general line which was short so I stayed in it and did not move.
Once I cleared the formalities, I was inside the terminal. The Athens airport terminal was nicer and airier than I expected. I quickly found the entrance to the Aegean business lounge and made my way upstairs.
There were several lounges in the same area on a level above the terminal, and the Aegean lounge was clearly signed, but also recognizable from the strong Aegean blue. They are very consistent with their branding.
Curiously, the signs outside did not specifically note that Star Alliance Gold and premium passengers were welcome, as is common at Star Alliance lounges. This lounge, however, is indeed open to them and follows standard Star Alliance lounge access rules.
The lounge is accessed through automated electronic gates where your boarding pass is scanned, though staff was on hand.
Personally, I don’t mind the electronic gates as they allow quick entrance if your boarding pass is coded properly. But I do think being greeted by airline staff and thanked for your business is a nice touch that seems to be going away.
While Athens is Aegean’s primary hub, it’s primarily a medium and short-haul carrier and operates no widebody aircraft so my expectations for this lounge were measured. I was pleasantly surprised at the size of the lounge, and the offerings. This is notable since I don’t think Athens sees much connecting traffic either, save for passengers traveling domestically within Greece.
The lounge was a very large space with several areas and buffet stations, with great views of the runway.
The restrooms were hidden in a corner. They were small considering the size of the lounge, though well appointed. Showers did not seem to be available.
Wifi was free and fast. Many seats were available with easy access to outlets which I always appreciate.
There was a large hot beverage area with a massive Nespresso machine and a very solid tea selection. For Americans, there was also drip coffee on hand.
I prefer cold coffee so I would have awarded bonus points if they had iced coffee or cold brew on hand, but that’s very rare in Europe, unfortunately.
A variety of mugs and glassware were available for the hot drinks. The hot beverages area also had various cookies and croissants.
Past the coffee station, there was another buffet area with a variety of pastries, yogurt, and prepared foods.
There were also salads, fresh chocolates, and finger foods. The hot food station had several items, though keeping kosher, I didn’t look too closely.
There was a great selection of beverages and a self-serve collection of wines and spirits. I appreciated that they had Greek beer and wine, and a lounge employee was happy to explain the different Greek beers to me and point me to his favorite.
There was also a selection of various newspapers and magazines, primarily in Greek. It would have been nice to see some English or international offerings though.
Keeping kosher, there was not much I can eat from the buffet, but reviews of the spread from my fellow passengers were pretty positive. I left the lounge around 4:25 pm to browse duty-free and head to the gate ahead of my 5:20 pm flight to Tel Aviv.
Aegean does a reasonably good job with its business lounge, especially given its lack of widebody service. The space is large and comfortable space to relax before your flight. With plenty of seating, fast wifi, and ample food and beverage, it’s pretty solid for a long layover too. While the lack of showers was disappointing, there isn’t much long-haul traffic here so its less of an issue. I would not come early to experience this lounge, but I was very impressed by the offering given Aegean’s foot print.

Member-only story

As a lover of Percy Jackson, visiting Athens has been a dream of mine since I was basically old enough to read. I eventually decided to visit on my own as I had a writing deadline staring me in the face. On one hand, I needed to write thirty-thousand words in a week.
On the other, in that same week, I had found a studio apartment in Athens for £300. Oh! And I only had one week off my typical job. What should I do? I wondered.
Dreams were staring me down on both sides, until I realised, why not do both? So I did, I booked the flights, and off I went, laptop in tow!
I’ve travelled on my own since my first solo-inter-rail trip at seventeen, so this wasn’t new to me, but I was still nervous! As I can imagine you, reading this, would be nervous at the idea of visiting Athens as a solo traveller, especially if you’re an introvert girlie like me.
If you’re thinking about going, I bet the Parthenon is high on your list of attractions, so let’s break it down, because trust me, official guidance on this is confusing!
In this one article, we’ll be covering when you should visit the Parthenon, where to book tickets, as well as some incredible hidden gems at the Parthenon you should keep a look-out…

Title: Athens is Paradise for Graffiti Artists
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The Greek economy might be on life support, but at least one group in Athens is making the most of it and clearly thriving: graffiti artists. It has been suggested that Athens might be the best place in the world to be a graffiti artist right now. Or, as one of the practitioners puts it, “a little paradise for the graffiti artists.”
The city is in the middle of a graffiti epidemic. It’s a combination of high youth unemployment and underemployment, a general sense of unrest, and authorities being stretched too thin to do much about it. Frankly, the police have bigger problems. The result is an artistic free-for-all on the city’s streets.
Whether you want to call them vandals or street artists, they’ve been busy. Not all of it is new, of course, but there’s an awful lot of fresh paint adorning the walls downtown in the past five years or so. Shops, homes, bus stops, and pretty much any other wall — except, notably, places that have high security like banks and government buildings (mostly) — are covered in paint. Relatively few walls are spared.
There’s the usual scratchy hit-and-run tagging, but there’s also quite a lot that has taken real thought and effort to pull off. Some of it is youthful rebellion, some of it is political expression, and some of it is art in its purest form. And, of course, it’s constantly morphing, with new paint going over old.
And some of it is quite beautiful. Here’s a small sampling. Credit to the artists, whoever you are.
There’s a very interesting short documentary on graffiti in Athens that shows some of the painters in action. It’s called Alive in the Concrete, and you can watch it online here.
