After checking out the Aegean Business Class Lounge it was time to board my Aegean business class flight from Athens to Tel Aviv.
If you are just joining, catch up on my itinerary and how I booked the trip. Also see previous reviews of the ground experience in Newark for Emirates passengers, SAS Lounge at Newark, the Emirates business class flight from Newark to Athens, and my stay at the InterContinental Athenaeum Athens.
I booked this flight by transferring my Amex Membership Rewards points to Aeroplan, a program that typically has good redemption values.
In this case, the cost was 15,000 miles for business class, plus $86.50 in Canadian dollars in taxes and fees. I charged the taxes and fees to my Amex Platinum to take advantage of the 5x per dollar on airfare, no foreign transaction fees, and the generous travel protection benefits it offers.
For this flight, there was a coach seat available for 7,500 miles. And as a Star Alliance Gold member, I would have received priority check-in, baggage handling, and lounge access anyway. However, I decided the premium of 7,500 miles was worth it to try the experience, even if it only consisted of a blocked middle seat and perhaps better food for the 2-hour hop. This was my first flight on Aegean so I wanted the full experience.
I left the lounge around 4:25 pm to browse duty-free and head to the gate for my 5:20 pm flight to Tel Aviv Ben Gurion International Airport (TLV).
At the gate, I was surprised that there was not much by way of added security. Usually, flights to Israel feature additional security.
Boarding began relatively on time. Aegean elites, Business Class, and Star Alliance Gold passengers were invited to board immediately after the pre-board for young families and the disabled.
Priority boarding did seem to be enforced by the Aegean gate crew which is always appreciated.
Boarding moved pretty quickly and we pushed back relatively on time. There was a safety demonstration in Greek and English and we briefly taxied before taking off.
I was welcomed at the cabin door and directed to my seat in the small forward cabin. Aegean has an exclusively narrow-body fleet and even a few propeller planes. This flight was operated by one of Aegean’s Airbus A320 aircraft.
As is standard for European short-haul business, the Aegean business class cabin was standard coach seats with a blocked middle. While people love to make fun of the recliners in domestic forward cabins in the United States, they are an upgrade over the European standard.
I assigned myself 2C. As boarding slowed, the Aegean crew quickly welcomed us aboard and offered orange juice, sparkling wine, and water (served in real glassware).
The seats offered USB-A ports, which while not a full outlet, is great to have, but somewhat outdated with the move towards USB-C.
It’s also not guaranteed on short-haul flights in Europe, even on mainline carriers. While the extra space of an empty middle was nice, I hate how some airlines put a tray in. It would be nice to be able to lift the armrest and be able to spread out (as you can on British Airways Club Europe).
There was a card in the seat pocket advertising wifi and what’s available on the portal.
It was cool to see Aegean offer 10 minutes of free connectivity onboard. While a few carriers make wifi free in premium cabins and others are aiming to make wifi free for everyone, it’s nice that Aegean gives everyone a few minutes free.
Unfortunately, the wifi was not working on this flight, so I couldn’t test the connectivity. Most of the flight was over the Mediterranean, so I can’t say I’m too surprised that wifi was not working.
Aegean distributed paper menus that were printed in English and Greek. Despite the destination being Israel, they did not have menus in Hebrew.
I was impressed by the 3-page paper menu for such a quick flight. And while US carriers have European carriers beat in terms of the seat, European carriers usually beat on service and soft product in Euro-business.
I liked that there were 2 hot entrees available to choose from. Both, however, were animal protein so if you are vegetarian or vegan, I would recommend packing your own food or ordering a special meal. The 4 wines were all Greek or from the region, a local touch I liked.
There was an extensive drinks selection of soda, coffees, teas, beers, and spirits. Having espresso drinks on board is also a nice touch of European carriers. I wish US carriers had espresso on board short-haul flights.
Based on my pre-flight research, I determined Aegean uses Stogel for their kosher meals out of Athens. My general experience with Stogel is that the food is not great, so I did not order a kosher meal ahead of time. I took a picture of the base tray set up from my seatmate, but nothing else from the service. My seatmate reported that they enjoyed the food.
I self-catered, and just ordered some beverages.
The crew very were friendly and checked back to top up beverages. As it was a quick flight, the service wrapped up pretty fast, and I passed the time till landing by reading. I did dip into the forward lavatory, which was pretty tight, but nicely appointed.
When we landed, we didn’t spend too long taxiing before deplaning at a gate. Unfortunately, Israel does not offer fast-track immigration for premium passengers and waits can be quite lengthy. However, I was lucky to have a relatively quick queue and the wait for my bag wasn’t too long once I was through.
Given the tight security entering Israel, I did not take any photos of the arrival experience in Israel.
Aegean offers a very solid business-class product, especially given that short-haul routes dominate its network. While a more premium seat would be appreciated, the friendly crew, paper menus, and meals served on real glass and china gave the overall experience a premium feel. While Athens isn’t a major connecting hub, I would not hesitate to fly Aegean in the future.

As a writer, I’m a sucker for literary themed restaurants, especially those I stumble upon, which is exactly how I found the Little Kook in Athens. The restaurant changes themes seasonally and I was lucky enough to enjoy the Alice in Wonderland ambiance.
Surrounded by the chaos of Athens’ life, adults and children alike visibly exhaled when they entered the alleyway with tables lined under an archway of decorations. The vibrant colors, familiar characters, and smell of desserts in the air seemed to bring out the silliness in the patrons: laughter, photos, one older woman giving herself cat ears as she posed next to Alice.
The staff was dressed in full themed outfits. I first requested a menu from Alice, then the Mad Hatter, and only after asking the Mad Hatter a third time did I receive one. It crossed my mind that perhaps I misunderstood (I am navigating Greece as a non-Greek speaker) and this was one of those “purposely rude” establishments. Don’t worry, it’s not one of those restaurants.
Before I could order, a coffee drink was brought to my table. Sadly, it belonged to the man at the next table. I’m not sure if he ever received his. The server generously told me to keep what they brought and did not charge me for the drink.

Content:
Sign up

Sign up

By Megan Sheekey
This week Mayor Giorgos Kaminis announced the creation of the Athens Partnership, a nonprofit vehicle established with guidance from Bloomberg Associates. The mission of the Athens Partnership is to facilitate public-private partnerships, supporting priority public programs in Athens, Greece. This uniquely positioned entity will intersect between city government and the private sector, leveraging the resources and strengths of both. It will allow the city, with philanthropic support, to address pressing needs and pilot new programs while evaluating their outcomes and merit for future investment.
As the migrant crisis and economic instability in Greece continue to deeply affect Athens residents, the Partnership will be one tool to help the city remain responsive and moving forward. Bloomberg Associates is honored to count Athens among its client cities.
Op-ed by Athens Mayor George Kaminis in the newspaper “Kathimerini Tis Kiriakis”
ATHENS PARTNERSHIP
A Mayor who wishes to do his job properly in today’s Greece must always find a balance among four basic priorities. Firstly, he must ensure the daily operation of his city. Secondly, he must respond to the social needs constantly generated by the current economic crisis (soup kitchens, homeless shelters, distribution of primary need goods, social tutoring classes, etc.). Thirdly, he must react fast to the, special or by now usual, political uproars we have been experiencing in recent years (political violence, long term strikes, occupation of public buildings, extended delinquency etc.). Fourthly, in several cities, as for example Athens, the mayor is now required to deal also with the multiple consequences of the refugee/immigration issue threatening to deconstruct an entire society, the strengths of which are tested and have reached their limit in the last six years.
One would say that all of this constitutes a multifaceted reality, which every mayor acting under similar conditions is compelled to deal with. In some way, this chronic and multifaceted crisis that our country is going through has formulated a “normality” of its own, an explosive mixture of daily life and special circumstances, where the latter are clearly dominating, since daily life in our days obeys to no normal routine. The drastic reduction in resources, both in manpower and materials, along with a number of other factors have made extremely and unimaginably difficult the effort of a mayor to even accomplish elementary duties such as, e.g., sanitation.
It is not enough though to just keep our head above water. We must also have our eyes focused deep in the horizon. Our cities, especially the major ones, and Athens mainly, have eventually taken over the duty to prepare the country for the post-crisis times. What the central government has failed to realize for several years now is that there are actually municipalities that are innovative. This is what we’ve been doing for so long in Athens.
At the same time that we are dealing with the problems of today being absolutely focused on our job, we are also obligated to prepare for tomorrow, raising the bar to the height it should be as if everything around us was going well. We are constantly seeking new modes of action, with a stable outward orientation, in Greece as well as abroad. In Athens especially we have broadened the range of collaboration of the City, forming partnerships with all of the reliable agencies of the city: businesses, public organizations, professional and commercial chambers, universities, private sponsors and, certainly the active citizens of the Society of Citizens.
Today we are taking a step further. We created the Partnership for Athens or Athens Partnership, a non-profit organization promoting targeted synergies of the municipality with the private sector.
With the Athens Partnership we support infrastructure projects, but also initiatives to reinforce the social cohesion and economic development and by and large the improvement of the quality of life in the city. The Partnership is seeking to attract donations from foundations, businesses and private sponsors, among which of course are the Greeks Abroad. The organization and operation of the Partnership shall obey the most updated principles of accountability, transparency and effectiveness, with emphasis on the funding of innovative and pilot programs, which shall not only benefit the city but also the municipality through the transfer of modern know how. As an independent organization operating between the municipality of Athens and the private sector, the Athens Partnership combines the forces of both, with the final beneficiary being the resident of our city.
The Athens Partnership is following the tradition of successful prototypes that have been operating efficiently for several years in major cities abroad such as London, New York, Los Angeles, and Melbourne; they also have non-profit organizations cooperating creatively with the municipalities in vitally important sectors, like fighting poverty, dealing with crises and sustainable development.
The municipal authority of our city and myself, personally would like to extent our heartfelt thanks to all the private citizens and organizations in Greece and abroad that have supported at times the capital with donations and sponsorships. With the Athens Partnership we are capitalizing on the experience we have acquired and upgrading the quality of our cooperation with all those who are intended to help us in this difficult task that we have undertaken: to keep our city standing and methodically prepare it for the future.

Title: Why I Fell in Love with Athens in Just One Afternoon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I came with low expectations — a stopover, a few days at most. “It’s kind of chaotic,” a friend warned me. “Not like the islands.” But I landed, blinked into the bright Athenian sun, and something in me clicked.
It started with the coffee. Greeks take their coffee seriously, and I learned quickly that sipping a freddo espresso at a slow pace is practically a lifestyle here. I sat at a small café in Koukaki and watched the city swirl around me: scooters zipping past, old men arguing over backgammon, the Acropolis peeking out in the distance like it was eavesdropping on our conversations.
Athens has this joyful contradiction to it — ancient and alive. In one direction, you walk past ruins that have witnessed centuries. In the other, a street artist is painting a neon mural on a crumbling wall. It’s not a museum — it’s a mosaic. And somehow, it works.
I wandered through Plaka, where balconies overflowed with bougainvillea and cats napped in the sun like tiny emperors. I bought fresh koulouri from a street vendor for 50 cents and felt like I’d hacked happiness.
Then came the music. At sunset, I stumbled upon a group of musicians playing traditional Greek songs near Anafiotika. Strangers danced. Kids laughed. Someone handed me a drink and said “Kalosorises” — Welcome. I smiled so wide my cheeks hurt.
I kept walking. The golden hour in Athens is no joke. It bathes the entire city in honey — softening even the graffiti and concrete into something cinematic. I climbed Filopappou Hill and looked back at the Parthenon as the lights flicked on. It felt like the city was winking at me.
And just like that, I was in love.
Not with some idealized version of Athens, but with the real one. The imperfect, passionate, noisy, sun-soaked Athens that feeds you too much and talks too loud and insists you stay just a little longer.
By the end of the afternoon, I stopped being a tourist. I was a guest. Maybe even something more.
Athens didn’t just surprise me — it lifted me. Reminded me that joy doesn’t have to be loud to be deep. That sometimes, happiness is a glass of cold white wine on a rooftop with strangers who feel like old friends, and a city that feels like home — even if it isn’t yours.

Title: Greek Myths, Indian Traditions: A Layman’s Reflections from Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Note to Readers:
These reflections are simply my personal observations and interpretations, based on my experiences in Athens. I understand that myths, religions, and cultures are deeply subjective and complex. While the stories and comparisons might resonate differently with others, I hope to offer a glimpse into how I viewed these intersections from my own perspective. At the end of the day, we all bring our unique lenses to the world, and it is through these diverse viewpoints that we learn from each other.
The story of the city of Athens being named so starts with a scene of a duel between Athena and Poseidon. A king sought a patron deity for the city who would protect it from attacks and bless its citizens. Both gods were interested.
The venue for the duel was decided to be at the top of a hill where Acropolis stands today. Poseidon struck his trident on the ground and out came gushing water. People ran to have a sip of what they thought was holy. It turned out to be saline, reinforcing Poseidon’s dominion over the Sea. Then Athena struck her staff and there emerged a beautiful olive tree. Olive proved invaluable to the greeks: Its wood were used to make boats that helped them trade, fruits made pickles, seed pressed for oil. Therefore, Athena was chosen as the patron deity. [1]
However, this enraged Poseidon who cursed the city with floods. To calm him, Athenians built a temple for Poseidon at Cape Sounion, overlooking the sea, his kingdom.
The Greek gods, I realised, seemed to differ from Hindu gods in how they were influenced by emotions and expressed unpredictability in actions, which many might term as impulsive and unjust. This caused a lot of dissonance to me because of the striking contrast to Hindu deities or gods I’ve grown up around, who although express emotions, but never allow these to cloud their judgment or be unrighteous. (There are exceptions ofc, but statistically insignificant and associated with taboo). Over the course of the trip, in a conversation with my guides, I reached the conclusion that Greek gods reflect psychological archetypes, while the Hindu gods represented ethical ideals. It seems like a classic case of Prescriptive vs Cautionary approaches. I will explain this with an example later.
Meanwhile, let's take a short detour to understand present circumstances in Greece.
I arrived in Greece at night, and the first sights that greeted me were far from the postcard-perfect images of Santorini and Mykonos areas. My stay was in a residential area of Omania, away from the curated tourist experience, and I was taken aback by the sheer poverty, homelessness and drug abuse, that lined the streets.
Greece’s economic crisis played a large role in this. After joining the EU, the government underreported its actual debt, making the economy seem more stable than it was. When the truth surfaced, investor confidence collapsed, and the country fell to debt crisis.
Because Greece uses the euro, it couldn’t devalue its currency to make exports more competitive, closing gates to making an economic comeback. People lost jobs, rural population migrated to Athens, to the point that today almost one-third of Greece lives in Athens alone. This led to a strain on urban amenities. The symptoms were very visible to me. I saw open defecation, men and women fighting and desperate looks from beggars scanning passerbys.
It busted the myth which the British perpetuated in colonized India that white man is superior by nature because he is inherently civilized. [2] Turns out, stripped of prosperity, social stability decays everywhere. That social stability and ‘in-group members trust’ is more a function of economic security than a function of race, was an assuring observation.[3]
Although the situation is too complex to be done justice in a paragraph, it can be said that misplaced intention to generate political good-will coupled with several other factors instead of investing in avenues which would ensure multiplier effect in the economy, Greece fell deeper into the debt trap. (I believe we would help ourselves by applying this lesson to the worsening situation with Freebies in India.)
While Greece faces serious economic struggles, I was moved by the resilience and warmth of the Greek people despite their hardships. They were nice and straightforward, even weary of their circumstances. Tourism keeps their economy afloat but I could sense their quiet frustration with tourists. And although you can’t quiet bite the hands that feed you, you are free to resent the fact that you have to rely on it.
Anyways, back to our cultural discussion. The next day started with a tour of Acropolis. It is at the center of the city, both geographically and historically. The Greek civilisation was a cluster of city-states, each with their own Patron Deity. However, they all worshipped a shared pantheon of 12 Olympian gods.[4]
The Acropolis itself houses three key temples, each dedicated to different aspects of Athena. The Parthenon, the grandest, is dedicated to Athena Parthenos (the Virgin Goddess). The Erechtheion is tied to the myth of Athena’s contest with Poseidon, and the Temple of Athena Nike honors her as the goddess of victory. [5]
Built fully out of marble, the columns of The Parthenon stand huge, with the doors facing the east. This was done intentionally to have the sun’s first ray in the morning fall upon Athena’s idol, which was around 12 meters tall and was said to have been built out of Gold and Ivory. Must have been a beautiful sight to behold!
However, there is no idol there anymore. It was destroyed in the later years as Hellenism fell and the temple became a church first and a mosque later. What stands today is just a few columns, although the government is now working to reconstruct the temple, asserting its central role in the Greek tourism and economy.
In fact a culture-preservation law prohibits any building in athens to be taller than 103 meters, ensuring that the Acropolis must be visible from all corners of the city and should be the highest point.[6]
The funny thing however is that right next to the hill of Acropolis, I saw Mount Lycabettus, with a Greek Orthodox chapel at the top, exactly twice the height of Acropolis. Orthodox Christianity is the state religion of Greece and I couldn’t help but wonder if the placement of this chapel — literally twice higher than the sacred Acropolis — was a subtle statement of the new religious order.
Hellenism survives today in form of modern reconstructions of rituals from textual sources and around 2000 people follow the religion in private. [7] . Private, I emphasise, because the Hellenics have had a tough time recently opening a temple because the temple supervisor was jailed on inauguration day and the church released an official statement, urging the adherents of the true faith “not to be led astray”.[8] The funniest thing, the Right to practice religion is an inviolable right in the Greek constitution and it was essentially ensured to the adherents of hellenic religion after its official recognition in 2017.[9] Critics have cited the lack of proper official procedures and other troublesome aspects underlining the reason behind closure of the temple but I am of the firm belief that this is outside the scope of our discussion and is purely concern of the involved parties. We have no right to impose our POV over theirs, since the stakes differ.
Hellenism died a slow brutal death. I call it brutal because unlike the forces that actively engage in demeaning pagan practices today, did not even find Hellenism worthy of being opposed in the Roman ages. The Romans in-fact absorbed the greek pantheon, often reshaping characters and stories. The real blow came with the Fall of Rome to Christianity where Hellenism was actively suppressed (Theodosian Decrees which outlawed pagan practices).
Greek gods derive their stories from texts like The Odyssey and The Iliad and these stories (to say the least), though fascinating, feel scandalous to the modern mind. Like the story of Hephaestus, the god of blacksmiths and fire, who was physically deformed and married to Aphrodite, the goddess of love and beauty. Aphrodite had an extramarital affair with Ares, the god of war. This angered Hephaestus who created a magical web to trap Ares and Aphrodite in the “act” in order to shame them in front of public. They were trapped and Hephaestus called the gods to witness the blatant unrighteousness. The gods simply laughed at all of them and let it slide. No one was punished. No consequence whatsoever.[10]
When such stories and their morality were challenged by the Greek philosophers, the priestly class did not seem equipped to handle the questions. In fact, instead of reasoning or applying intellectual capacity, some even tried to silence the dissent. Philosophers like Socrates, who offered alternate theories of Godhood, were thrown in prison on charges of “corrupting the youth” (shown in picture).[11] This is in severe contrast to the brahmanical approach where the response was to strengthen arguments and rationalize actions, codifying them even, which is probably the reason why Hinduism survives today. The natural response of the Vedic society to Buddhist rise was the systematic Refutation of Śūnyavāda (Doctrine of Emptiness) by Mīmāṃsakas led by Kumārila Bhaṭṭa, which was later followed by the rise of Ādi Śaṅkarācārya who brought the Vedic teachings to their logical conclusions.
This is also be traced to the differing roles of the priestly class in a Hindu and Hellenic society. While the hellenic priests often acted as a medium between the gods and the common mass, conducting rituals, orally communcating stories and seeking blessings, the priestly class in Hindu society served multifold roles of conducting rituals, preserving texts, codifying ethics and asserting supremacy of The Vedas. Hinduism’s ability to absorb, debate, and reformulate ideas, even in the face of external challenges, is a significant strength. [12][13]
Although the Vedic Paramparā also distinguishes between Karma Kāṇḍa (ritual action) and Jñāna Kāṇḍa(knowledge), the traditional Gurukula system trained students across a wide spectrum of disciplines — ranging from astronomy and mathematics to linguistics, logic, and philosophy. This stands in striking contrast to ancient Greece, where schools of philosophy often developed independently of the priestly or ritualistic traditions, leading to a sharper divide between intellectual inquiry and religious practice.
The stories of gods were also contrasting, with common undertones of personified emotions. During an interaction with another Greek Mythology enthusiast, who quoted me this story of Aphrodite and Ares (the underlying theme being adultery and passion) , I was immediately reminded of the story of Lord Hanumān doubting his capabilities before making a leap to Lanka. It took him a trusted aide in the form of Jāmbavān to remind him of his true powers, set aside his doubts and take a leap across the seas. His story underlines the common theme of self-doubt and imposter syndrome that all of us face, whilst also providing a solution — seeking reassurance from a trusted friend or mentor.
If Greece taught me anything it is that Bharat and Bhartiyata are here to stay. Our ancestors have left us with an unshakable foundation — a profound source of strength and reassurance. Big white pill.
Yes, people might moving towards and away with time, but to quote His Holiness The Late Shankaracharya of Dwarkapeeth
“the seed will never perish. A minority shall always remain faithful to traditions…….. and that will be enough to keep it from getting lost”.
Around 2000 people in Greece still follow Hellenism. Zeus, Athena, and Dionysus are quitely worshipped in the altars of their homes. Their festivals have found a way to stay alive.
If a tradition, once our contemporary, can stay alive in shadows, how much stronger must ours be?
For over a thousand years, around 130 Agnihotri families have kept the sacred Agni alive. [14]
The Vedas are today chanted on the Ghats of Kashi, exactly like they were chanted 4000 years ago.
Indra, Varuna, and Mitra are still offered oblations.
The lineage of our Acharyas remains strong. The saints and realized beings still walk around us, in subtle and physical forms.
Our deities still respond to our prayers.
The institutions are still around to produce another Shivaji, another Vivekananda, and another Chandragupta Maurya.
People still chant the name of Shri Rama. Glory be to Him. Glory be to Maa Bharti for staying so strong even on the face of severe onslaughts. And Glory be to the Divine Mother for making me a Bhartiya first and an Indian second.
Seeing how remnants of Hellenism persist, despite centuries of suppression, made me appreciate how deeply rooted traditions find ways to survive. It reminded me of my own traditions and their resilience. Across cultures: faith, memory, and heritage endure in the hearts of people, waiting for the right moment to shine again.

Title: [14] Coworking Cities: Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The Coworking magazine by Coworkies. We highlights portraits of extraordinary people who entered the coworking world as owners, managers or members.

--
Listen
Share
If you follow Coworkies regularly, we’ve taken you to many different cities already. From New York to Shanghai or lately Prague, we’ve shared stories of people creating an impact on their cities by building incredible local coworking scenes. This month, we bring you to a whole new city, one we did talk about yet: Athens.
Why did we go to Athens? So many reasons!
Aside from discover a beautiful city full of History, we were curious to:
In just 2 days, we were lucky enough to find all the answers to our questions. To discover it too, scroll down and enjoy the ride through Athens unique coworking scene.
With 665,000 inhabitants in the city proper (3.75 Mo for the larger Athens) and more than 5 Mo tourists a year, Athens is without a doubt one of the lungs of Greece. Over the last decade, this lung has been heavily damaged by one of the toughest economical crisis of its History that has impacted many professionals and industries, from corporate companies to freelancers.
How did coworking grew in the middle of such a difficult time, let’s have look!
/ Facts and figures.
Unless other European capital cities such as Berlin or London, coworking has reached Athens later, more precisely in 2010 with the opening of CoLab workspace, which does not exist anymore. Until 2012, the entire country was counting 4 coworking spaces, which is a really low number that can also be explained and aligned with the crisis the country encountered as well as a lack of education about the term coworking itself.
Indeed, for a country of 11.3 Mo inhabitants, counting 4 coworking spaces does not help in spreading the word and educating the population to the new ways of working. But a wind of change has hit the country and today, in Athens only, there are about 10 coworking spaces that have flourished, offering various concepts to freelancers, companies and startups:
Now that the introduction is made, let’s dig deeper into Athens coworking scene, from the days it started to today!
Coworkies in Athens.
All and all, we spent 1 and half day in Athens and one thing is sure, we did not rest. We had the pleasure to visit 6 coworking spaces, in different areas of Athens. The diversity of spaces we came across was pretty impressive. Above all, what has impressed us even more is the people making Athens coworking scene what is is. Each one of them has a unique story that reflects in her/his space. In Athens, we’ve come across education in coworking spaces. We’ve also visited makerspace for Artists or Companies. Lastly, we’ve even had a yummy lunch prepared by refugees in a coworking space with a social impact.
We invite you to explore Athens with us by browsing around our interactive map of spaces we’ve seen! Some hidden tips and stories not present in this article are hidden in there, will you be able to find them?
The following piece has been co-written with coworking spaces from Athens. Thank you The Cube, Stone Soup and Athens Makerspace for contributing.
Did you know that, CoLab, which opened in 2010 and has now been transformed and renamed The Cube, was actually an idea pitched at the Startup Weekend?
“Like many we had also been directly affected by the crisis in Greece and we were bold and crazy enough to create our next job investing everything we had and didn’t have into a crazy new adventure. It’s been a real roller coaster but so worth it and rewarding.” — Maria, co-founder of The Cube.
Since CoLab, other coworking spaces have flourished in Athens.
In 2011, Loft2Work opened its doors, with the vision to build a space Encouraging & supporting Social Entrepreneurship as a means to promote social justice and alleviate poverty. Loft2Work was also very popular for organizing events centered on people rather than on businesses.
In 2012, 123p opened its doors with the objective to become THE place in town for startups. Renamed today the Found.ation, it is the leading technology and innovation enabling platform in SE Europe, acting as a startup hub, a digital transformation accelerator for corporations and a tech education hive.
Coworking has no borders and this is very true for Impact Hub Athens. After studying in Vienna and Madrid and working out of Impact Hub in both respective cities, , Dimitris Kokkinakis and Sophie Lamprou, returned to Athens and decided to create the brand there in 2013. Since then, Impact Hub Athens has had tremendous impact on the city, gathering professionals working for social good and organizing some of the most incredible project such as El Sistema Greece which promotes inclusion and integration for refugee children through music education and even had a huge concert at the Acropolis last summer.
In 2014, Olga and Klaas have opened Stone Soup. When we asked Olga what pushed them to open a coworking space, she told us, she got inspired by Amsterdam.
“The Dutch capital inspired me professionally, made me confident and showed me how to put in action my ideas. It also convinced me that the north was not my place to be. I came back to Greece with the dream to implement better the work I was doing in Amsterdam. I thought I would do it better because in Greece it mattered more and the impact would be bigger for my entourage and myself. So I started networking and bringing people together and we started sharing the same roof, working together and making plans for new projects, or in other words, I initiated Stone Soup by placing a pot with water on fire and threw in it some stones. Then it all started cooking…” — Olga, Stone Soup
The people of Stone Soup are…
“Professionals with one foot set in Greece and the other somewhere abroad. You cannot afford to be based only in Greece nor to depend your sales only in the local market. I think the people that surround us are motivated and adventurous with great stories to share and they can surely inspire you. They like the warm and casual vibe at Stone Soup. The ability to easily interact with other co-workers and the feeling of ownership at the space. We started as a cooperative space, and while we maintain our coop ideals, we have matured as a business and we offer our services in a more structured way. But we remain open. Whomever would like to join, they are welcome. We do not ask for a membership fee in order to share our network or knowledge and we try to operate with no strings attached. “
What if an old cosmetic factory could transform into a beautiful and modular coworking space? This is exactly what happened in 2016, when Th. Tsiropoulos and V. Stavropoulos opened the beautiful Tzaferi16. The modern and contemporary look of the space makes it a great place not only for work but also for events.
But Athens is not just about coworking spaces. The makers scene is also growing and flourishing, We visited Athens Makerspace, a young non profit organisation, founded in March 2016. When Ilias and his team started it, their vision was clear:
“Every person, of every age, must have access to the tools and knowledge they need to implement their ideas. We associate ourselves with the ideas of sustainable design, innovation and fabrication.”
What do people work on at Athens Makerspace? Well, pretty much anything it seems:
“Our members work on a variety of projects. We have amateurs, intermediate makers and professionals. So many amazing creations are taking place in our makerspace. Members who use the laser cutter to create jewelry, handbags, signs and more to sell. Members using the woodshop and electronics lab to create a full size arcade. Members who use the 3D printers and the electronics lab to create custom automations and robots. A member who uses the sewing machine to create reusable tea bags and much more. We are even developing production methods to upcycle plastic waste. Our members can use our equipment for practical, professional or artistic reasons. They are encouraged to innovate, prototype solutions meet other makers, learn and share their knowledge. There are so many possibilities. The sky is the limit!”
The opening of Athen Makerspace has inspired others. LUDD a lab for Open Design and Fabrication opened its doors in 2017. More than just a space, LUDD is a platform where the latest developments in open design, prototyping and fabrication technology, along with shared know-how, serve as the basis for a community of individuals, organizations and broader initiatives, to connect and collaborate, thus accelerating local innovation. We had the pleasure to visit Manolis, one of the co-founder and his team and were really impressed by the amount of cool projects that are built in the space. From furniture to more complex pieces, creativity has no boundaries at LUDD.
Today, Athens coworking and maker scenes have reached a new milestone. With more than 10 coworking spaces around the city and more coming, the population becomes more and more familiar with the concept of coworking and its benefits.
Chatting with our contributors, they gave us very different perspective on it:
“But I think lately it has evolved to a more self-sustained business and the market is growing. I think people are more cautious about making claims as to how much the startup hype is able to support the co-working business and the overall economy.” — Olga, Stone Soup
“The fact that we started the 1st coworking space in Athens in times of crisis actually helped people think outside the box and become go getters, innovate and create their next job not wait for it. Greeks are Entrepreneurs and we all know that crisis also brings change and opportunity with it. There is a lot of brain drain but at the same time one of our services is recruiting local talent to international companies that are trying to and looking into the market in establishing here in Athens, this way giving the talent a reason to stay.” Maria, co-founder of The Cube.
Chatting about the makers scene, it is also growing and changing:
“There are a few interesting spaces in Athens that promote the maker movement. We are very proud that Athens Makerspace is the first. The unique aspect of the maker scene in our city is that it shares the Greek idea of the community. People from different organisations want to meet in the same event, have a good time and work on a project together. We give our best to make our city better in any way we can. Fortunately, there are many opportunities for people to make their ideas a reality, share their knowledge and teach others. We understand one another and we also welcome newcomers who really want to learn and be part of the community”. In the centre of Athens there are so many hidden little shops that you can buy handmade objects or materials for your project. Some of them dating decades back. The maker scene here has a beautiful history full of handcrafters that we are trying to uphold.” Andriana, Community Manager, Athens Makerspace
a discussion with the local coworking actors.
Maria, Co-founder The Cube
“It has great potential things are changing, we have been past the hive phase and the community is maturing. The biggest problem is bureaucracy into setting up and running a business in Greece and as I already mentioned brain drain and talent moving abroad seeking for opportunities at this current phase.”
Olga, Co-founder Stone Soup
“I think the scene will become a lot more international. When we started almost 100% of our residents were Greek but now you can see 50% Greek and the other half is a mixture of different nationalities. People come either to live in Athens or to spend some time (1–3 months). The digital nomad paradigm is getting of the ground.”
Andriana, Community Manager, Athens Makerspace
“There are 3 reasons why we believe that in the future more people will prefer making, repairing, upcycling or reusing than buying.
First of, the environmental awareness is currently spreading and thankfully becoming part of our everyday life will be the main reason for that.
Secondly, many makers are finding a way to make a living through their creations ($$$!). And last but not least, despite the above, creative thinking and handmaking is a very important part of life that has been ignored in the past decades. It creates a special bond with all the stuff that surrounds us, adding so much value to everything that is custom-made rather than mass produced. Plus, it is proven to provide some serious psychotherapy in this rapidly evolving world.
We really hope that in the near future, schools will start incorporate the making aspect in their teaching methods. Building mini makerspaces in-school or asking people to do workshops for the students or even have a teacher that specializes in this field. The hands-on education is proven to be an amazing method and we believe that it’s time for schools in Athens to embrace it.
Also something that we notice more and more lately is the increase of women in the maker movement. Right now we have more women working on projects in Athens Makerspace than we ever did. We really hope and believe that this will continue as the social stereotypes that created a gender imbalance in the community, gradually fade.”
📨 Subscribe to our once a month newsletter to follow our startup project and meet the awesome people we encounter along the way in the coworking spaces of the world.What’s your story? Tell us on Twitter @COWORKIES.

Title: ‘‘Cricket,Cricket,Cricket’’ — Welcome to Athens!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
My partner and I love to travel! (I mean who doesn’t?) Therefore we decided to visit the magnificent Greek city also known as Athens! You may be sitting there questioning the title, (Cricket, Cricket) and some of you may have guessed by now. Even though Athens is the capital city of Greece and a place that's crowded with shopaholics- the sound of crickets fill the air all day long. However, I am sure the locals are used to it.
When it comes to travelling we always try to budget and can always stick to it! (That is a complete lie.) We think about the places we want to visit and places we want to stay. Wherever in the world you may visit — you do not always get to visit each and every corner of the city, so our top attractions/activities depend on the amount of time we have in that city.
How many days is enough to visit Athens?
The time spent in a city all depends on the reason for visiting. For example you may visit for the beautiful sceneries, the outstanding history or you just love to open up your wallet and get straight into those bougie stores. However, in our case we just wanted to wallow in to delicious food and visit the still standing historical attractions. We had spent just under 2 nights in Athens. That is more than enough time to see the top attractions and indulge in all the finest foods Athens has to offer.
Two nights? Run me through your itinerary…
Sure. We arrived midday of August, and as soon as we landed and stepped foot outside the airport- the August heat lashed onto our skins! This may sound overdramatic- but do bare in mind we are from England and the sun does not do us great favours! As I was saying, the heat was a lot and we had to find transport to reach us to our accommodation. I love to use public transport when we travel to a foreign country and I am slightly against using taxis all the time unless it’s needed. Only because it takes away the enjoyment of feeling what it is like living like a local. However, I did regret this as soon as we reached because :
BUT mainly because
2. Public transport was not looking promising- it was overly crowded and that’s not what you want when you are carrying around your suitcase and a few other bags. So eventually we found a cab (baring in mind this took up to an hour) that took us straight to our accommodation.
Once we reached our apartment — we freshened up and gushed ourselves with sunscreen lotion! (Wearing sunscreen lotion sometimes feels like you are going to war with the sun — I mean you kind of are if you think about it.)
We decided to visit the most famous attractions of Athens first- I mean it would be an insult not to! The Acropolis and The Parthenon. On the way there I was imagining what it would look like — of course I knew the scenery would be beautiful but photos do not do justice — it looked incredible! ( Now for those of you that do not know what the The Acropolis is — well then you will just have to Google it.) It was a sight that caught my eye. Stairs took you straight to the top of the attraction and there you could take in the breath-taking views. (I will leave some helpful tips at the end, so do have a look.)
Next, we were starving — so we decided to take our last few photos and get some lunch/dinner (can we call that chinner?) We wanted to try Greek food- however, when it comes to being a vegetarian it is not that simple, especially in Europe.
First stop: Street Souvlaki — Gyros time! How was it? Personally, I liked it. It was stuffed with aubergine, courgette, halloumi cheese and chips and drizzled with chilli jam. Ok, for those of you that don’t love their vegetables this may not sound appealing — but it was good, I liked it. My husband on the other hand, ‘eh’. For those of you that don’t know what that means, it means, well it means ‘eh’.
Next cheeky stop: crêpes anyone? Yes please! Whatever happens on holiday stays on holiday and in your belly. Dessert is a must on holiday so we found a cute little dessert shop that were making crêpes and the smell dragged us in! We bought a crepe to share, (which we don’t usually do, but hey sharing is caring.) The smell of Nutella tickled by taste buds and to top it of with some Strawberries.
Day 2: Don’t cha wish you girlfriend liked to shop like me? Don’t cha… (no not really)
The above title is giving mixed messages to you all — Yes, Athens is great for shopping — but we visited a few stores and we were done! I guess shopping isn’t for everyone. But for those of you that love shopping the main place to visit would be Ermou Street.
Next, we decided to visit: The Acropolis Museum
Which was filled with historical artefacts from the ancient times. It was fascinating and definitely worth the visit. Below the museum lay a phenomenal ancient civilisation which has been preserved very well. Archaeologists had used the remains of what was found to get an idea of what the different areas were used for.
Lastly, we decided to go for dinner before we called it a night. We decided to fill our bellies with indian food, so we visited Namaste — which is a walking distance from the museum. The food was delicious. Authentic? Yes, very much.
That was all for Athens. Next stop — Naxos! But hey that’s for another day.
Check out the helpful tips below:
2. Keep a hat, sunglasses, water and sunscreen with you at all times. ( if you didn’t guess so already — it gets kind of hot.)
3. I would recommend to book a taxi when arriving in Athens to take you to your accommodation. Taxis were a nightmare to find/contact. (Uber does work in Athens — so we used this. For the rest of your trip you can use public transport but the scheduled times are not always correct.)
4. There is a lot of walking involved when you want to visit the main attractions — I do recommend hiring a car. Unless you love to walk — then go ahead!
5. Greek Salad is amazing! Definitely try it out.
6. Baklava is popular in Greece so I would try this too.

Title: (Greece)Breathing in Ancient Echoes: A Journey Through Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Stepping off the metro and into the sun-drenched streets of Athens feels like opening a history book with the pages still whispering secrets. The air carries a warm, dry breeze laced with the scent of jasmine and grilled souvlaki. You turn a corner, and there it is: the Acropolis, standing guard over the city like an old friend greeting you after years apart.
No photograph truly captures the magic of the Acropolis. The way the Parthenon’s marbled columns glow rose-gold at dusk, or how the ancient stones hum with stories of philosophers and poets cannot be fully conveyed. Standing before this magnificent ancient structure, you can directly feel the wonder created by human creativity and perseverance. The Parthenon, standing firm for 2,500 years, is not merely a building but a symbol of human civilization that transcends time, offering a moment that stays in your heart.
Lose yourself in Plaka, Athens’ old neighborhood nestled at the Acropolis foot. Cobblestone lanes twist between pastel houses draped in bougainvillea, their wobbly pavement echoing every step you take. Every corner reveals a tiny kafenío spilling laughter and card games, a cat sunning itself on a doorstep, or an artisanal shop selling hand-painted ceramics. Stay close to a map, but feel free to get delightfully lost — each turn brings a new discovery.
In Monastiraki, the pulse of modern Athens beats alongside relics of every era. Street musicians serenade you near the flea market, where you can barter for vinyl records, vintage postcards, or a well-loved leather bag. Perch on the marble steps of Hadrian’s Library, feeling centuries-old stones under your fingertips while absorbing the vibrant energy of the streets.
Walking through Athens, you’ll discover the remarkable coexistence of modern and ancient. You might be strolling down a busy shopping street and suddenly encounter the ruins of a Roman-era amphitheater, or see columns of the 2,000-year-old ancient Agora standing right next to a modern coffee shop. Especially at sunset, the ancient ruins take on an almost living quality in the golden light that embraces the city.
With every step, the pavement beneath your feet seems to tell stories of the past. When you place your hand on an old stone wall, the warmth of the stone that has stood in that place for thousands of years creates a connection to the past through your palm. In Athens’ narrow alleyways, echoes sometimes reverberate, sounding almost like the whispers of ancient Greeks.
During my stay, I had the opportunity to visit the historic Piraeus Port on a business trip. As Athens’ main harbor for over 2,500 years, Piraeus offers a fascinating blend of maritime heritage and modern commerce. The bustling port, one of the largest in the Mediterranean, serves as Greece’s gateway to the world and a reminder of the nation’s enduring connection to the sea.
Walking along the waterfront, I watched massive cruise ships and cargo vessels docked alongside traditional fishing boats, their colorful hulls bobbing gently in the harbor. The scent of salt water mingled with the aroma of fresh seafood from tavernas lining the marina. Locals call this area “the heart of Greek shipping,” and it’s easy to see why — the energy here is different from central Athens, more cosmopolitan yet deeply rooted in maritime tradition.
After my meetings concluded, I explored the charming neighborhoods surrounding the port. Mikrolimano, with its horseshoe-shaped marina lined with seafood restaurants, offered stunning views where I watched fishermen mending their nets — a practice unchanged for centuries. In Pasalimani, elegant yachts suggested modern luxury while the nearby Archaeological Museum of Piraeus housed bronze statues recovered from the harbor’s depths, a testament to the port’s ancient significance.
The contrast between Piraeus and central Athens provided a fuller understanding of Greek identity — while the Acropolis represents Greece’s philosophical and cultural heritage, Piraeus embodies its seafaring spirit and commercial prowess that have sustained the nation throughout history.
On my last evening, I climbed Filopappou Hill just as the sun dipped below the Aegean horizon. The city sprawled beneath me — rust-red rooftops giving way to olive groves and distant azure. A street musician began to strum a haunting melody on his bouzouki, each note drifting through the twilight haze. I closed my eyes and let the music, the breeze, the ancient stones all blend together. In that instant, Athens wasn’t just a city of ruins; it was a living masterpiece, forever echoing with the laughter, dreams, and tears of everyone who ever called it home.
Athens isn’t about rushing from one selfie spot to the next. It’s about pausing to feel time fold onto itself — sharing sweet moments with locals at dawn, or watching street life unfold as light dances across the Acropolis. It’s a place that invites you to slow down, to breathe in history, and to savor both the grand and the minute details of daily life. When you leave, you carry a piece of that magic with you — a sense of grounded wonder and the comforting knowledge that some moments are eternal.
Safe travels, dear friend. May your heart be as full as mine was, and may Athens whisper its stories to you, too.

Title: AYS SPECIAL FROM ATHENS: One night in Exarcheia
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Daily news digests from the field, mainly for volunteers and refugees on the route, but also for journalists and other parties.

--
Listen
Share
The night I slept in Exarcheia was perhaps the turning point. My phone had been stolen, I had been caught at the airport six times, each time returned. I had even once dyed my hair blond and worn coloured lenses to appear more ‘European’ — it seems so ridiculous now.
In Exarcheia I was surrounded by hashashin, every nation, class and colour united in smoking weed, perhaps the best form of integration there is. It was cold, January 2017, and I was lucky, because it was the only night that I slept outside, unlike so many others.
I woke the next morning and came across another guy, also young like me, with green eyes, from Latakia. He had also slept on the street that night, but he looked so clean I could not believe he was sleeping rough. Seeing him, a guy more or less my age in the same situation, made me realise that I was not alone and that there were so many others like me trying to find a way to survive. After so many failures, sleeping on the street, losing so much money on wasted attempts to smuggle myself out of Greece, I began to understand that this was not the path for me.
That morning at 5am I went to Katekhaki (the Greek asylum service) and I also received my first fine for not paying my metro ticket. I took the fine, smiled, said, ‘efharisto poly’ (thank you very much in Greek) and kept on towards Katekhaki, throwing away the paper fine on the way.
This was the first fine of forty similar fines I would receive over the next two years, thanks to the incredible Greek system of fining people who clearly cannot pay their tickets. As a conscientious member of Greek society now, I pay my monthly transport, but those fines amounted to 1,200 euros. Of course, I never ever thought of that at the time.
Why did I go to Katekhaki? Because six months previously I had not attended my asylum interview — I had been far too focused on the idea of getting out of Greece to find my brother in Sweden. Besides, no one helped you in Greece, there was no accommodation, the only option for me was the squats. It did not feel like a place that offered stability, or a future. But now it seemed like I needed to change my plan, and so I went to Katekhaki and took my asylum card and the date for my interview, which was to be three months later. I returned to Exarcheia, managed to stay in a squat for three days and there met a group of Spanish people who were to offer me my first place to stay.
I began to plan. To me, the most important things was finding a job, and so I thought about what seemed to me to be a previous life, but one that had given me experiences that now I could draw upon.
In Damascus I had always been interested in technology — my brother had bribed me to do well in my exams with the promise of a laptop. He tricked me and gave the laptop to someone else, but then relented and bought me a newer one; he could see how much it meant to me I think.
I had studied technology in college for a while and then in Turkey I had managed to get some work at Vodaphone and had started to study coding. Whenever I needed to learn something I went to one place: youtube. Since Damascus, through Turkey and here in Greece, it is always the place I go to for learning new things, for inspiration and motivation.
I began to work, buying old phones and then mending and updating them and selling them on. I even made money online — just imagine 989 euros in my paypal, untouchable because there was no account for it to be transferred to. No one would accept my Greek Asylum white card as valid ID. I felt as if I was some sort of ethereal phantom, magically working online, but for no material benefit, except for the personal satisfaction of seeing the numbers on the screen and dreaming about what I would do with the money if it was physically in my possession.
Many things have happened since then, many of which we will all experience in our lives as refugees — the struggle to find a job, a home, a way to build a life. I realise I am not unique in this sense and this motivated me to try and help others in any way I can.
For a year I was lucky to be involved with a youth centre which gave me accommodation in exchange for volunteering there. I was always trying to think of new ways of making money within the narrow confines of Greek law where you cannot have a bank account unless you have a job. I helped people write CVs, gave courses on computer software, computer literacy, anything that I felt could be helpful for people like me looking for a future here.
I got a job, went to the training and got 99% on my coding exam, although to be honest it was my third retake. Then the company told me to go home, because the Greek system did not issue my AFM (tax number) fast enough. I tried everything, applying from different offices, with my company (which arranges all the necessary visas, AFMs and accommodation for their foreign workers), on my own, with a Greek person, anything! In the Exarcheia office where I originally registered I went with a Greek friend to check on the progress of my AFM which I had submitted a month previously. Eventually one clerk at the office whispered to my friend, ‘the person you need to talk to is in the toilet. Wait until he comes out and try and get him before he goes into the office.’ A couple of minutes later a large man with an even larger belly waddled out of the toilet, sideways. My friend tried to speak with him, but all she received was a dismissive gesture and a grunt. I had felt as if I had done everything, I had never given up, I had given so much of my time to learning and teaching others and had got this job, only to lose it because of a stupid bureaucracy.
It seems so funny now, looking back on it, because a month after that we returned and I managed to get my AFM, from the same toad-man. It had arrived maybe 10 days after I had visited the first time, but they had never bothered to call me.
In my despair my Greek friend put it in perspective. She too had suffered from this system, it was not specifically discrimination because I was a refugee, but rather an inefficient system that makes it impossible even for ordinary Greeks to do apparently simple things. Obtaining an AFM was my right as someone with residency, I had to be reminded that it would come eventually, that this was part of the journey, even if it felt as if Greece wanted me to personally suffer.
That was two months ago. Now, one AFM, a bank account and a 1,200 euro fine later, I am working as a software developer in a company that I dreamed of working for when I was in Syria. I could not have done this in Germany, France, Belgium or Holland, and so, although I spent so much time and money trying to escape this country, it turns out that this is one of the few places I can actually get the experience I need to continue my career.
What kept me going after that night in Exarcheia, before that in Turkey and Lesvos, was always having a plan and working out how to make it happen. In every situation, even if it is new, or potentially stressful and unfamiliar, I see opportunities to explore, make new contacts, learn something new. I truly believe that anyone can do what I have done, they just need focus, flexibility and a willingness to learn.
Be independent, do not follow the bad habits of others, and recognize that sometimes what works for others may not work for you. Make the most of your time and plan your day, week, month, even your year. Wherever you go there are opportunities to learn. Even in Athens, where I thought there was nothing, there are lots of different places that offer amazing training in languages and other skills.
Live in the present, but always think about the next step, and trust yourself. And use youtube!
(Written by one of many asylum seekers living in Athens)
We strive to echo correct news from the ground through collaboration and fairness.

Title: 3.4 Coming of Age in Athens
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

See educational website firstphilosophers.com

--
Listen
Share
Socrates’ borough or deme was Alopece, located in the immediate suburbs of Athens to the southeast. In his constitutional reforms of 508 BC, Cleisthenes identified and distributed the hundred and thirty-nine demes among ten administrative “tribes,” replacing four mutually hostile kinship tribes. He designed the new mapping to break up family dynasties and regional interest groups, so as to force people from different regions of Attica to work together (ch. 2*). The new tribes were given important political functions; for instance, each tribe annually elected a general to serve as one of the commanders of the Athenian armed forces for that year.
Each tribe also contributed fifty members to the Council every year, and each deme received proportionate representation within their tribe’s cohort of members. Socrates’ Alopece, belonging to the tribe of Antiochis, sent ten citizens to the Council annually. Socrates himself would serve his deme as a Council representative in the year 407/6 BC (see ch. 19.4*).
After the deme system was configured based on the geographical location of boroughs in Attica, one’s membership in it became hereditary. Consequently, the son always belonged to the deme of his father, even if he moved to another location and resided within the geographical boundaries of a different deme. In reality, however, people tended to remain in the same villages for centuries, as was often the case in Europe before recent times. Socrates’ deme in the suburbs of Athens was convenient for a man who frequented the city streets, so it seems likely that he continued to live in his ancestral home in Alopece.
When he was eighteen, Socrates was presented to the demarch or borough chairman as a candidate for citizenship. Since the city of Athens kept no vital records, family members and close acquaintances had to swear that he had reached his eighteenth birthday. They also had to swear that his father was a citizen. In the year that Socrates came of age, Pericles pushed through a bill that required that not only a man’s father, but also his mother must be Athenian in order to qualify for citizenship. Socrates must have met the more stringent requirement, for his name was duly entered in the deme’s register of youth eligible for citizenship.
After the deme certified Socrates and his age-mates, they sent the records to the Council, which conducted a review (dokimasia) to verify that the information was correct. After this last step, Socrates would have become a citizen and, therefore, eligible to participate in civic processes, except those with an age requirement. For instance, to hold some offices a citizen must have attained the age of thirty. Public records henceforth would certify his age and thus eligibility for office — and for military service.
Hereafter he was officially known by his “demotic” name, Socrates of Alopece, a designation meant to identify citizens with their boroughs more closely than with their families, so as to counteract the powerful influence of family groups (indicated by the patronymic, for instance, Socrates son of Sophroniscus) on the politics of the city.
Socrates now became a cadet or ephebe (ephēbos), subject to military training and assignment. In the fourth century, cadets received rigorous military training, performed in parades and exhibitions and served in garrisons around the city for two years. Spartan cadets had received rigorous military and survival training from an early time. It is not clear, however, how much formal training Socrates received in his time as a cadet in mid-fifth-century Athens. He may have served on garrison and patrol duty in the city and the borders of Attica but with little formal training.
Fortunately for Socrates, around 451 when he’d come of age, Cimon was invited to return early to Athens from his exile and negotiated a five-year truce with the Spartans whom the great statesman favored (see ch. 2.5*). Cimon then led an expedition to raid Persian territory in Egypt and Cyprus while Socrates was still serving at home as a cadet. About the time Socrates finished his two-year training, Cimon died and a treaty was negotiated with the Persian Empire, initiating a period of relative peace for several years.
As Socrates completed his military training, after having finished his brief formal education some years before, he succeeded at the age of twenty to the estate of an independent citizen in 449. He came of age just at the time when a thoroughgoing democracy was being instituted in Athens for the first time. Socrates would continue his education by participating in a government that called on the talents of all its citizens to carry out its business. As we shall see, Socrates never aimed at political leadership, but he could not escape holding offices or, in what was considered an equally political responsibility, participating in the armed services of Athens. He would serve bravely in the army and would, by chance or by fate, hold the very highest office in the government — for one day.
In Socrates’ time, Athens led the Greek world in drawing on the talents of all its citizens to govern the city. As Pericles would say some eighteen years later in his famous funeral oration, speaking of the comprehensive Athenian experience with excusable pride, “In summary, I declare that our whole city is the school of Greece.”

Philosopher, classicist, historian of ancient science.

Title: The Niarchos Center, a resonant sweet spot of urban design
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
On a recent trip to Athens, I visited the Niarchos Center, a new cultural complex just south of Athens housing the Greek National Library (GNL) and the Greek National Opera (GNO). The 566 million euro project, designed by architect Renzo Piano, was completed in 2016 by the Stavros Niarchos Foundation.
This place is unlike anything else in Athens. Or anywhere really. It really feels like — the future.
A beautiful, glass-clad building gleams over the city with a long reflective canal glimmering by its side.
The modernistic building feeds into an organized labyrinth of small beautiful parks and gardens composed of Mediterranean climate shrubbery.
The complex is free and open to the public to “flaner”, explore, and play.
While we didn’t visit the Opera House or the Library which are both supposedly world-class, we strolled along the outside spaces and walked with our jaws figuratively dropped in awe, impressed by the beauty and detail of all the elements that just seemed — to work. The spaces were clean and well-maintained, but not sterile. People of all ages were walking, children were playing, teenagers were gathering in some of the nooks and crannies but in a fun not sketchy way. There were bike stations that were being used — but not abused.
The element that impressed us the most was the playground — or rather, the playgrounds, with an s. There were multiple “play” spaces for different ages. Even for adults!
For the youngest crowd (10month — 2 years) where we spent the most time, the playground was composed of countless jungle gym structures mostly made of wood — both aesthetic and functional. There was a manual lever system spewing water to play with. The kids ran around barefoot laughing and screaming. The parents were sitting on the benches around, relaxed. It was the best playground I’ve ever seen.
And again, it was that perfect balance between clean (but not sterile feeling) and utilised. A resonant sweet spot. I imagine this usage is every parks and recreation enthusiast’s dream. Occasionally we’d see a security or maintenance person walk by. So we knew that this beautiful fragile equilibrium was maintained by a very well-planned and methodical “back office”.
Now apparently, the privately-owned complex is to be donated to the Greek state and publicly-run. And the big question that everyone is asking is — can this fragile sweet spot persist if the complex is run by the state?
The doubt is founded — especially when you visit the numerous public parks across Athens which are abandoned and dilapidated with defunct playgrounds. And though some parks like the Pedion tou Areos are lush and quite beautiful, they are coined as “dangerous” as pockets of “immigrants, drug addicts, and radicals” inhabit the spaces. So families will tend to avoid these parks.
As a new parent, I’ve only recently been attuned to the huge importance of parks and green spaces in cities.
The contrast between the Niarchos Center and the Pedion tou Areos is flagrant — and frustrating. With the Niarchos Center, you see that the harmonious populated park CAN work. But why doesn’t it work — with a beautiful park right in central Athens?
This being said, the Pedion tou Areos has a certain charm. A charm that actually artist communities seem to be drawn to. And these communities want to engage people to the park’s alluring ecosystem.
So how do we find that right mix to create a sustainable harmonious park space for all ages to feel free, safe, and relaxed?
Is it a question of public versus private management? Top-down or bottom-up planning?
We’ll be back in a couple months to see if and how things have evolved with both parks.
And back to the Niarchos Center, we haven’t even explored the intricate ecological design of the complex — with 10,000m2 of solar panels and the labyrinth of parks and gardens that I’ve alluded to that serve as a roof garden for the building.
Athens is such a rich, complicated, juxtaposing city — I imagine an urban planner’s heaven and hell.
But in any case, if you go to Athens, make sure to visit the Niarchos Center. AND the Pedion tou Areos park.
--
--
Excited about energy, music, and how to live more consciously and respectfully of nature and others.

Title: Three small islands off the coast of Athens you need to visit
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Beyond Mykonos, Santorini, Crete, and even Athens, there is much more to Greece than these touristy destinations. Three small day-trip islands you should visit next time you visit Greece are Aegina, Hydra, and Poros. Each island off the coast of Greece has a unique history because the city-states of modern-day Greece were not unified until the mid-17th century, following the Greek revolution against the Ottoman empire.
Aegina is one of the closest islands to the coast of Athens. From Piraeus port, the island is a short forty-five minuet to hour ferry ride. The water surrounding Aegina is very clean, thus home to sea urchins. Don’t let them deter you, just use caution when swimming in the shallow pebbled water surrounding the coast because the views are well worth the swim. Paralia Marathona beach is a short drive from the port, and the views from the beach of nearby islands look like a scene from Jurassic park. The mountains jut out of the water just a few kilometers away, covered in greenery, and appear untouched. When in Aegina you must visit the Temple of Aphena, which is about a 15-minute drive from the port. The temple is the second best-preserved temple in all of Greece, and directly faces the city of Athens. The island of Aegina is also known for being one of the few places in Greece that grows pistachios. When returning to the port, it is paramount that you try any number of the many pistachio products sold downtown. My favorite was the pistachio butter which tasted exactly like Nutella. Some friends of mine loved the pistachio liquor, which I recommend asking to try but wasn’t my favorite.
My second favorite day-trip island is Hydra, which is about a two-hour ferry ride from Athens. Hydra is a very small, narrow island that does not permit cars, motorcycles, or ATVs of any kind. So you will find donkeys lining the port, awaiting to carry travelers and their luggage up the mountainside. Hydra does have beaches, but they are only accessible by boat on the opposite side of the island from the port. There are cliff-jumping sites that line the rest of the coast. Apart from swimming, there is an island museum and a golden star art structure you can view from the coast side, which is a short walk from the port. Hydra also has cliffside bars and cafes with some of the best views I have seen in Greece. I highly recommend getting breakfast or dinner and taking in the views for a few hours because they are what Instagram is made of.
My third island recommendation is Poros, which like Aegina, is also about an hour ferry ride from the Piraeus port. The views from Athens to Poros are unmatched. You pass many seaside cliffs, and uninhabited islands and may even see some dolphins as I did. The water changes from deep blue to bright seafoam green along the way and is some of the clearest, brightest, saltiest water I have ever swam in. Upon our arrival to Poros, we witnessed a greek wedding take place just off the coast on a tiny island that was just big enough for a church and about fifty standing guests. The port town is quiet and faces another costal town of the mainland less than a kilometer away, creating a natural canal. The townspeople are extremely hospitable and grateful for our small purchases. These islands also heavily rely on tourism for revenue but receive much less foot traffic than the better-known islands. After browsing the shops, we followed the clock tower signs through the mountainside homes to the highest point of Poros. At the top, we were welcomed with an amazing sunset view of the surrounding islands. Because Poros is a much smaller island, their souvenirs were very cheap, so I stalked up on postcards, a new towel, and some sunglasses before we headed back to Athens.
I have found that these smaller islands just off the coast of the mainland are much more affordable, welcoming, and just as stunning as the well-known islands of Mykonos, Santorini, and Crete. Greece is all about taking a step out of the hustle and bustle of life, so I encourage everyone to take a few day trips to the quiet and forgotten islands and truly get a feel for the authentic greek culture.
--
--
American study abroad student currently living in Athens, Greece. Follow along for life updates, and topics I find strange and helpful to know.

Title: What has Lystra got to do with Athens?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
As a follow up to last week’s blog (on the ‘nod of recognition’) I want to reflect on how to connect with different demographics in our preaching.
Francis Schaeffer talked about Lystra and Athens and Romans chapter 1:18–32 as Paul ‘addressing the world without a Bible’.
In all these places Paul is addressing a common religious consciousness that is found in every society and every person. This religious consciousness is articulated differently from person to person, and sometimes it is not articulated at all.
In Acts Paul tackles people without a Bible is very different ways. In the best known of these sermons he preaches in Athens to intellectuals who were used to expressing and evaluating new ideas (Acts 17), using careful reasoning and making use of well-chosen cultural references to connect with his target audience.
Dan Strange, in his book Plugged In, describes the process of Paul’s preaching in Athens using four E’s:
Enter — Explore — Expose — Evangelise
Strange’s pattern reminds the preacher that before speaking there is a need to observe and listen in each situation. Preachers are taught to carefully exegete Scripture, but they are not always taught to exegete their audiences. Both these tasks are important if we are to communicate effectively.
It is important to note that both here and in Lystra, Paul does not quote any biblical text, but his sermons in both places are underpinned by a scriptural God-centred worldview.
What is interesting is that Paul’s approach in Athens is very different from what we see Lystra. He does not preach in the same way to a farming community as he does to the philosophers in Athens.
In Athens Paul uses careful reasoning and quotes from poets and philosophers; in Lystra, by contrast, he makes use of more common place points of contact such as the cycles of the seasons and patterns of sunshine and rainfall. These were the things that preoccupied the thinking of those who lived in a rural community that was dependant on the land.
The key for the preacher in Paul’s flexible strategy is that from the same basic theological premise that the Lord God is the creator and sustainer of all, he preaches a distinct message to these very different communities. In this way Paul sought to connect with the reality that God has put eternity into our hearts.
Coming back to the four E’s, I would guess that most preachers are well-practiced in the art of exposing and evangelising, but fewer are experienced at entering and exploring.
Entering and exploring involve taking a deep dive into cultural context in which we are preaching. This involves getting a feel for the things that engage a particular congregation.
Time spent asking good questions and listening carefully to the congregation will always be repaid in the ability to connect with people more effectively.
Good preachers understand Scripture and understand people.
Different genres of Scripture require different handling. You cannot preach a Psalm in the same way you preach on a letter.
Different congregations also require different handling. It is worth asking of your congregation, “Is this more like Lystra or Athens, or is it something in between?”
…
John Woods
